{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Combined strong and weak lensing analysis of 28 clusters from the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey", "authors": ["Oguri, Masamune", "Bayliss, Matthew B.", "Dahle, H\u00e2kon", "Sharon, Keren", "Gladders, Michael D.", "Natarajan, Priyamvada", "Hennawi, Joseph F.", "Koester, Benjamin P."], "author_address": ["AA(Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, University of Tokyo, 5-1-5 Kashiwanoha, Chiba 277-8583, Japan; Division of Theoretical Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, 2-21-1 Osawa, Tokyo 181-8588, Japan), AB(Department of Physics, Harvard University, 17 Oxford Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA; Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA; Department of Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA; Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA), AC(Institute of Theoretical Astrophysics, University of Oslo, PO Box 1029, Blindern, N-0315 Oslo, Norway), AD(Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA), AE(Department of Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA; Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA), AF(Department of Astronomy, Yale University, PO Box 208101, New Haven, CT 06511, USA; Department of Physics, Yale University, PO Box 208120, New Haven, CT 06520, USA), AG(Max-Planck-Institut f\u00f6r Astronomie, K\u00f6nigstuhl 17, D-69117 Heidelberg, Germany), AH(Department of Astronomy &amp; Astrophysics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA; Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, University of Chicago, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, USA)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "420", "publication_year": "2012/03/1", "start_page": "3213", "end_page": "3239", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "gravitational lensing: weak", "galaxies: clusters: general", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012MNRAS.420.3213O", "abstract": "We study the mass distribution of a sample of 28 galaxy clusters using strong and weak lensing observations. The clusters are selected via their strong lensing properties as part of the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey (SGAS) from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Mass modelling of the strong lensing information from the giant arcs is combined with weak lensing measurements from deep Subaru/Suprime-cam images to primarily obtain robust constraints on the concentration parameter and the shape of the mass distribution. We find that the concentration c<SUB>vir</SUB> is a steep function of the mass, c<SUB>vir</SUB>\u221dM<SUP>-0.59\u00b10.12</SUP><SUB>vir</SUB>, with the value roughly consistent with the lensing-bias-corrected theoretical expectation for high-mass (\u223c10<SUP>15</SUP> h<SUP>-1</SUP> M<SUB>\u2299</SUB>) clusters. However, the observationally inferred concentration parameters appear to be much higher at lower masses (\u223c10<SUP>14</SUP> h<SUP>-1</SUP> M<SUB>\u2299</SUB>), possibly a consequence of the modification to the inner density profiles provided by baryon cooling. The steep mass-concentration relation is also supported from direct stacking analysis of the tangential shear profiles. In addition, we explore the 2D shape of the projected mass distribution by stacking weak lensing shear maps of individual clusters with prior information on the position angle from strong lens modelling, and find significant evidence for a large mean ellipticity with the best-fitting value of <e>= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06 for the mass distribution of the stacked sample. We find that the luminous cluster member galaxy distribution traces the overall mass distribution very well, although the distribution of fainter cluster galaxies appears to be more extended than the total mass. <SUP> a </SUP>Photometric redshifts estimated from the SDSS data, as spectroscopic cluster redshifts are not available for these clusters. <SUP> b </SUP>Based on the spectroscopy of the brightest cluster galaxy at Apache Point Observatory 3.5-m telescope. <SUP> c </SUP>We use deep R<SUB>c</SUB>-band images retrieved from SMOKA instead of obtaining r-band follow-up images. This field includes two separate cluster cores, both of which act as strong lenses. <SUP> d </SUP>Based on the new spectroscopic observation with Gemini/GMOS conducted after the publication of Bayliss et al. (2011b).", "doi": "10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1109.2594", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012MNRAS.420.3213O", $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-cite js-item-cite\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\r\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button at-CiteButton\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal>\r\n    <i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i>\r\n    <span>Cite</span>\r\n</a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal js-citation-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Masamune Oguri, Matthew B. Bayliss, H\u00e5kon Dahle, Keren Sharon, Michael D. Gladders, Priyamvada Natarajan, Joseph F. Hennawi, Benjamin P. Koester,  Combined strong and weak lensing analysis of 28 clusters from the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 420, Issue 4, March 2012, Pages 3213\u20133239, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x\">https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\r\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Combined%20strong%20and%20weak%20lensing%20analysis%20of%2028%20clusters%20from%20the%20Sloan%20Giant%20Arcs%20Survey%26lt%3Bspan%20class%3D%26quot%3BxrefLink%26quot%3B%20id%3D%26quot%3Bjumplink-fn2%26quot%3B%26gt%3B%26lt%3B%2Fspan%26gt%3B%26lt%3Ba%20href%3D%26quot%3Bjavascript%3A%3B%26quot%3B%20reveal-id%3D%26quot%3Bfn2%26quot%3B%20data-open%3D%26quot%3Bfn2%26quot%3B%20class%3D%26quot%3Blink%20link-ref%20link-reveal%20xref-fn%20js-xref-fn%26quot%3B%26gt%3B%2A%26lt%3B%2Fa%26gt%3B&amp;publicationDate=2012-03-01&amp;volumeNum=420&amp;issueNum=4&amp;author=Oguri%2C%20Masamune%3B%20Bayliss%2C%20Matthew%20B.&amp;startPage=3213&amp;endPage=3239&amp;contentId=10.1111%2Fj.1365-2966.2011.20248.x&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\" class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767784 id=\"16767784\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We study the mass distribution of a sample of 28 galaxy clusters using strong and weak lensing observations. The clusters are selected via their strong lensing properties as part of the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey (SGAS) from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Mass modelling of the strong lensing information from the giant arcs is combined with weak lensing measurements from deep Subaru/Suprime-cam images to primarily obtain robust constraints on the concentration parameter and the shape of the mass distribution. We find that the concentration <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> is a steep function of the mass, <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u221d<em>M</em><sup>\u22120.59\u00b10.12</sup><sub>vir</sub>, with the value roughly consistent with the lensing-bias-corrected theoretical expectation for high-mass (\u223c10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>) clusters. However, the observationally inferred concentration parameters appear to be much higher at lower masses (\u223c10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>), possibly a consequence of the modification to the inner density profiles provided by baryon cooling. The steep mass\u2013concentration relation is also supported from direct stacking analysis of the tangential shear profiles. In addition, we explore the 2D shape of the projected mass distribution by stacking weak lensing shear maps of individual clusters with prior information on the position angle from strong lens modelling, and find significant evidence for a large mean ellipticity with the best-fitting value of \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06 for the mass distribution of the stacked sample. We find that the luminous cluster member galaxy distribution traces the overall mass distribution very well, although the distribution of fainter cluster galaxies appears to be more extended than the total mass.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: weak&quot;\">gravitational lensing: weak</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767786 id=\"16767786\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1\u2002INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing plays a dominant role in determining the mass distribution of distant galaxies and clusters of galaxies, because it allows direct measurements of the distribution of dark matter which accounts for \u223c90 per cent of the total matter content of the Universe. Precise measurements of dark matter distributions are important not only for understanding the formation of galaxies in the context of the hierarchical structure formation scenario, but also for testing the properties of the putative dark matter particle, in particular its cold and collisionless nature. Observations of clusters are suitable and very apt for the latter purpose, as the long cooling time-scale for hot gas in clusters indicates that the cluster gravitational potential is mainly determined by the dynamics of the dominant dark matter component which are well predicted by <em>N</em>-body simulations. However, it is also expected that the baryonic component in clusters, which dominates the mass in the innermost regions, should play an important role at some point.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are two regimes of gravitational lensing that can be employed to measure and map the mass distribution in clusters. One is strong lensing, i.e. the regime that produces drastic lensing events with highly elongated arcs or multiple images of background objects (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kochanek 2006</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan 2011, for reviews). The other lensing regime is weak lensing wherein statistical measurements of small distortions in the shapes of background galaxies are produced by a massive, foreground cluster (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bartelmann &amp; Schneider 2001</a>, for a review). Since strong and weak lensing probe mass distributions at different radii, the combination of these two is powerful and essential for the full understanding and detailed mapping of the gravitational potential of clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing studies of clusters have indeed confirmed several important predictions of the standard \u039b-dominated cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model. For instance, from numerical simulations, the radial run of the density of the mass distribution is predicted to have a universal form, that of the Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW) profile (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro, Frenk &amp; White 1996</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Detailed lensing measurements of massive clusters have confirmed this prediction by and large, although there does appear to be some cluster to cluster variations (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>). Another important prediction is that massive clusters are on average highly non-spherical with a typical major-to-minor axial ratio of \u223c2:1 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto 2002</a>). Weak lensing measurements of dark matter distributions in a sample of massive clusters have directly confirmed this prediction as well (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2010</a>). Furthermore, lensing analysis of several merging clusters of galaxies strongly supports the collisionless nature of dark matter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b85\" data-open=\"b85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Merten et al. 2011</a>), although a possible case against the collisionless nature has also been discovered (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b74\" data-open=\"b74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mahdavi et al. 2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, measurements of the concentration parameter, which appears in the NFW profile, from gravitational lensing observations for clusters have been controversial. The concentration parameter is defined as the ratio of the virial radius to the scale radius, and is a dimensionless parameter that quantifies the degree of the mass accumulation in the innermost regions. The standard \u039bCDM model makes a prediction about this parameter too, namely that more massive haloes or haloes at higher redshifts have smaller values of the concentration parameter on average (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>). However, measurements of the dark matter distribution in the massive lensing cluster A1689 for instance, using both strong and weak lensing, have indicated that the mass distribution is surprisingly highly concentrated with an estimated concentration parameter of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 12, which is significantly higher than the expected standard \u039bCDM prediction of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 4 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b129\" data-open=\"b129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The interpretation of this result of lensing clusters being overconcentrated requires careful consideration due to the role played by projection and selection effects. This is because lensing observables can only measure the projected mass distribution, and hence the recovery of the 3D mass distribution requires additional assumptions about the elongation along the line-of-sight direction. For instance, because of the large triaxiality of dark matter haloes, the mass and concentration parameter inferred from gravitational lensing depend strongly on the orientation with respect to the line-of-sight direction. This naturally implies that both the mass and concentration are significantly overestimated when observed along the major axis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe, De Lucia &amp; King 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b103\" data-open=\"b103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless &amp; King 2007</a>). The large orientation dependence in turn suggests that strong-lensing-selected clusters represent a highly biased population with their major axes preferentially aligned with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2010</a>). Thus, the dark matter distribution of A1689 alone does not pose a severe challenge to the \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b103\" data-open=\"b103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless, King &amp; Clowe 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b127\" data-open=\"b127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno, Jetzer &amp; Lubini 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Morandi et al. 2011a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Morandi, Pedersen &amp; Limousin 2011b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b126\" data-open=\"b126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno &amp; Umetsu 2011</a>), although such high values of the concentration parameter appear to be common in the combined strong and weak lensing analysis of massive clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Comerford &amp; Natarajan 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b140\" data-open=\"b140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011b</a>). High concentrations can be tested with the distribution of the Einstein radii, but the results have still not converged (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b117\" data-open=\"b117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b139\" data-open=\"b139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b141\" data-open=\"b141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>). Also puzzling is the fact that such high concentrations have not been claimed in weak lensing analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>) or X-ray analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Buote et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori et al. 2010</a>) for samples of massive clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the combined strong and weak lensing analysis allows accurate and robust measurements of the concentration parameter, the current main limitation is the small number of clusters available for such a detailed combined analysis. The Sloan Giant Arcs Survey (SGAS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011a</a>), which is a survey of strongly lensed giant arcs from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b135\" data-open=\"b135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">York et al. 2000</a>), has already discovered more than 30 bright giant arcs and therefore offers an ideal technique to expand the sample of clusters appropriate for detailed lensing analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present a systematic study of strong and weak lensing analysis for a sample of 28 clusters from the SGAS, based on our extensive follow-up imaging observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2002</a>). We study the radial dark matter distributions of the clusters in detail to measure the concentration parameters for these clusters. For this purpose we conduct a stacked lensing analysis as well as individual modelling of clusters. With the stacked lensing technique we also study the 2D mass distribution, and constrain the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The structure of this paper is as follows. We describe our cluster sample and follow-up imaging observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>, and present the strong and weak lensing analysis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. The results are combined to discuss the mass\u2013concentration relation in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>. We also conduct a stacked lensing analysis, which is detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>. We then study the cluster member galaxy distribution in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6</a>, and summarize the main conclusions in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7\"></span><a href=\"#ss7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 7</a>. In Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> we conduct semi-analytic calculations to evaluate the effect of the lensing bias on various observables. Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a> summarizes the strong and weak lensing analysis results of individual clusters. Throughout the paper we assume the standard \u039b-dominated flat cosmological model with the matter density \u03a9<sub>M</sub>= 1 \u2212\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>= 0.275, the dimensionless Hubble constant <em>h</em>= 0.702, the baryon density \u03a9<sub>b</sub><em>h</em><sup>2</sup>= 0.022\u200355, the spectral index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>= 0.968, and a normalization for the matter power spectrum \u03c3<sub>8</sub>= 0.816 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b65\" data-open=\"b65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Komatsu et al. 2011</a>) where needed.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767795 id=\"16767795\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2\u2002CLUSTER SAMPLE AND FOLLOW-UP OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767796 id=\"16767796\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-1>2.1\u2002Cluster sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We draw our sample of clusters for detailed lensing analysis from SGAS, which involved an initial extensive visual search of giant arcs in red-sequence-selected clusters in the SDSS. The sample is constructed utilizing two selection methods. One is the SDSS \u2018Visual\u2019 survey which selects giant arc candidates from the visual inspection of the SDSS imaging data (Gladders et al., in preparation). The other survey is the SDSS \u2018Blind\u2019 survey which searches for giant arcs from <em>g</em>-band follow-up imaging of the most massive \u223c200 clusters selected from the SDSS imaging data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2008</a>). Some of the clusters have also been reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b133\" data-open=\"b133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wen, Han &amp; Jiang (2011)</a>. We are conducting massive spectroscopic follow-up observations of these new giant arcs with the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hook et al. 2004</a>) to measure redshifts for the newly discovered arcs as well as redshifts for the lensing clusters. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a> for details of our spectroscopic follow-up and successful redshift measurements for more than 20 giant arcs. We note that this paper includes a few new GMOS spectroscopy results obtained after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>. We also include two cluster-scale quasar lenses discovered from the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b104\" data-open=\"b104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b105\" data-open=\"b105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. 2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), as they satisfy similar selection criteria to the SGAS lens sample, and have also been observed at the Subaru telescope.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767798 id=\"16767798\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2>2.2\u2002Observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed the SGAS giant arc clusters with Suprime-cam (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2002</a>) at the Subaru 8.2-m telescope, primarily for the wide-field weak lensing analysis, between 2007 June and 2011 April. Combined with a few images retrieved from the archive system named SMOKA (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Baba et al. 2002</a>), our sample comprises 28 clusters with Subaru/Suprime-cam multicolour follow-up imaging. The Suprime-cam has a large field of view of \u223c34 \u00d7 27\u2003arcmin<sup>2</sup> with a pixel scale of 0.202\u2003arcsec, and is therefore ideal for weak lensing studies of massive clusters at intermediate redshifts whose typical virial radius is \u2272 10\u2003arcmin. Our strategy is to obtain deep images in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, with the longest exposure in <em>r</em> band. The deep <em>r</em>-band imaging is performed to conduct weak lensing analysis using <em>r</em>-band images, but the additional colour information from <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> bands are crucial for reliable selection of background galaxies for the weak lensing analysis (more details presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>) as well as secure identifications of multiply imaged arcs in the cluster cores. We note that the weak lensing analysis results of the first four SGAS clusters have been published in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data are reduced using <span class=\"small-caps\">sdfred</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">sdfred</span>2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b134\" data-open=\"b134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Yagi et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b111\" data-open=\"b111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ouchi et al. 2004</a>). The reduction procedure includes bias subtraction, flat-fielding, distortion correction, sky subtraction, and co-adding to generate the final mosaic images. When co-adding, we remove some of the frames which have significantly worse seeing sizes than other frames. We derive the magnitude zero-points by comparing objects in the reduced images with the photometric catalogue of the SDSS data. The astrometric calibration is performed with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin 2006</a>), again using objects in the SDSS data as astrometric reference sources. The photometric galaxy catalogue of each cluster is constructed using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>), with the Galactic extinction correction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b123\" data-open=\"b123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schlegel, Finkbeiner &amp; Davis 1998</a>). Our 28 cluster sample and basic parameters of follow-up images are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767801\" scrollto-destination=\"16767801\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster sample and summary of Subaru/Suprime-cam imaging observations. The redshifts of the clusters are taken from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>Name\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000)\u00a0</td><td>Dec. telescope.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note282\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note282\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>We use deep <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band images retrieved from SMOKA instead of obtaining <em>r</em>-band follow-up images. This field includes two separate cluster cores, both of which act as strong lenses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note283\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note283\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Based on the new spectroscopic observation with Gemini/GMOS conducted after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t1_note280\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note280\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Photometric redshifts estimated from the SDSS data, as spectroscopic cluster redshifts are not available for these clusters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note281\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note281\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Based on the spectroscopy of the brightest cluster galaxy at Apache Point Observatory 3.5-m telescope.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note282\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note282\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>We use deep <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band images retrieved from SMOKA instead of obtaining <em>r</em>-band follow-up images. This field includes two separate cluster cores, both of which act as strong lenses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note283\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note283\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Based on the new spectroscopic observation with Gemini/GMOS conducted after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767801\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767802 id=\"16767802\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3\u2002STRONG AND WEAK LENSING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767803 id=\"16767803\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1\u2002Strong lensing analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We mostly follow <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a> for the strong lens modelling methodology. Basically we assume the elliptical extension of the NFW profile (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. 1996</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) to model the mass distribution of a dark halo, and add contributions from member galaxies assuming the pseudo-Jaffe model. The velocity dispersion \u03c3 and cut-off scale <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> of the pseudo-Jaffe model are assumed to scale with the luminosity as <em>L</em>\u221d\u03c3<sup>1/4</sup> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>\u221d<em>L</em><sup>1/2</sup>. The normalization and cut-off radius may be fixed to a typical value if there are not enough observational constraints. We may also fix the centre of the main halo to the position of the brightest cluster galaxy, depending on the number of available constraints and the configuration of multiple images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify multiple images based on spectroscopic follow-up results of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a> as well as colours of lensed arcs measured from the Subaru/Suprime-cam images. While redshifts of arcs are available for many of our sample clusters, for clusters without any arc spectroscopy information we assume that the redshift of the main arc is <em>z</em><sub>arc</sub>= 2 with the conservative 1\u03c3 error of \u03c3(<em>z</em><sub>arc</sub>) = 1, because our extensive spectroscopic observations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011a</a>) as well as photometric analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss 2011</a>) have convincingly shown that most of the arcs in our sample fall in this redshift range. The positional uncertainties of all the arcs are assumed to be 1\u2003arcsec in the image plane, which is much larger than measurement uncertainties, but is typical of the uncertainties associated with parametric strong lens modelling of clusters.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We perform strong lens modelling using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>), using the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization in the source plane (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). From the derived best-fitting mass model, we compute the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> of the system by solving the following equation:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m1.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m1.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=N56gzYMIzWQ6cIQ1sakwH-jOH1p6F5EOFjDjbpotOaKWgpIn~SdAoYYV4Qgo9cgEyDWi2ybYgAJ48CxC7S7hClEyE7HjdMTW0Flgz~422cIFc6vDmZ1XL-QU52nq6ZgF95jt9pJPq8mVJKn5gz4YQLoN9EkT9GElEuxdeUVRULNFesST~BccRLEwdk606MMhjWYFPTlO7Iz7J~YieiTLfMtrxbHqx28-9LtbFE0VBxuFZme1tfuZAy4tS3JGMbE55QmdlFJgBn-nH9E0SedXGrHIPw~efNj-5Qv-azLw2Q4K73PV8jgEb9cnG39kn7zfi5Rp7tkZVc-Vsm~qI6ek~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m1.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">1</span></div> and use only this Einstein radius determination as the constraint from our strong lensing analysis. We use the Einstein radius as it is a robust quantity that is well constrained from the strong lensing modelling and is fairly insensitive to our model assumptions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>). We estimate the error on the Einstein radius by changing one (usually mass) of the parameters from the best-fitting values, optimizing other parameters, and monitoring the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> differences. However, to be conservative in our estimates, we always assign a minimum error of 10 per cent to the Einstein radius, even if the procedure above returns smaller errors, given the unaccounted complexity of cluster mass distributions and projections along line of sight (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D\u2019Aloisio &amp; Natarajan 2011</a>). For clusters without arc spectroscopy, we conservatively estimate the 1\u03c3 error on the Einstein radius by changing the arc redshift by \u00b11. The Einstein radii are computed for both the arc redshift <em>z</em><sub>arc</sub> and the fixed source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2. We use the former value for the combined strong and weak lensing analysis, whereas the latter value is used for the statistical, stacked lensing analysis.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the definition of the Einstein radius adopted here differs from that in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>. In this new definition the contribution of stellar masses is explicitly included, while in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a> the Einstein radius was computed from the dark halo component alone. The use of this modified definition is because the separation of dark and luminous components is not obvious, and has to rely on several assumptions, unless we have additional data such as the velocity dispersion measurement of the central galaxy (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b122\" data-open=\"b122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b94\" data-open=\"b94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newman et al. 2009</a>). Thus the effect of baryonic components has been taken into account in interpreting our results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> lists the Einstein radii derived from strong lensing modelling. SDSS\u2003J1226+2149 and SDSS\u2003J1226+2152 are two nearby strong lensing cores in a highly complex massive structure, both of which are covered by our Subaru/Suprime-cam imaging (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011b</a>). We perform strong lensing analysis for both cores. We also show the best-fitting ellipticity <em>e</em> and the position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> of the best-fitting main NFW component, as they are used later for 2D stacking analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5.2</a>). The best-fitting critical curves for individual clusters are presented in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767809\" scrollto-destination=\"16767809\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of strong lensing analysis. We tabulate the Einstein radii both for arc redshifts and for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2, the total number of multiple images used for strong lens modelling (<em>N</em><sub>img</sub>; the number of multiple image sets is shown in parentheses), the best-fitting ellipticity (<em>e</em>) and position angle (\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>) of the main dark halo component, and references for arc redshifts.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><td>Name\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em><sub>arc</sub><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em><sub>img</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub> clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t2_note232\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note232\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Note that for some clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. In this case we show the redshift of the main arc.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note233\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note233\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> is measured east of north.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note234\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note234\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup><em>References.</em> 1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>; 2 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2010)</a>; 3 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kubo et al. (2010)</a>; 4 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. (2003)</a>; 5 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b128\" data-open=\"b128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sharon et al. (2005)</a>; 6 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. (2006)</a>; 7 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2008b)</a>; 8 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Belokurov et al. (2009)</a>; 9 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b66\" data-open=\"b66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kubo et al. (2009)</a>; 10 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b96\" data-open=\"b96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ofek, Seitz &amp; Klein (2008)</a>; 11 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koester et al. (2010)</a>; 12 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2008)</a>; 13 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b116\" data-open=\"b116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>; 14 \u2013 new redshift not yet published in the literature; 15 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Diehl et al. (2009)</a>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767809\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong lensing analysis for some of these clusters has been published in the literature (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koester et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. 2011</a>). Our estimates of the Einstein radii presented here generally agree with these previous results. For A1703, our best-fitting Einstein radius is in excellent agreement with that of the independent strong lens modelling by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b116\" data-open=\"b116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>. An exception is SDSS\u2003J1343+4155 whose Einstein radius in our strong lens modelling result is much smaller than what presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2010)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. (2011)</a> because a large offset of the halo centre from the brightest cluster galaxy has been found in the previous analysis, whereas in the present paper the centre of the halo is fixed to the location of the brightest cluster galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767811 id=\"16767811\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2\u2002Weak lensing analysis</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For weak lensing measurements, we follow the formalism outlined in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser, Squires &amp; Broadhurst (KSB; 1995)</a> using the software package <span class=\"small-caps\">imcat</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a> We first detect objects in the reduced images using a hierarchical peak finding algorithm. For all the clusters in our sample, we use <em>r</em>-band images for weak lensing shear measurements. We then measure the shapes of objects by iteratively refining the centroid of each object. Stars for correcting the distortion of the point spread function (PSF) are selected in a standard way by identifying the appropriate branch in the magnitude half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>h</sub> plane, along with the peak significance cut \u03bd &gt; 15. Shapes of the stars are measured as a function of the size of the weight function, <em>r</em><sub>g</sub>, in order to make PSF corrections with matched <em>r</em><sub>g</sub> values. We divide each co-added image into 4 \u00d7 3 chunks and fit the PSF in each chunk independently with second-order bi-polynomials. The smear polarizability is corrected by computing a scalar polarizability <em>P</em><sub>s</sub> from the trace of the matrix, and then fitting <em>P</em><sub>s</sub> as a function of magnitude, <em>r</em><sub>g</sub>, and the galaxy ellipticity. For our weak lensing analysis, we only use galaxies with \u03bd &gt; 15 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=DhjJkfRAAtwxblzUir9KCd86UhL~GyJDbwWNWk5BcsLfzCcBy8uSS9DJSCNrtvyCplb92azHNXn6UwRFyhGB8HGT3sNJmh3FDJ~NKa31BL~EHEuqE~JDAh5RzavgRobmre-~h~FvlproByPVEfIebhqTThpxJwAbwYU7ALCbmUcXQ2FccUDU5NcN8lzaJEXNEP6JO1W40FeAVhTKE-YgR38hLKai~K2rzXjD8C-2-bd7OW6YJ1TWW38w32M8KCWMhpzkNThBxt~73DfTA8bEfc11AhTSpf2TRKItfoXq3rwIMKlX3wNPniM6mfNZSBP0nA6AZqxdFRl16s2mttzLHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu2.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=NWHWPR4mCVXIiCs2gnfKigIL0-6~KdWLt1DHG8nUp6Ftn95DbyrW1OSaPYLr-X5BjTzaj7Sn9esgokEjJv9j0cuagYRNjLlmoZv2UgU8NRf9O7PWeyhbLKDxnA8o~l8PtYaq2xi1fcj-oblclmd7MX2j6QrFQAmovac1vp6PXfKLbLzwoOST1w3CO6XIFmztWzqknVjrcr4MChjDWLM0Vsrv~Azbd62DvI4RqDeLieeH7yaNj-dZaITFPyf~Hky9KWOUhWeyCGdM5VzqSJPJvtCQt~QcnVTFQwiRjU9qrVN9mmT8uzI-URlwNodZpIxUXebLELdVoocH-RoEKGIBPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu2.gif\" /></span> and \u03c3 (<em>r</em>*<sub>h</sub>) are median and rms dispersion of half-light radii for the stars selected above. Given the general tendency of the KSB algorithm to underestimate the weak lensing shear (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Erben et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Heymans et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Massey et al. 2007</a>), we include a calibration factor of 1/0.9, i.e. this factor is multiplied to all the estimated shear values. For each object we assign the statistical weight <em>w</em><sub>g</sub> defined by (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hamana et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hamana et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b110\" data-open=\"b110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe, Okura &amp; Futamase 2010b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b130\" data-open=\"b130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>)<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m2.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=laMfuBV02wVjJAKaYMfolKgtGG8Q1Ujv7yS4NGpgry82oeWNeOBNSzyy0pQDpON6FgP8EJbjtD0E-oahR1jsyHB6VZriTPgIpa74d8P-f1feal8OiE47ZujwP5Ifn5uKKBCfBbK45BKqiZkQaUAKTg95SCvmnfw0mngBIBk8IjYy4XVvVCuo9YwlJooYZy-x6oI0360W~7c3IZ8eTEI6K1E5CSxkM01Q2NM6dpOKW4rPQKJd2BbGYZuDSERgdIZlgD9-bQZDjrdIeKJ1VNT7BODI89JODrHd2NgGYo9r8w8c~zZuTvAk4nA0pq~xNJnlPQwKFTfP-5mKO7zXyCD1Pg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m2.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div> with \u03b1= 0.4 and \u03c3<sub>g</sub> is the variance of the shear computed from 20 neighbours in the magnitude\u2013<em>r</em><sub>g</sub> plane. When computing shear by averaging shear measurements of galaxies in a bin, we also apply a 3\u03c3 clipping which appears to reduce the shear measurement bias.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To check the accuracy of the weak lensing shear measurement, we perform a series of image simulations. Specifically, we generate a galaxy catalogue using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">stuff</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin 2009</a>). Each galaxy is described by the sum of bulge and disc components, which we model with S\u00e9rsic profiles with the index <em>n</em>= 4 and 1, respectively. We also add stars in the catalogue. We convolve the image with a PSF which we assume follows the Moffat profile \u03a3(<em>r</em>) \u221d [1 + (<em>r</em>/<em>a</em>)<sup>2</sup>]<sup>\u2212\u03b2</sup> with an elliptical extension. Based on the catalogue, we generate a number of realistic Subaru/Suprime-cam like images with different seeing sizes (0.5\u20131.1\u2003arcsec) and \u03b2 (3 &lt; \u03b2 &lt; 12) using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). We find that the resulting shear multiplicative error (the parameter <em>m</em> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Heymans et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Massey et al. 2007</a>) depends on both seeing size and \u03b2 such that <em>m</em> is smaller for larger seeing sizes or smaller \u03b2, but our algorithm generally yields |<em>m</em>| \u2272 0.05 for a wide range of PSF parameters examined here.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767814 id=\"16767814\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3\u2002Galaxy selection in colour\u2013colour space</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A careful selection of background galaxies is essential for cluster weak lensing studies, because contamination by cluster member galaxies is known to dilute the detected weak lensing signal significantly, particularly near the cluster centres (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b80\" data-open=\"b80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2007</a>). Our <em>gri</em>-band imaging is very powerful for reliable background galaxy selection, because we can select galaxies efficiently in colour\u2013colour space (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2010</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We determine the colour cut that is appropriate for our cluster sample based on the COSMOS photometric galaxy catalogue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ilbert et al. 2009</a>). Thanks to the wide wavelength coverage from the ultraviolet to mid-infrared, the photometric redshifts are very accurate down to <em>i</em>\u223c 25. By inspecting the photometric redshift distributions in each point of the <em>g</em>\u2212<em>r</em> versus <em>r</em>\u2212<em>i</em> colour space, we determine the colour cut for our analysis as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m3.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=gdGZ3YhThXjTdqcKnINKQQjDDTvW9JyznJRmvYlAMZj~9O1a8T~wWdFz7SmhjVbSLDGPcb9nuV5BolmGwyESsU3aKGCb5P4khlShZw6g6cDC7DhSPRrCir9HM81317CVzk4MButQruCfvHye2mM0cshQa482qwre6sgotqguLJ61UIu2DTZ5Vp~MCrGmYToNPXE5Lydf~rGXjdauExxs337fLcqgIht6RGt4SJgiKUIbE8z43AImeYshFTufBwG8p76rdZX9aIZ9WUi-vWD252QxI9Y~6ooaxzhcqSKzyb9~vNqBM3RP49uNcxLI~cU0lth9oEiOf~F0C4B727hTvg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m3.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">3</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m4.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=mLA5PCjbJb5xH3aw24ffIo4NlxQxiwQdrrCzIvtVBzons8yyX07yBCZp~0Y1~VkyAHl1tIJ0vwhwNXbyfZx6viOYJIEZWFKbMgH4ZKoHnh8uVxA8EdS4vl~1ulDRZG3i5fHlHmNEvv7SxTyXIv6H4t~DQiAHzXmnsoeP2rf6weWHwUM3RR0NhkWWAeU3DreDO4rCc5aedNVS~sRtzXQ-Zh1SLbHPDGlL9ddvxoFItLv1hEM2t667Oa0Wxr8jzDsBRuM7oGyjjtDO-0QCzBFF2NrnH6jKDLwDFf1EmaSMsOPvijj5U4h6nCEIoT~BTQm5GkliGKGgPjAY2NkX9AJxZw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m4.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m5\" content-id=\"m5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m5.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m5.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=Aio5w~~p1zDH96yfoE1ljX1vGtG7y36nlMDHjfZdsHFMm4DCZ8ZthCc~kzbzQ5HDOMyi6RPdlUcspCJB6WJn3lHmhi9tnpwfKSmTOAImNEyibdWkDpS34pTBIH7C6p3SZ9oAI3V~FSxcrcWwxGYKkMxSnwvn0y4wS9c0g2rX84bULBRMUTzyt~kEVhBjxgJtAV-3NFjIBG~csSSFTRDLCApbs209cbc5mc63pnqFznwhZ53QjsLMG-d~bBsB8ytFEKGM3ftDYc412iweFVTKItuPrYvg2d9fmm8QSjaCJYoHmpFArUJBJia7KtOCSo0PKdo2sgyRk8MWi-AVTlaTJQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m5.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">5</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m6\" content-id=\"m6\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m6.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m6.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=xkuDZZeUjTpz1ozOa1qkC7nKdnL5eBG5TwqAFYDY~NwmVvz0o9rDUGHB5rAYVUGQUPvrtJEaDRakBKoVytgls55Z17mCXJk6hMbvXchV3JpK7E0rJXBNco0nVZlb0Czp4vhMqRK3KDwQ4efl-~~cQFeqNyH~dQ-4Ao-BT0POhPJeoJ7~GnAk8XMK~--5F-8bBG3ZYTZuRJqk9xEBm562z-rF8HV~ygUhBz3FfmUaYncPrdpwH~PXAPSIWfKVMR-lVHrx5V1bmhXyubeShxzMs3IUaDLLfzP~kk36qayM6OWOtfhb6UceG6Xp4s5E5nwmFo9~UBeynXRi81~VxTyDQQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m6.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">6</span></div><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a> shows the cut and resulting COSMOS photometric redshift distribution. It is seen that our cut efficiently selects galaxies at <em>z</em>\u2273 0.7, the redshifts higher than any cluster redshifts in our sample. In our weak lensing analysis, we also limit the range of <em>r</em>-band magnitude to 21 &lt; <em>r</em> &lt; <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub>, where the limiting magnitude <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub> is determined from the galaxy number counts of each cluster field image (see below).</div>                        <a id=\"16767817\" scrollto-destination=\"16767817\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=JZvQa6aZ7kjhZR8VwgdAS9RjivuDiS0GoTQxCauHjw5BIPxiA35-vAJgwAruMSnwSl6PhvzLZ05mAgtDWv7y9iTLD8USDFJx-i-Vm8UU7-nNzPDScwD7RRGsFUAGbj7qjd8759HSELOwkGrTfFV6Tzr4uIQz62N1TjP8tZ0xWSZrYU-wvYbkQpt0Q4ybPCxqZrsyrFJvGCbYwbv5NLcTIxGKtR0H5yR8DIpkbWBcOHFfDF8iuBe56nn0Nq9N-CVqInfh6RapNTpg8PuHHNN3SPyNKELvU~q8wB8oCNnH~mgoS63GWG~Uk7ZrqKk104a~hXacYHoXoTf7pjjy28EHhA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). The colour cut for red member galaxy selection is indicated by dotted lines. The four regions correspond to colour cuts for different cluster redshifts. Solid contours indicate galaxy number density in the COSMOS catalogue (i &lt; 25). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767817/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=vxeARjJWcepWmZlvoMQ7Vv7aehbevpLjfQWg0ntF0jngsLCFYDj6BC7l~VpSgDsAzTAtekshNTwmARNH~sk5BcjxgT6JfnRA6nI-IX2vnI6S8ekaCKIDGWZcaUfyr4dUves1YU~98D2LQs3pknRBKwYA7k3-SCG5sg~Saj9YoIufxZYR19UIfXEFR0LjmpVqGCUtwXoyiajNr1ASB8lziDRigKyISxP8rk0E5n607eRelWguDX7tvdyznYRYFS~m7q1FOH6BOij~XcjyX-~lSsC0u0bDdSPooelEjR4F~ABce2MM-fYGq9yR6eS~q28EqrRslPKy4AvJbUxBcZq6mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767817&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=JZvQa6aZ7kjhZR8VwgdAS9RjivuDiS0GoTQxCauHjw5BIPxiA35-vAJgwAruMSnwSl6PhvzLZ05mAgtDWv7y9iTLD8USDFJx-i-Vm8UU7-nNzPDScwD7RRGsFUAGbj7qjd8759HSELOwkGrTfFV6Tzr4uIQz62N1TjP8tZ0xWSZrYU-wvYbkQpt0Q4ybPCxqZrsyrFJvGCbYwbv5NLcTIxGKtR0H5yR8DIpkbWBcOHFfDF8iuBe56nn0Nq9N-CVqInfh6RapNTpg8PuHHNN3SPyNKELvU~q8wB8oCNnH~mgoS63GWG~Uk7ZrqKk104a~hXacYHoXoTf7pjjy28EHhA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767817/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=vxeARjJWcepWmZlvoMQ7Vv7aehbevpLjfQWg0ntF0jngsLCFYDj6BC7l~VpSgDsAzTAtekshNTwmARNH~sk5BcjxgT6JfnRA6nI-IX2vnI6S8ekaCKIDGWZcaUfyr4dUves1YU~98D2LQs3pknRBKwYA7k3-SCG5sg~Saj9YoIufxZYR19UIfXEFR0LjmpVqGCUtwXoyiajNr1ASB8lziDRigKyISxP8rk0E5n607eRelWguDX7tvdyznYRYFS~m7q1FOH6BOij~XcjyX-~lSsC0u0bDdSPooelEjR4F~ABce2MM-fYGq9yR6eS~q28EqrRslPKy4AvJbUxBcZq6mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767817&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading).
