Symbols are same as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=0KpvS9TcLygjJ58X90iom-YQJHbb7YHkx02IYMySih4Mx42YbAxQHSpvU6HrqvL3i0-gLavJIQMnRauqxfDTIAGtr4MceZGSrm8EDi4amA4uBiQyLA8MEM6Sq4AF498LmuojeRBkFgp5X05NtMlFHLdF4d-6QOAUuQSiGSW7hhO8s5zb7yaGOhWMZDSJkDVZd2eVdx1Yu-bkky6eqVucEX8n3zOZXc~Z4f-JX3GSDIUj0D7wCHet2ZY7uy~C8U8utaukD3fcQToLDK4ZJrp80AzWhRT-6kb9SfXDnLhmNhtntjPJGZ1CBhLpisZMuFGpFAd7nh7CwdTzFWbrIdHuXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Concentration parameters from stacking lensing analysis as a function of the Einstein radius for the source redshift zs= 2. The black shading region indicates the theoretical expectation with the selection effect (see Appendix A, for details). Symbols are same as Fig. 9.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767862/mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767862\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=ejs2xiiJdjG7Nal2BdtBhJoP4oJRqoKGUfHzfp0nwaJoRn0uAMxxSgFy0bSMEjxP611IOd030iajQEsm-yALvozHKr99pA1YtZ8DZTSNo836A7jv3OVFuZdOdayW7a07v1s0toDcop4lAt2saAsEAvcMKRn84~udFB-SrpJJT4mKtP8SW8vVTPW7NREAM9O7vt5t4HsECvpM6CZIBY4klhFT01LydgvtAgCdVfVSYNlaCKEXkhxV5pe05ajxa~-wW76MEi5PgMT9HfYzotTfI8rY7tWxyMuEQrW-~dmUmV5a0IyIMkHzJIv3eJFFSXmHN4PAqYYfcGMDE4De3LC8Dg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767862&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Concentration parameters from stacking lensing analysis as a function of the Einstein radius for the source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2. The black shading region indicates the theoretical expectation with the selection effect (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details). Symbols are same as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767866 id=\"16767866\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-2>5.2\u20022D stacking analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to stacking of the tangential shear profile, we conduct stacking of 2D shear maps to study the mean shape of the projected dark matter distribution in clusters. Such 2D stacking analysis has been attempted for samples of galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b91\" data-open=\"b91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Natarajan &amp; Refregier 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra, Yee &amp; Gladders 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b75\" data-open=\"b75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mandelbaum et al. 2006a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b112\" data-open=\"b112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Parker et al. 2007</a>) or for clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evans &amp; Bridle 2009</a>). The biggest problem of these 2D stacking analysis has been that the position angle (orientation) of the projected mass distribution has to be known for each cluster when stacking. In previous work, it was assumed that the position angle of the mass distribution coincides with that of the light distribution, e.g. the surface brightness distribution of the central or satellite galaxy distributions, although the assumption has not yet been fully justified (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bett 2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our unique sample of strong and weak lensing clusters provides an important means of overcoming this difficulty. The idea is that strong lens modelling can generally constrain the position angle of the dark halo component quite well, which can be used as a prior information for the position angle to stack weak lensing signals. This procedure evades any assumptions on the alignment between mass and light, and hence should enable much more robust 2D stacking analysis.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5.1</a>, we conduct stacking analysis in the physical length scale. For each cluster, we adopt the position angle obtained in strong lens mass modelling (\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>) to rotate the catalogue of the background galaxies by \u2212\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> such that the position angle of the dark halo is aligned with the north\u2013south axis. Specifically, the position of a galaxy at (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) with respect to the cluster centre is changed to<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m28\" content-id=\"m28\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m28.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m28.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=DBTMxeLOXP1YzT34FZP5W9k4e6eyCeNlwm8EzQAJLQkC88GVXg~9IkxMfIr72cRvIxfZCgCwCopN5Z0s6AO5auCiM35OOwq4ta-AT3qydZzAth55-RyXUBONcIY6wG2wQBdFJG6JyjlFLi4MZUlLi6XBmB0sjIsmoNX3bg~fniuCW4got1s0mBfO9MEsbzDSsuGyPQDoWCJOrMtIXpk-fKCH~s-HO8YLi6xTmUbcuBE05XnLHddVPOunv5lWBaPIU8UOKobFkIsVMTyCjqm0hhgrvIbxVa5afgtfnlqHt9jHeOj30nel~K4oO32w1HuiPqLstJyk8exlSKF7t6Gn-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m28.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">28</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m29\" content-id=\"m29\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m29.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m29.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=anH3c5vm1kXUGyRgIzKkKaVXYwWweSU34uu8bfFI7cKNBJuF0ZEfeh4utXFGo0J2ceKeXxU--59MxFispceHj0D3XavY~C0ihD~unMPu4OJgehtVZrCy8icvsPBVzyWE-1xp9maxtQRckA0RiU8gG7oLBIdGrdi5h80qzOaQwDQkiIqBo8oV8vbvpjyTvbaCH8FqsPY26qn3jlsCSmFQRI4GMpinYjJX5bDsXZNbsfepyhPU16Ke8ofn2Y7vdCCtwh4uD-B0-LMJzbxdklFfKeSfyovco5GJpXdbNe5WK3zePSQn3zlSBKHXDlliODZxanwI1P3haZT56TUELYD3oA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m29.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">29</span></div> and the two shear components (<em>g</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>g</em><sub>2</sub>) are modified as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m30\" content-id=\"m30\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m30.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m30.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=EZXAHWPpaw8j-e8NAIDX8eXae33vHqjyd3oj6Nb6eUOkpP7189FTzAc25A6LlBe~vvIOAG8cbKry8R1iXmV-4cIqT-M4Nz~OoYtXrc4tCnvuhEoE2FeC2GJggVwUErJT2xMgHJhv4dmxtbQ~sk4dmpG0JxAwSCiU6-PTeq8bgx5KeRGg6DVuMb4MXEyswk29WLiP9G7e~B3JfOAc5GeMc~pk88Mo2k3MD9yFh4uNXcY1nEiFd1k4BGn3ARdFZpe5JW~4aIoehyrrHR5EsSfbBxfrFlUpWTQrmaPtLGLTTYxuj6EKDlRivEK-~o~ajv-oAjKF0dk9eOPydROtvb7lZA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m30.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">30</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m31\" content-id=\"m31\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m31.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m31.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=JPQ1AHjNPBz2Ia46YRfN~P3WXYrBd~jdJ5-YXvQwERLMxmzOXmDQONnjE3gCqWwSrBZfrPaX57d0X1gni3NnOWwf0H4ttzAFJF2osHBrCDPvMgJaRIWbCoA1aRwBpgzUX9svLc5GU~rzB2JFMBeA8nxNw6WErKAkYSIVRfm3AxyN~LCbCnVF9ZHsDRTuhePIhoK9lR6R490MxINIaxR2KInt1tH6p1PsQO8IYjrIEp6XlQ0aX7ZiiFrb~tl4O80oxUfe-Kf9UrDds54DrRNc8kDP5Kgj6QwZCFDMCnecbtwCyleZoO~Cv5G03GS6trzQKn3xvXfRgiU2PsPIQRb6bw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m31.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">31</span></div> We stack the rotated shear catalogue in the physical unit, \u03a3<sub>cr</sub><strong><em>g</em></strong>\u2032(<strong><em>r</em></strong>\u2032), to obtain the average 2D shear map of our cluster catalogue. The cluster catalogues analysed in this section is same as those in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5.1</a>, containing 25 clusters in total.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stacked 2D shear map, as well as the corresponding density map reconstructed from the shear map, is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a>. As expected, the projected mass distribution from the stacked 2D shear map is quite elongated along the north\u2013south direction, suggesting the highly elongated mass distribution of our cluster sample. As a sanity check, we also compute the 2D shear map without any alignment of the position angle when stacking. The resulting mass distribution shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a> appears to be circular symmetric, which supports that the highly elongated distribution in our stacked map is not an artefact.</p>                        <a id=\"16767891\" scrollto-destination=\"16767891\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=Mj1TiRianAZUiYD1lQPgPgz4k9IgSnffmalGkxi7h2yFpEVVBbZJGwuYxGFDQZxqoD3w4Ua7iziHzMUkKEu-OKtGRG~0~~cfB4xIn7I1m8M0JO22qlq-pxU19-2ohr-a6BANexTICf3FXNiRWCKNyyGLZUtOd9w17nvRBFJ308wO-VqbYs7CZMjWvJtrOmMP8nf76GIqbjUxda0reLyk3J63RVrtCGKe2F4urQR8TL~YORa~mWZAuKaNZ1N28m6zSc5daZRsSJUW~64-ATDz8BixsY4LTGTaKP41meyNbsMv3RK14ABYCQAN0nQSPdeZAz6TeQ96-ylH9NxiM~zJ4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The 2D weak lensing shear maps obtained from stacking analysis of 25 clusters. The sticks show observed directions and strengths of weak lensing shear distortion. Colour contours are the surface density map reconstructed from the shear map using the standard inversion technique (Kaiser &amp; Squires 1993). Both the shear and density maps are smoothed for illustrative purpose. Left: the result when the position angle of each cluster is aligned to the north\u2013south axis before stacking, by using the position angle measured in strong lens modelling. The resulting stacked density distribution is clearly elongated along the north\u2013south direction. Right: the result without any alignment of the position angle when stacking. The resulting density distribution is nearly circular symmetric in this case.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767891/mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767891\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=w-yzubNYSVyapgPfHToyrRdVZtaQ-GOC6K-pm9jl9mCbcckX2Jin~zK21BfgpyTSRd~fcXliKBMnrt2FH7zj-Yliwd5tGEYn4encpKmzC0qQb8Zy7p4dTdYB5QMS7kQZLaPn1KoJY4eVYc1swp90EtAiEwZ6IdanhGnVGkh9Nip~37RvixwuFLwR-STLG9ff4SlduQ398rKU207kVi8a2IrBb0qfptOPEQ~OT1tJJfKLAmlvCXLkQEl5sKbOmm-PbmhToaCFgj2PvaWFNxrjujqyIhUi9vs43sldKpXf-lobjwzY-IYTlISa2aONW9LkNvnF8Umv5nTxJ6DBP6fclw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767891&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The 2D weak lensing shear maps obtained from stacking analysis of 25 clusters. The sticks show observed directions and strengths of weak lensing shear distortion. Colour contours are the surface density map reconstructed from the shear map using the standard inversion technique (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser &amp; Squires 1993</a>). Both the shear and density maps are smoothed for illustrative purpose. Left: the result when the position angle of each cluster is aligned to the north\u2013south axis before stacking, by using the position angle measured in strong lens modelling. The resulting stacked density distribution is clearly elongated along the north\u2013south direction. Right: the result without any alignment of the position angle when stacking. The resulting density distribution is nearly circular symmetric in this case.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=Mj1TiRianAZUiYD1lQPgPgz4k9IgSnffmalGkxi7h2yFpEVVBbZJGwuYxGFDQZxqoD3w4Ua7iziHzMUkKEu-OKtGRG~0~~cfB4xIn7I1m8M0JO22qlq-pxU19-2ohr-a6BANexTICf3FXNiRWCKNyyGLZUtOd9w17nvRBFJ308wO-VqbYs7CZMjWvJtrOmMP8nf76GIqbjUxda0reLyk3J63RVrtCGKe2F4urQR8TL~YORa~mWZAuKaNZ1N28m6zSc5daZRsSJUW~64-ATDz8BixsY4LTGTaKP41meyNbsMv3RK14ABYCQAN0nQSPdeZAz6TeQ96-ylH9NxiM~zJ4Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The 2D weak lensing shear maps obtained from stacking analysis of 25 clusters. The sticks show observed directions and strengths of weak lensing shear distortion. Colour contours are the surface density map reconstructed from the shear map using the standard inversion technique (Kaiser &amp; Squires 1993). Both the shear and density maps are smoothed for illustrative purpose. Left: the result when the position angle of each cluster is aligned to the north\u2013south axis before stacking, by using the position angle measured in strong lens modelling. The resulting stacked density distribution is clearly elongated along the north\u2013south direction. Right: the result without any alignment of the position angle when stacking. The resulting density distribution is nearly circular symmetric in this case.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767891/mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767891\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=w-yzubNYSVyapgPfHToyrRdVZtaQ-GOC6K-pm9jl9mCbcckX2Jin~zK21BfgpyTSRd~fcXliKBMnrt2FH7zj-Yliwd5tGEYn4encpKmzC0qQb8Zy7p4dTdYB5QMS7kQZLaPn1KoJY4eVYc1swp90EtAiEwZ6IdanhGnVGkh9Nip~37RvixwuFLwR-STLG9ff4SlduQ398rKU207kVi8a2IrBb0qfptOPEQ~OT1tJJfKLAmlvCXLkQEl5sKbOmm-PbmhToaCFgj2PvaWFNxrjujqyIhUi9vs43sldKpXf-lobjwzY-IYTlISa2aONW9LkNvnF8Umv5nTxJ6DBP6fclw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767891&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The 2D weak lensing shear maps obtained from stacking analysis of 25 clusters. The sticks show observed directions and strengths of weak lensing shear distortion. Colour contours are the surface density map reconstructed from the shear map using the standard inversion technique (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser &amp; Squires 1993</a>). Both the shear and density maps are smoothed for illustrative purpose. Left: the result when the position angle of each cluster is aligned to the north\u2013south axis before stacking, by using the position angle measured in strong lens modelling. The resulting stacked density distribution is clearly elongated along the north\u2013south direction. Right: the result without any alignment of the position angle when stacking. The resulting density distribution is nearly circular symmetric in this case.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We constrain the ellipticity of the projected 2D mass distribution by directly fitting the 2D shear map with the elliptical NFW model prediction. Here we closely follow the procedure detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2010)</a> for the 2D shear fitting. Briefly, we modify the convergence \u03ba(<em>r</em>) (i.e. the projected surface mass density) of the spherical NFW profile simply by introducing the ellipticity in the isodensity contour as <em>r</em><sup>2</sup>\u2192<em>x</em><sup>2</sup>/(1 \u2212<em>e</em>) +<em>y</em><sup>2</sup>(1 \u2212<em>e</em>). With this procedure our definition of the ellipticity is <em>e</em>= 1 \u2212<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>, where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are major and minor axis lengths of the isodensity contour. The corresponding shear pattern is computed by solving the Poisson equation. We then construct pixelized distortion field by computing mean shear and errors in each bin, and compare it with the elliptical model prediction, adopting the pixel size of 0.1\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc. We add the contribution of the large-scale structure to the error covariance matrix (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2010</a>). We perform fitting in a 6\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc \u00d7 6\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc region, but remove the innermost 4 \u00d7 4\u2003pixels considering several possible systematics that might be affecting signals near the centre. Unlike <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2010)</a>, we fix the mass centre to the assumed centre (the position of the brightest galaxy in strong lensing region), because strong lensing available for our cluster sample allows a reliable identification of the mass centre for each cluster. Thus, we fit the 2D shear map with four parameters (<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>, <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>, <em>e</em>, \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>), employing a Markov Chain Monte Carlo technique.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f12\" data-open=\"f12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 12</a>, we show the posterior likelihood distribution of the mean ellipticity \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 from the 2D stacking analysis of all the 25 clusters. When the position angles are aligned, the resulting density distribution is indeed quite elliptical with the mean ellipticity of \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06. We find that the elliptical NFW model improves fitting by \u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup>= 26.9 compared with the case <em>e</em>= 0, which indicates that the detection of the elliptical mass distribution is significant at the 5\u03c3 level. The measured mean ellipticity is consistent with the average ellipticity from strong lens modelling \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.38 \u00b1 0.24, although the latter involves large scatter. The best-fitting position angle of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu6.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=1vdTfMb~yq1DXJjj~36o3j88kxsqE9mNsxbmMmEhd25Y1CCECgIXrBJlA1VwOENbnHcWCKmXDBWZs2dmEffVprbza80gY4oi8VlzaT5sawLMnJKfAGuxwAjGNkWnOBNc4Y6aCMsoWPGLOWNeEKVQPyGfiRMSli5ACnPpGeRdYMvZB6q~BpYwm5Nlw1JUFoQl1P6gcw5UDwvoi1JIKMom2F0vg7KzelZgEndZlxd9gxAzvRzpZjXTvQuIM-Edy6RsDfS5ymVkfIzOwcAhjIycnirB4-N05uwfXCYlfeyc60D9alesZm-jIZ6cW-UrARlWeK68GyYhQectAWOB0sd~5A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu6.gif\" /></span> slightly deviates from the expected position angle of \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>= 0, but they are consistent with each other within 2\u03c3 (\u0394\u03c7<sup>2</sup> &lt; 4). In contrast, if the position angles are not aligned in stacking shear signals, the resulting constraint on the mean ellipticity is \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 &lt; 0.19, i.e. it is fully consistent with the circular symmetric mass distribution <em>e</em>= 0 within 1\u03c3.</p>                        <a id=\"16767898\" scrollto-destination=\"16767898\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=mGG6f3QaghDcUpAz3nVdkLCAwdNzh8VWkdYzB1YAjE7X~2nsDTce3o8eRAak38r6VvmY2UaExbh00DMzAMnYDnIR2wmE6cs5mr5E6dVftD1-5H7Tc4iiWNyR~0vVApM8tUmlNtuYF~cGGAlF2Lv6wI5sw1HQMka9ZU6vjOPWuEDybPpFdf-MhaI6HUDYq7DDHN0-Jm5ZxKllIZp5miUM0tGPLPIL8AqNYbdgSLctIcrxtDBZ4munMBPaZdDIXrcMs-7VwrvM2BocSVq~SpUQWuE8uhCVyslc-HboTB9ESag-DRtETCNknufQwC8A0gRq16vddxX5HaPbVuWuCjuN8g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The marginalized probability distribution of the mean ellipticity \u3008e\u3009 from stacked weak lensing analysis of 25 clusters. The solid line indicates the case when the position angles are aligned according to those measured with strong lens modelling, in which the mean ellipticity is detected at 5\u03c3 level (\u3008e\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06). The dashed line is the marginalized probability distribution for stacking without any alignment of the position angles, for which the mass distribution is consistent with the circular symmetric distribution (\u3008e\u3009 &lt; 0.19). The vertical dotted line indicates the theoretical expectation, \u3008e\u3009= 0.44, based on a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). The open circle with error bar shows the average ellipticity and 1\u03c3 scatter from strong lens modelling.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767898/mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767898\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=MSaCKjjFvkSO7GiPC7GRWFtYz4qUHWzwnOWvxDZeJQSZPChPK8VUtHNQCCkj-T9MZBu6VqtpOoGXWs4Nzokgydy7YTsZNKfa-jU03XIjTXsVc6kN-L5jpsXnpCT1wKZ~o4hfm7rgDTmmqokvaZ8bX9kPdZ7Y8Po5RVY2kXDUiyGab5Tf0EbsqLbbO0wbwPT078Rd4zRKabAZpoPVjs9nNIMDBCOkKhm2PjpWKunDy-ia9qKB6oE2hpPev-lFNDSy5rHI5X~OOA-UnbEtsQ5Xq~Uu1Lu3eYUpJN1GzyZr2EPMT49yrEzo-m2ANa34WyefL~emBlfdUjffQB~~Xec~eA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767898&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The marginalized probability distribution of the mean ellipticity \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 from stacked weak lensing analysis of 25 clusters. The solid line indicates the case when the position angles are aligned according to those measured with strong lens modelling, in which the mean ellipticity is detected at 5\u03c3 level (\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06). The dashed line is the marginalized probability distribution for stacking without any alignment of the position angles, for which the mass distribution is consistent with the circular symmetric distribution (\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 &lt; 0.19). The vertical dotted line indicates the theoretical expectation, \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.44, based on a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. The open circle with error bar shows the average ellipticity and 1\u03c3 scatter from strong lens modelling.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=mGG6f3QaghDcUpAz3nVdkLCAwdNzh8VWkdYzB1YAjE7X~2nsDTce3o8eRAak38r6VvmY2UaExbh00DMzAMnYDnIR2wmE6cs5mr5E6dVftD1-5H7Tc4iiWNyR~0vVApM8tUmlNtuYF~cGGAlF2Lv6wI5sw1HQMka9ZU6vjOPWuEDybPpFdf-MhaI6HUDYq7DDHN0-Jm5ZxKllIZp5miUM0tGPLPIL8AqNYbdgSLctIcrxtDBZ4munMBPaZdDIXrcMs-7VwrvM2BocSVq~SpUQWuE8uhCVyslc-HboTB9ESag-DRtETCNknufQwC8A0gRq16vddxX5HaPbVuWuCjuN8g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The marginalized probability distribution of the mean ellipticity \u3008e\u3009 from stacked weak lensing analysis of 25 clusters. The solid line indicates the case when the position angles are aligned according to those measured with strong lens modelling, in which the mean ellipticity is detected at 5\u03c3 level (\u3008e\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06). The dashed line is the marginalized probability distribution for stacking without any alignment of the position angles, for which the mass distribution is consistent with the circular symmetric distribution (\u3008e\u3009 &lt; 0.19). The vertical dotted line indicates the theoretical expectation, \u3008e\u3009= 0.44, based on a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). The open circle with error bar shows the average ellipticity and 1\u03c3 scatter from strong lens modelling.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767898/mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767898\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=MSaCKjjFvkSO7GiPC7GRWFtYz4qUHWzwnOWvxDZeJQSZPChPK8VUtHNQCCkj-T9MZBu6VqtpOoGXWs4Nzokgydy7YTsZNKfa-jU03XIjTXsVc6kN-L5jpsXnpCT1wKZ~o4hfm7rgDTmmqokvaZ8bX9kPdZ7Y8Po5RVY2kXDUiyGab5Tf0EbsqLbbO0wbwPT078Rd4zRKabAZpoPVjs9nNIMDBCOkKhm2PjpWKunDy-ia9qKB6oE2hpPev-lFNDSy5rHI5X~OOA-UnbEtsQ5Xq~Uu1Lu3eYUpJN1GzyZr2EPMT49yrEzo-m2ANa34WyefL~emBlfdUjffQB~~Xec~eA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767898&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The marginalized probability distribution of the mean ellipticity \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 from stacked weak lensing analysis of 25 clusters. The solid line indicates the case when the position angles are aligned according to those measured with strong lens modelling, in which the mean ellipticity is detected at 5\u03c3 level (\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06). The dashed line is the marginalized probability distribution for stacking without any alignment of the position angles, for which the mass distribution is consistent with the circular symmetric distribution (\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 &lt; 0.19). The vertical dotted line indicates the theoretical expectation, \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.44, based on a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. The open circle with error bar shows the average ellipticity and 1\u03c3 scatter from strong lens modelling.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare this result with the theoretical prediction in the \u039bCDM model. For this purpose we employ a triaxial model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. Assuming that the halo orientation is random, we compute the probability distribution of the ellipticity by projecting the triaxial halo along arbitrary directions (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b102\" data-open=\"b102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri, Lee &amp; Suto 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Keeton 2004</a>). In this analysis, we fix the mass and redshift of the halo to <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>= 4.6 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> and <em>z</em>= 0.469, which are mean mass and redshift of the 25 clusters. We find that the mean ellipticity predicted by this model is \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.44, in excellent agreement with the measured ellipticity. The analysis presented in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> indicates that the effect of the lensing bias on the mean ellipticity is small, with a possible shift of the mean ellipticity of \u22720.05 at most, and hence it does not affect our conclusion. Our result is also in good agreement with the previous lensing measurement of the ellipticity by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2010)</a> in which 2D shear maps of individual clusters are fitted with the elliptical NFW profile, rather than examining the stacked shear map.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We check the sensitivity of our ellipticity result on the size of the fitting region, as one possible concern is that infalling matter associated with the filamentary structure outside clusters might boost the mean ellipticity. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a> shows how the constraint on the mean ellipticity changes by making the size of the fitting region smaller from our fiducial choice (half the box size of 3\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc). The figure indicates that the detection of the mean ellipticity of \u223c0.45 is robust against the choice of the fitting size, as the results are consistent down to half the box size of \u223c0.3\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc where the constraint becomes significantly weak. The analysis also implies that the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution does not change very much with radius. Theoretically, dark haloes are expected to be more elongated near the centre (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto 2002</a>), although the effect of baryon cooling and star formation can make the shape rounder particularly near the centre (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kazantzidis et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lau et al. 2011</a>). Our detection of the elliptical mass distribution down to small radii may therefore help constraining the amount of cooling in clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"16767904\" scrollto-destination=\"16767904\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=lOY24HkqP9VkJSKkiKpH4UffJ0wZYBPRpdL7GwPY8qxAL3xx1iOoUBbz9VE0H2wQS2lslvfPkp2uDe9e2kfDNxumnUNMM8mImFZ9JQ7kibBqRF0Qqw4Ttm2XB-d8~xwyT-Mlub5sIqut7pMXo-Fjm-cuhV-S91~6i2kFwmqW91Engeq4pM4LLpIlp7leTweTaZbs0Wfcv63pF~Y9kWc7-CIRa4stjcYzvoz37qRrS1SQy1IJGTNFbhD3UtYVFHvGLMar7bhmhZy0IZsGw2weHS-D9u9fkJIU6wmykuLkVP9bq00E1FCu-uVu3nPMiK9vivsMBJbvcM5T2hBrBoynRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean ellipticities measured in stacked 2D shear map as a function of the box size for fitting. Our fiducial result and its 1\u03c3 range adopting half the box size of 3\u2003h\u22121\u2003Mpc are indicated by the horizontal line with shading.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767904/mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767904\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=w0u2gauZYefp2Iks2GIFYUORxzn9U7088AbkrPoD1giJ-hggTgcNB52jxuxR~-r~IPFuxPfWeH5MxVQiDCvxoRJPo2tk8VNZ7q7DkcwD3T0dARp1SolBP8mCDqx3fcPBF7qQaupv7V7Atdu9HcO7VKt3hN0MCRRh0SpAzGM0Qjg2MDlERS9~W1cGjBsoqhsUBqA240z6qT~xhyvQj~VEc7MH9i9CzHTmAFR~CK4Mhm9mxN8YCwF6i8CIJOjOfrj4Pun1Eh4~Yc4Rz67FlzYq7AVkMaKLaxo-i4lRbnN7ZrwbajSY6XPSGDZhCnIpNndse-2A0pCgpWoyd88lty24IQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767904&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mean ellipticities measured in stacked 2D shear map as a function of the box size for fitting. Our fiducial result and its 1\u03c3 range adopting half the box size of 3\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc are indicated by the horizontal line with shading.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=lOY24HkqP9VkJSKkiKpH4UffJ0wZYBPRpdL7GwPY8qxAL3xx1iOoUBbz9VE0H2wQS2lslvfPkp2uDe9e2kfDNxumnUNMM8mImFZ9JQ7kibBqRF0Qqw4Ttm2XB-d8~xwyT-Mlub5sIqut7pMXo-Fjm-cuhV-S91~6i2kFwmqW91Engeq4pM4LLpIlp7leTweTaZbs0Wfcv63pF~Y9kWc7-CIRa4stjcYzvoz37qRrS1SQy1IJGTNFbhD3UtYVFHvGLMar7bhmhZy0IZsGw2weHS-D9u9fkJIU6wmykuLkVP9bq00E1FCu-uVu3nPMiK9vivsMBJbvcM5T2hBrBoynRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean ellipticities measured in stacked 2D shear map as a function of the box size for fitting. Our fiducial result and its 1\u03c3 range adopting half the box size of 3\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc are indicated by the horizontal line with shading.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally we check the mean ellipticities for different \u03b8<sub>E</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> bins. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 14</a> shows the results, and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> gives the summary of constraints on the mean ellipticities. We find a possible decrease of \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 at the largest Einstein radius bin, although it is not very significant given the large error bars. On the other hand, there appears no simple trend in the mass bin result.</p>                        <a id=\"16767909\" scrollto-destination=\"16767909\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=daMjHWQBbyCYdI6MFnq6VlMI~nUqRPMSokL5isBNNuhemmEVLJlZzRGWoPrjXcPzmJB5ZFFSSbv0Bo~kRZb6-D24RzUNfLcZ7VvjQKJ~kbs0pdNrI4YQzetT0wRj2KJR5BkznmOUWfQGBwNRKsvi1oQhYr9e1E7F0OSb1WcsXBLZInfrdT8K5gxhQ8aD8b~2cfyu~eEaslw8JyN0NulkaAVcoB7AqzzaFJDSaIlkgrRuuBR4WFUtzmLKIsKupcslNF71WYeS0x4hgEhS5erjml5CcXyKBQ4K4d4v6aHSVDcrT0reP0tb7C2vhu2WT9SW4Em80ls12Jn8-eq69~7JeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mean ellipticities from stacked shear maps in three different \u03b8E (upper panel) and Mvir (lower panel) bins. The horizontal line with shading indicate best fit and 1\u03c3 range of the full sample result. Dashed lines show the predicted mean ellipticity from semi-analytic calculations with the lensing bias (see Appendix A, for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767909/mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=rwaIQMSrd4b4V76C0zndw0Hk0p8p0X~vmdJ072cqWeY8-EO1sidhZ3nTkkmswEpBXXfqkP-KUK5IhYvL2pMix9HQBYer0OSG6tRIqcx50DK9SIwcK~K0g8-jjqSfz0H-NRUOCR0jm1AP07G3crfVTQoadeANSQwfoJ06T5klrIXUvQeuuAOfCANfIdkKA3-OUlip5qmtfkklvZZ-2o2ycn7OvowS1oy-GUAbU3Y7Q28tNA9k7Lq4X53oa8Y9s6Uvhb4bWJEC6LowbmPs4RmU9MaglvJRDfUHnEnb0ja5Ln9CPc5Gwhf4TLv9zVkMyetsIlqcF6SHIHnb9oAZuwyLmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767909&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mean ellipticities from stacked shear maps in three different \u03b8<sub>E</sub> (upper panel) and <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> (lower panel) bins. The horizontal line with shading indicate best fit and 1\u03c3 range of the full sample result. Dashed lines show the predicted mean ellipticity from semi-analytic calculations with the lensing bias (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=daMjHWQBbyCYdI6MFnq6VlMI~nUqRPMSokL5isBNNuhemmEVLJlZzRGWoPrjXcPzmJB5ZFFSSbv0Bo~kRZb6-D24RzUNfLcZ7VvjQKJ~kbs0pdNrI4YQzetT0wRj2KJR5BkznmOUWfQGBwNRKsvi1oQhYr9e1E7F0OSb1WcsXBLZInfrdT8K5gxhQ8aD8b~2cfyu~eEaslw8JyN0NulkaAVcoB7AqzzaFJDSaIlkgrRuuBR4WFUtzmLKIsKupcslNF71WYeS0x4hgEhS5erjml5CcXyKBQ4K4d4v6aHSVDcrT0reP0tb7C2vhu2WT9SW4Em80ls12Jn8-eq69~7JeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mean ellipticities from stacked shear maps in three different \u03b8E (upper panel) and Mvir (lower panel) bins. The horizontal line with shading indicate best fit and 1\u03c3 range of the full sample result. Dashed lines show the predicted mean ellipticity from semi-analytic calculations with the lensing bias (see Appendix A, for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767909/mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=rwaIQMSrd4b4V76C0zndw0Hk0p8p0X~vmdJ072cqWeY8-EO1sidhZ3nTkkmswEpBXXfqkP-KUK5IhYvL2pMix9HQBYer0OSG6tRIqcx50DK9SIwcK~K0g8-jjqSfz0H-NRUOCR0jm1AP07G3crfVTQoadeANSQwfoJ06T5klrIXUvQeuuAOfCANfIdkKA3-OUlip5qmtfkklvZZ-2o2ycn7OvowS1oy-GUAbU3Y7Q28tNA9k7Lq4X53oa8Y9s6Uvhb4bWJEC6LowbmPs4RmU9MaglvJRDfUHnEnb0ja5Ln9CPc5Gwhf4TLv9zVkMyetsIlqcF6SHIHnb9oAZuwyLmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767909&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f14.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mean ellipticities from stacked shear maps in three different \u03b8<sub>E</sub> (upper panel) and <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> (lower panel) bins. The horizontal line with shading indicate best fit and 1\u03c3 range of the full sample result. Dashed lines show the predicted mean ellipticity from semi-analytic calculations with the lensing bias (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16767913\" scrollto-destination=\"16767913\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t6\" data-id=\"t6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the 2D stacking analysis.</p></div> </div><div (\u00b0)\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>All\u00a0</td><td>0.47<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.06</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.1<sup>+3.9</sup><sub>\u22124.1</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.29<sup>+0.13</sup><sub>\u22120.18</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.1<sup>+13.9</sup><sub>\u221218.8</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.70<sup>+0.05</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>13.0<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.3</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.52<sup>+0.10</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>6.7<sup>+12.2</sup><sub>\u22129.2</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.58<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.2<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.5</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.28<sup>+0.12</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.7<sup>+11.3</sup><sub>\u221217.6</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.60<sup>+0.09</sup><sub>\u22120.11</sub>\u00a0</td><td>16.7<sup>+7.0</sup><sub>\u22128.7</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767913\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t6\" data-id=\"t6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the 2D stacking analysis.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>Sample\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009\u00a0</td><td>\u3008\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>\u3009 (\u00b0)\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>All\u00a0</td><td>0.47<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.06</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.1<sup>+3.9</sup><sub>\u22124.1</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.29<sup>+0.13</sup><sub>\u22120.18</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.1<sup>+13.9</sup><sub>\u221218.8</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.70<sup>+0.05</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>13.0<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.3</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.52<sup>+0.10</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>6.7<sup>+12.2</sup><sub>\u22129.2</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.58<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.2<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.5</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.28<sup>+0.12</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.7<sup>+11.3</sup><sub>\u221217.6</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.60<sup>+0.09</sup><sub>\u22120.11</sub>\u00a0</td><td>16.7<sup>+7.0</sup><sub>\u22128.7</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><td>Sample\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009\u00a0</td><td>\u3008\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>\u3009 (\u00b0)\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>All\u00a0</td><td>0.47<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.06</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.1<sup>+3.9</sup><sub>\u22124.1</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.29<sup>+0.13</sup><sub>\u22120.18</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.1<sup>+13.9</sup><sub>\u221218.8</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.70<sup>+0.05</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>13.0<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.3</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.52<sup>+0.10</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>6.7<sup>+12.2</sup><sub>\u22129.2</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>0.58<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.09</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.2<sup>+4.4</sup><sub>\u22124.5</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>0.28<sup>+0.12</sup><sub>\u22120.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.7<sup>+11.3</sup><sub>\u221217.6</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>0.60<sup>+0.09</sup><sub>\u22120.11</sub>\u00a0</td><td>16.7<sup>+7.0</sup><sub>\u22128.7</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767913\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">While results for all subsamples are almost consistent with the full sample result, the dependence on \u03b8<sub>E</sub> might be suggestive of conflicting selection effects on our sample. There are two main lensing biases that can affect the results on the mean ellipticity measurement. One is the orientation bias, i.e. clusters with larger Einstein radii appear to be rounder than normal clusters because of the alignment of the major axis with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>). The other selection effect is directly related to the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution. Because the ellipticity significantly enhances the giant arc cross-section (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti, Bartelmann &amp; Moscardini 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2007</a>), a sample of clusters with prominent lensed arcs should have more elliptical projected mass distribution. These two selection effects apparently conflict with each other, although a naive expectation is that the orientation bias dominates for large Einstein radii, whereas the ellipticity bias is more significant for small Einstein radii. Indeed, our semi-analytic calculations presented in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> shows a clear dependence of the mean ellipticity on the Einstein radius, as plotted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 14</a>. The observed trend appears to be consistent, at least qualitatively, with the theoretical prediction. A large sample is needed to confirm this trend more robustly.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767918 id=\"16767918\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6\u2002RELATION BETWEEN MASS AND MEMBER GALAXY DISTRIBUTIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Understanding the relation between the mass and cluster member galaxy distributions is important for the cosmological use of optical clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koester et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b118\" data-open=\"b118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rozo et al. 2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b119\" data-open=\"b119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b121\" data-open=\"b121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rykoff et al. 2011</a>) as well as detailed stacking analysis for a large sample of clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Evans &amp; Bridle 2009</a>). The spatial distribution of galaxies, in comparison with that of subhaloes in an <em>N</em>-body simulation, is crucial for exploring the formation history of cluster member galaxies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nagai &amp; Kravtsov 2005</a>). Here we examine spatial distributions of cluster member galaxies using the stacking technique and compare them with accurate measurements of mass distributions from stacked lensing analysis.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">While the colour information from <em>gri</em>-band images allows us to select the galaxy population around a given redshift efficiently, the selection is not perfect in the sense that there is some contamination from foreground and background galaxies. Thus, in this paper we take advantage of the high number density of galaxies after stacking to subtract the foreground and background galaxies statistically. Specifically, we assume that the stacked number density distribution is described by the sum of cluster member galaxies and background galaxies as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m32\" content-id=\"m32\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m32.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m32.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=qmwhv9IFVzFpPfI5oOSuNKCBa2rjYoMxGYVGzNllUpq4ke2v-V2mNQw08lOAChx8Cw6Bj0sM6ab9TwG0-GUsmxeJykmovekyEKV0Chs31~9IJp5k~u7b~ZaCQmhSackSTfsM0GjiG3-E4u0zbu5vkXV6mVr2b5zI31njJyD9Qk9my0q63KGMJVdRmttqUnB5DG1Esi5fsrK6R-h5DEGFOGIZ-J0iu5So9jOlTUXwPAm18VyQ4HYPFKLPnbRonRUMreiZqhEzalV6zyoJDMTTJS0ogAT4xGRrRYofOi1IjFJ72miXhENSkiAh3DcAAWWP92ItTWD6vdE8v4cD81gZpg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m32.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">32</span></div> where <em>a</em><sub>g</sub> is the normalization, \u03a3<sub>nfw</sub> is the surface density distribution of the NFW profile and <em>b</em><sub>g</sub> is the number density of foreground/background galaxies which is assumed to be constant across the field.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we focus on two parameters that describe the number density distribution of member galaxies. One is the scale radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> of the NFW profile, which is used to check whether or not the galaxy distribution is more extended than the mass distribution. The other is the ellipticity of the projected number density distribution, as our stacking analysis enables detailed analysis of 2D distributions for both mass and member galaxy distributions. We constrain the scale radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> by fitting azimuthally averaged radial profile of the galaxy number density, whereas the ellipticity is derived from the 2D fitting of the density distribution. The total number of parameters for the radial profile fitting is three (<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>, <em>a</em><sub>g</sub> and <em>b</em><sub>g</sub>), and that of 2D fitting is five (<em>e</em>, \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>, <em>r</em><sub>s</sub>, <em>a</em><sub>g</sub> and <em>b</em><sub>g</sub>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We consider two distinct galaxy populations, one is red member galaxies selected by the colour cut (equations <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m7\"></span><a href=\"#m7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m8\"></span><a href=\"#m8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a>) and the other is all galaxies without any colour cut. For each galaxy population, we consider galaxies that are more luminous than the luminosity cut, i.e. <em>L</em> &gt; <em>L</em><sub>cut</sub>. The luminosity cut is defined in terms of <em>L</em><sub>*</sub>, where <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> is the luminosity corresponding to the <em>i</em>-band absolute magnitude <em>M<sup>i</sup></em><sub>*</sub>=\u221221.22 + 5 log\u2003<em>h</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b121\" data-open=\"b121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rykoff et al. 2011</a>). For the highest cluster redshift in our sample, a luminosity 0.1<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> corresponds to <em>i</em>\u223c 24.5, which is well above the magnitude limit of our Subaru imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show our fitting results in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f15\" data-open=\"f15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 15</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>. We find that the mass and galaxy number distributions agree reasonably well for the luminous galaxies, <em>L</em>\u2273<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>, for both the scale radius and ellipticity. However, for fainter galaxies of <em>L</em>\u223c 0.1<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> the scale radius of the galaxy distribution tends to be larger (i.e. smaller concentration parameter values), and the average ellipticity is smaller.</p>                        <a id=\"16767930\" scrollto-destination=\"16767930\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=mCNy1WnLq2uq442tX-fiLZ5RLvqqWKJrc8qG5GIArLMuxZByYYQn~KoYDJnDq92hLpc2Au9ctWaUANUxud2iSuH235l66ankcx0mgpLKB8x6NQxfMykKQ1feysXtNq9ZaoXBcf97cIH2mQFEKon-uZTaTQb1FXMDs-EtnTMWgxsfgRsIGcWdWbldocE9z2sh5atT5tXjiRTYIvoDNcenATnuMa6pf7QxABJ4hznzDsOz0dutALMCibRqkK05wr8cogFqxJGUdmfDdh~SgphCRJrDG16M-YZUlbqgeanyblNM6WUIkRxcoGbxvrZL-V5RnKIjhNAO-XTtt-O8yUcSfw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean scale radius \u3008rs\u3009 (upper) and mean ellipticity \u3008e\u3009 (lower) of the member galaxy distribution from stacking 25 clusters, as a function of the luminosity cut Lcut. Filled squares and open circles show the results for red member galaxies and all member galaxies, respectively. Horizontal lines with shading are the scale radius and ellipticity for the mass distribution, measured by stacked lensing, for the same cluster sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767930/mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767930\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=eddHVJwkj~twrjisAjwlV~zzLJdU7SXX2fy~BfrkK2EqkdtRJQcxZB59g5x5IISaBTaxk6YCI1ghjJ59nxl6iDrR6HpwdnUDerHehC~G-lxnuY4coNc9c-~1ddXCLXgJlmEUrXtDJbf1P40-I5ZMbjoRHqpYSSkZUAiEx7hVnaT~a5El7uRfJaK8M5~bIOrAtasHwCHANEJ6Tfv-64VnvZ0QtjxPCpbypNUaod0-hYr4qhuM~6rwDl1g0R46HRQrSqZMu8REB0aR2ilE9QG6XO7q4e1rkMbcpvMXn16EDZ-mijt~8wi92vQG~gBF-0BEvOrW3X79aifObX8MxwrlPQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767930&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mean scale radius \u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (upper) and mean ellipticity \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (lower) of the member galaxy distribution from stacking 25 clusters, as a function of the luminosity cut <em>L</em><sub>cut</sub>. Filled squares and open circles show the results for red member galaxies and all member galaxies, respectively. Horizontal lines with shading are the scale radius and ellipticity for the mass distribution, measured by stacked lensing, for the same cluster sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=mCNy1WnLq2uq442tX-fiLZ5RLvqqWKJrc8qG5GIArLMuxZByYYQn~KoYDJnDq92hLpc2Au9ctWaUANUxud2iSuH235l66ankcx0mgpLKB8x6NQxfMykKQ1feysXtNq9ZaoXBcf97cIH2mQFEKon-uZTaTQb1FXMDs-EtnTMWgxsfgRsIGcWdWbldocE9z2sh5atT5tXjiRTYIvoDNcenATnuMa6pf7QxABJ4hznzDsOz0dutALMCibRqkK05wr8cogFqxJGUdmfDdh~SgphCRJrDG16M-YZUlbqgeanyblNM6WUIkRxcoGbxvrZL-V5RnKIjhNAO-XTtt-O8yUcSfw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean scale radius \u3008rs\u3009 (upper) and mean ellipticity \u3008e\u3009 (lower) of the member galaxy distribution from stacking 25 clusters, as a function of the luminosity cut Lcut. Filled squares and open circles show the results for red member galaxies and all member galaxies, respectively. Horizontal lines with shading are the scale radius and ellipticity for the mass distribution, measured by stacked lensing, for the same cluster sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767930/mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767930\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=eddHVJwkj~twrjisAjwlV~zzLJdU7SXX2fy~BfrkK2EqkdtRJQcxZB59g5x5IISaBTaxk6YCI1ghjJ59nxl6iDrR6HpwdnUDerHehC~G-lxnuY4coNc9c-~1ddXCLXgJlmEUrXtDJbf1P40-I5ZMbjoRHqpYSSkZUAiEx7hVnaT~a5El7uRfJaK8M5~bIOrAtasHwCHANEJ6Tfv-64VnvZ0QtjxPCpbypNUaod0-hYr4qhuM~6rwDl1g0R46HRQrSqZMu8REB0aR2ilE9QG6XO7q4e1rkMbcpvMXn16EDZ-mijt~8wi92vQG~gBF-0BEvOrW3X79aifObX8MxwrlPQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767930&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f15.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mean scale radius \u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (upper) and mean ellipticity \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (lower) of the member galaxy distribution from stacking 25 clusters, as a function of the luminosity cut <em>L</em><sub>cut</sub>. Filled squares and open circles show the results for red member galaxies and all member galaxies, respectively. Horizontal lines with shading are the scale radius and ellipticity for the mass distribution, measured by stacked lensing, for the same cluster sample.</p></div></div>                        <a class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767933\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t7\" data-id=\"t7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Analysis results on the member galaxy distribution.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td><em>L</em><sub>lim</sub> (<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (red) (<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (red)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (all) (<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (all)\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>0.27<sup>+0.08</sup><sub>\u22120.06</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.49<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.05</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.23<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.05</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.55<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10<sup>\u22120.5</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.23<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.40<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.28<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.36<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.24<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.02</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.36<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.02</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.32<sup>+0.05</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.37<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><td><em>L</em><sub>lim</sub> (<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (red) (<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (red)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>r</em><sub>s</sub>\u3009 (all) (<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>e</em>\u3009 (all)\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>0.27<sup>+0.08</sup><sub>\u22120.06</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.49<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.05</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.23<sup>+0.06</sup><sub>\u22120.05</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.55<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10<sup>\u22120.5</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.23<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.40<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.28<sup>+0.04</sup><sub>\u22120.04</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.36<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>10<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0</td><td>0.24<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.02</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.36<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.02</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.32<sup>+0.05</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.37<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.03</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767933\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The radial distribution has also been studied in previous work. Measurements of the projected number density distributions suggest low concentration values of <em>c</em>\u223c 2\u20135 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Katgert, Biviano &amp; Mazure 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b72\" data-open=\"b72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lin, Mohr &amp; Stanford 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hansen et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lin &amp; Mohr 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Biviano &amp; Poggianti 2009</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lin &amp; Mohr (2007)</a> found that more luminous galaxies tend to be distributed with large concentrations, which is consistent with our results in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f15\" data-open=\"f15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 15</a>. Simulation work by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nagai &amp; Kravtsov (2005)</a> also predicts that the galaxy number density distribution is slightly more extended than the mass distribution, which is again consistent with our result, although no significant dependence of the concentration on the stellar mass was reported from the simulations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There have been measurements of the ellipticity of the projected galaxy number density distributions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b113\" data-open=\"b113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paz et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b95\" data-open=\"b95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Niederste-Ostholt et al. 2010</a>), but its connection with the underlying mass distribution has not yet fully been explored. The similar ellipticity for luminous member galaxies is reasonable, but the origin of the smaller mean ellipticity for fainter galaxies is unclear. Essentially, the smaller mean ellipticity for the stacked cluster sample indicates either the galaxy distribution is on average rounder or there is a large misalignment (i.e. difference in the position angles) between the mass and galaxy distribution. In either case, careful simulation work is crucial to check if the observed distribution is in agreement with current understanding of cluster galaxy formation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767938 id=\"16767938\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss7>7\u2002CONCLUSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have performed a combined strong and weak lensing analysis for a sample of 28 clusters in the redshift range 0.28 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.68. The cluster sample is based on the SGAS, a large survey of giant arcs amongst SDSS clusters. In this paper, we have presented extensive follow-up observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam, which enables reliable weak lensing measurements out to large radii. Combined with the giant arcs with significant amount of spectroscopic information, we can constrain mass distributions of these clusters quite well to measure the concentration and shape of the mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass\u2013concentration relation derived from our lensing analysis has the slope of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u221d<em>M</em><sup>\u22120.59\u00b10.12</sup><sub>vir</sub>, which is significantly steeper than the slope predicted by the theoretical expectation of \u22120.2 which includes the effect of the lensing bias. Concentrations measured by the combined lensing analysis are in reasonable agreement with the \u039bCDM prediction for massive clusters (<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>), if we take proper account of the lensing bias. The result indicates that the anomalously high concentration (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>), which has been claimed from analysis of small number of lensing clusters, is now much less evident, thanks to the much larger number of clusters we have analysed in the paper. On the other hand, observed concentrations appear to be significantly higher than theoretical expectations for lower masses of <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, which may be explained as arising from the effects of cooling baryons in cluster centres.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have also stacked tangential shear profiles for the sample of clusters to obtain an accurate mean profile, which is seen to be in good agreement with the NFW profile. Our stacking analysis at different Einstein radii and mass bins has confirmed our results on the mass\u2013concentration relation from the individual analysis of these clusters. In addition to the radial profile, we have explored the stacked 2D shear map to study the shape of the projected mass distribution. By aligning shear maps of individual clusters with the position angles of dark haloes from strong lens modelling, we were able to detect the elliptical shape of the stacked mass distribution at the 5\u03c3 level. The mean ellipticity of \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06 is in excellent agreement with the \u039bCDM expectation. The significant detection of the highly elliptical shape of dark matter haloes with weak lensing has also been reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2010)</a>; this work confirms the previous finding using a different sample and technique. Finally, based on stacking analysis we have compared distributions of cluster member galaxies with mass distributions, finding good agreement between them for luminous (<em>L</em>\u2273<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>) member galaxies. Distributions of fainter galaxies are found to be more extended.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our work has demonstrated the power of combined strong and weak lensing, not only for analysis of individual clusters, but also for detailed stacked lensing analysis. The techniques described in the paper can be applied to the unique sample of lensing clusters obtained by the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <em>Hubble</em> (CLASH; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b114\" data-open=\"b114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Postman et al. 2011</a>). The detailed comparison of SGAS results as presented in the paper with upcoming CLASH results, as well as lensing results from the Local Cluster Substructure Survey (LoCuSS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>), will be very useful, particularly because of markedly different sample selection between these surveys.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767945 id=\"16767945\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title js-splitscreen-backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/kaiser/imcat/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/kaiser/imcat/</a></p></div></span></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank T. Hamana, E. Komatsu, Y.-T. Lin, S. Miyazaki, D. Nagai, N. Okabe, J. Schaye, M. Takada and K. Umetsu for useful discussions. We also thank an anonymous referee for useful comments and suggestions. This work was supported in part by the FIRST programme \u2018Subaru Measurements of Images and Redshifts (SuMIRe)\u2019, World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan, and Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research from the JSPS (23740161). PN acknowledges support from the National Science Foundation\u2019s Theory Programme via the grant AST10-44455.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767962 id=\"16767962\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Baba</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H.</div></div></span> <em>et al.</em>, <div class=\"year\">2002</div>, in Bohlender D. class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F729%2F2%2F127\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F729%2F2%2F127\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b132\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b132\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b132\" href=\"javascript:;\"
