class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2010.408.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.408.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.408.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b139\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b139\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b139\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b139\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b139\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b139\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Barkana</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Rephaeli</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Y.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ben\u00edtez</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2011a</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">410</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1939</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b140\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b140\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b140\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b140\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b140\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b140\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div></span> <em>et al.</em>, <div class=\"year\">2011b</div>, preprint (arXiv:1103.5618)</p></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b141\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b141\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b141\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b141\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b141\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b141\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bartelmann</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Rephaeli</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Y.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Oguri</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ben\u00edtez</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hao</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Umetsu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">K.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2011c</div>, preprint (arXiv:1105.2295)</p></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767966 id=\"16767966\" class=\"backappendixgroup-title js-splitscreen-backappendixgroup-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendices</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767968 id=\"16767968\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11>APPENDIX A:\u2002EXPECTED PROPERTIES OF STRONG-LENSING-SELECTED CLUSTERS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We predict properties of clusters in our strong-lens-selected cluster sample using a semi-analytic model developed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a>, which is based on a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. In brief, a catalogue of haloes is generated according to the mass function and axial ratio distribution derived from <em>N</em>-body simulations, and each halo is projected along random direction to compute its lensing property (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b102\" data-open=\"b102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Keeton 2004</a>). The projected convergence profile is compared with that of a spherical NFW profile to estimate the mass <em>M</em><sub>vir,\u20032D</sub>, the concentration <em>c</em><sub>vir,\u20032D</sub>, and the ellipticity <em>e</em> of the projected mass distribution. Here we fix the lens (cluster) and source redshift to <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>= 0.45 and <em>z</em>= 2, respectively, which are typical for our cluster lens sample analysed in the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compute a giant arc cross-section \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> of each halo from ray-tracing of extended sources using <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). The source is assumed to have a S\u00e9rsic profile with <em>r</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>= 0.4\u2003arcsec and the ellipticity randomly assigned between 0 and 0.5. For each cluster we compute the arc cross-section for the length-to-width ratio of <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> &gt; 5 by randomly throwing source galaxies in the source plane. Output images are convolved with the Gaussian kernel with the full width at half-maximum of 0.8\u2003arcsec in order to take account of the seeing effect.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We study the impact of the lensing bias by averaging concentrations and ellipticities of the halo catalogue with an appropriate weight that mimics our selection criteria. Obviously our cluster sample is weighted by the arc cross-section \u03c3<sub>arc</sub>, which can be a reasonable choice of the weight. Furthermore, we preferentially conduct follow-up observations for clusters with larger Einstein radii (i.e. giant arcs located more distant from the cluster centre), because they are expected to be more massive. We can model this selection effect, e.g. by multiplying <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu7.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=Bk1UZ8Im5RbZMhrvQqI4LPK4I0QwwUzyw21SlbrCb3Oa1YW5P3H25NQM34YF~5QNvOKP0RyJV30eJq6LsiJVfGQfl4RFP9pCIiLKo0bWbTa0WS1raGV3Bcqxp35EjF9NWjCnY0iAvct3yKHcfpZPJsVYL1X2bEEw1ZvK-9QoogGP~B3uzjFvbN9~ZBFGEkN1DA6ln30KP0AdQCT71D5BW2-qn7a~Sq55h5VBcaHRajlU8Njf6fnhVHWUXXmCC-vLU0GzaGJAv1jaoyykblXxQ7mWkXhKD1J~wAI3BvFzGDnPfjjBQ7-5LVSaHN~2fEND0LqS0tUXuqiTcn0Q2RdAQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu7.gif\" /></span> to the weight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f16\" data-open=\"f16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A1</a> shows the mass\u2013concentration relation derived from the projected mass distribution assuming a spherical mass distribution, which is relevant for the comparison with our lensing measurement, based on the semi-analytic calculation described above. We find that the enhancement of the concentration parameter due to the lensing bias is a strong function of the mass. For instance, when both the arc cross-section and the Einstein radius are used for computing the lensing bias, the concentration parameter is enhanced by \u223c80 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 8 \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, \u223c30 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 4 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> and \u223c20 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767982\" scrollto-destination=\"16767982\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=TLRM3PFi1pbNU~v4DEDzyhXvmoKOtrqUqvs~SR1aoBuveWEPN6lecme0oFccvnXp8xlgrvoZ0~WDFu6ZekQm72LDIz2BiTNnN~Bxv7tH65gWbiBaV8ACaF2c8jfGmTbETbtgR8EXWM0WPgrcRvJ~rRwzG8JbsYRgXGL-GszweHDu41IoeZv20tBcv~Pa0URr4FhZ37qVBRNGk8JHYE7i4oiYBNfjR30CWQBuwR0nlbi~faR0lwTujWCSKBzNMylYY2MpLHYfWzF0yBIGcvZbT5mNEl9vt2Sv3k6lBtke~xgj00oc5LVK7UTNq9OX~dYqc1CSZpIjyjemaac5z9xOXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for z= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3arc or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8E, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various N-body simulations (Duffy et al. 2008; Gao et al. 2008; Prada et al. 2011). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767982/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767982\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=KQ9knH-vjmjw3G5Gwvp1fdxKcgich67HAoIAx3fE1Ev5I8~litpTmMMIpQOYMQacNnK0~s2WKtg4nbJ0rsBWRx-iRnN8OslwrgNhO2SMpa6GjHWwHQjb2zWVDkGUmEAUla2TSScqXMz4BAQXRhsCWMbrrjuId3d~A-rWHrymaSga6v-QavpUhtAbmwB0SM6PZz5RrZYJhOQ1ppQH4B4qQ1-EFv~WjlJFDgavpu6yH-~~k8mgEF27BIF3gX21bgLy7LHHLuTQULZ6caHXnrfsiTfF6ULI6STl2mY4XmWxjocDsbux8yoLyRgWycwZ-Hj8tzBwMAr0~yjwvNvAC19Bpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767982&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for <em>z</em>= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various <em>N</em>-body simulations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. 2011</a>). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=TLRM3PFi1pbNU~v4DEDzyhXvmoKOtrqUqvs~SR1aoBuveWEPN6lecme0oFccvnXp8xlgrvoZ0~WDFu6ZekQm72LDIz2BiTNnN~Bxv7tH65gWbiBaV8ACaF2c8jfGmTbETbtgR8EXWM0WPgrcRvJ~rRwzG8JbsYRgXGL-GszweHDu41IoeZv20tBcv~Pa0URr4FhZ37qVBRNGk8JHYE7i4oiYBNfjR30CWQBuwR0nlbi~faR0lwTujWCSKBzNMylYY2MpLHYfWzF0yBIGcvZbT5mNEl9vt2Sv3k6lBtke~xgj00oc5LVK7UTNq9OX~dYqc1CSZpIjyjemaac5z9xOXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for z= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3arc or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8E, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various N-body simulations (Duffy et al. 2008; Gao et al. 2008; Prada et al. 2011). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767982/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767982\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=KQ9knH-vjmjw3G5Gwvp1fdxKcgich67HAoIAx3fE1Ev5I8~litpTmMMIpQOYMQacNnK0~s2WKtg4nbJ0rsBWRx-iRnN8OslwrgNhO2SMpa6GjHWwHQjb2zWVDkGUmEAUla2TSScqXMz4BAQXRhsCWMbrrjuId3d~A-rWHrymaSga6v-QavpUhtAbmwB0SM6PZz5RrZYJhOQ1ppQH4B4qQ1-EFv~WjlJFDgavpu6yH-~~k8mgEF27BIF3gX21bgLy7LHHLuTQULZ6caHXnrfsiTfF6ULI6STl2mY4XmWxjocDsbux8yoLyRgWycwZ-Hj8tzBwMAr0~yjwvNvAC19Bpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767982&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for <em>z</em>= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various <em>N</em>-body simulations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. 2011</a>). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also compare our result based on the triaxial model with other work studying the mass\u2013concentration relation in <em>N</em>-body simulations based on the spherical NFW profile. We find that our mass\u2013concentration relation has larger concentration than predicted by the relation of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a>, which has been adopted for comparisons with lensing measurements in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>. On the other hand, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> concluded that concentrations of massive haloes evolve little with the redshift. As a result, concentrations predicted by the model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> are much larger compared with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a> relation predicts. We note that such little evolution of massive haloes has been noted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b136\" data-open=\"b136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. (2003)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b137\" data-open=\"b137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. (2009)</a>. Our mass\u2013concentration relation based on the triaxial model resides in between the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> relations, and more resembles the relation presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. (2008)</a> which was essentially the modification of the model proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. (1997)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also investigate the impact of the lensing bias on the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution. We find that the lensing bias due to the arc cross-section tends to increase the mean ellipticity, which is understood by the fact that the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution significantly enhances the giant arc cross-section (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). In contrast, the lensing bias due to the Einstein radius decreases the mean Einstein radius, because of the alignment of the major axis with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>). Therefore, these two lensing biases counteract with each other. In either case, however, the effect of the lensing bias appears to be small, with the change of the mean ellipticity by \u223c0.05 at most.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a> has shown that extreme lensing clusters having very large Einstein radii are more severely affected by the lensing bias. Thus we check the dependence of the concentration and projected ellipticity on the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. For the mass distribution of the cluster, we assume a flat prior of log\u2003<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> between 10<sup>14</sup> and 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and the number distribution predicted by the mass function of dark haloes above 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, which is expected to more or less resemble the selection function of our cluster sample. The result shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A2</a> indicates that both the concentration and ellipticity depend strongly on the Einstein radius such that clusters with larger Einstein radii are more concentrated and spherical. Again, this can be interpreted by the alignment of the major axis with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"16767989\" scrollto-destination=\"16767989\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=aWAzoqoLZXPiNVjQP7Yyjl3~d7Lngbo~7t9f97hnBE8vBHcqlqkZ6eIJbtJR3I9z4ms2z3BfKuG7FI-uXQLUK9frmkfYsSLWBdgA7PiwGr6OiZpktTvUE7GEr1a~PSixH2dW7RBlMUa6pYqBaQZHoCADgyw73smIzmQXkt-FC9JtV4jk6WlP31WE7M8umjXyslR0-N02VRtWE3UWOlf0sUaApPW3vPoDzLPcaOeDenz0V6qkBRYohHugt4YfvwkI298rVDFQoDjZOmZ2n~mqvNiusNd~QhIEr86dwpKXwc0rHEiryW3Qo-EGoflBNFPD2KKyK66YLw4ofpUZvxxjAA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8E. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002) and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767989/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767989\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=PSUOQmpaOqVnNG5OY2LmPHYuiV0WhoKN85EyUe0Th0fegQnuJU0bROnpH5YY5PM2DIFBRQPbzK9~FGRGvxPo7Ekb43j0oMsWdMBtxcb-EhLkeuSs1f9fclkTwk2I6wKnLFnGcmbrSgaT4MD8LZ1qxbdlcKGZ2VuYCKchCar9wovjN1HZjptHz~n4XoURy7SsDolBbTQUdWn7jMxVy1AvT92ubGUyUTISb5Z~9iOLJPh--MRvHi8WKt78yYcxl2yNqwSU4Eeh2fOun-cLoEeLXQIi599sWbzjKHHT~RGegp5z5h8~ydv3~Ypa36QezxbC1ErPKCvSJfwk8C~JtukHrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767989&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a> and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=aWAzoqoLZXPiNVjQP7Yyjl3~d7Lngbo~7t9f97hnBE8vBHcqlqkZ6eIJbtJR3I9z4ms2z3BfKuG7FI-uXQLUK9frmkfYsSLWBdgA7PiwGr6OiZpktTvUE7GEr1a~PSixH2dW7RBlMUa6pYqBaQZHoCADgyw73smIzmQXkt-FC9JtV4jk6WlP31WE7M8umjXyslR0-N02VRtWE3UWOlf0sUaApPW3vPoDzLPcaOeDenz0V6qkBRYohHugt4YfvwkI298rVDFQoDjZOmZ2n~mqvNiusNd~QhIEr86dwpKXwc0rHEiryW3Qo-EGoflBNFPD2KKyK66YLw4ofpUZvxxjAA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8E. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002) and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767989/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767989\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=PSUOQmpaOqVnNG5OY2LmPHYuiV0WhoKN85EyUe0Th0fegQnuJU0bROnpH5YY5PM2DIFBRQPbzK9~FGRGvxPo7Ekb43j0oMsWdMBtxcb-EhLkeuSs1f9fclkTwk2I6wKnLFnGcmbrSgaT4MD8LZ1qxbdlcKGZ2VuYCKchCar9wovjN1HZjptHz~n4XoURy7SsDolBbTQUdWn7jMxVy1AvT92ubGUyUTISb5Z~9iOLJPh--MRvHi8WKt78yYcxl2yNqwSU4Eeh2fOun-cLoEeLXQIi599sWbzjKHHT~RGegp5z5h8~ydv3~Ypa36QezxbC1ErPKCvSJfwk8C~JtukHrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767989&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a> and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767991 id=\"16767991\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss12>APPENDIX B:\u2002LENSING ANALYSIS FOR INDIVIDUAL CLUSTERS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Figs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f18  f24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f18  f24\" data-open=\"f18  f24\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1\u2013B7</a>, we show for each cluster the critical curve of the best-fitting strong lens modelling plotted on the Subaru/Suprime-cam <em>gri</em>-composite image (2 \u00d7 2\u2003arcmin<sup>2</sup>; squares are positions of multiple images used for mass modelling), weak lensing mass map plotted on the Subaru/Suprime-cam <em>r</em>-band image (contours are drawn with spacing of 1\u03c3 noise level, and the cross indicates the position of the brightest cluster galaxy), and the tangential shear profile as well as the best-fitting NFW profiles. The shading in the tangential profile plot indicates the measured Einstein radius and its 1\u03c3 error at the arc redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"16767995\" scrollto-destination=\"16767995\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=eTe8kjOXiRgEGsRrIRNkzpB264fgyge9cpyI1hzyZmgWrk999ABZkj-smvKwHZx9jLGcyqFt6~znJ7S5C-oYdlW7ZsGVWtklvbin37XUMgBq8oMqkct-5m-gmkI5aUy1WJiW9PwmfOPjNwJNI6V2yb5W7tKwOrWv3RT9S-goshqzZjfrEzcO7fHaR09p3epCX0F8L1tT55QyhExVVhoW5-twTf5KTeDwM9Gq~1TErTgKpFFUIA-WBnVInA39FtOTtAaftKG4L~lLrFKjKdKz1MH7kKbHTK0kuQF0eCdzG3WEzr1nir7GH3FfxWH6XuSRoOgwsyyyAIRKDara4S-D1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS\u2003J0851+3331, SDSS\u2003J0915+3826, SDSS\u2003J0957+0509, SDSS\u2003J1004+4112.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f18.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a    </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-1\" link-destination=\"16767945\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-1\" link-destination=\"16767966\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a class=\"js-jumplink scrollTo\" href=\"#16767968\">APPENDIX A:\u2002EXPECTED PROPERTIES OF STRONG-LENSING-SELECTED CLUSTERS</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n        <li class=\"section-jump-link head-2\" link-destination=\"16767991\">\r\n            <div class=\"section-jump-link__link-wrap\">\r\n\r\n                <a class=\"js-jumplink scrollTo\" href=\"#16767991\">APPENDIX B:\u2002LENSING ANALYSIS FOR INDIVIDUAL CLUSTERS</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n        </li>\r\n</ul>\r\n \r\n $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view at-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu-split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n                                </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown drop-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-dropdown=\"FilterDrop\" aria-haspopup=\"true\">\r\n                                <i class=\"icon-menu_views\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ViewsDrop\" class=\"f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article contents</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-cite js-item-cite\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\r\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button at-CiteButton\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal>\r\n    <i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i>\r\n    <span>Cite</span>\r\n</a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal js-citation-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Masamune Oguri, Matthew B. Bayliss, H\u00e5kon Dahle, Keren Sharon, Michael D. Gladders, Priyamvada Natarajan, Joseph F. Hennawi, Benjamin P. Koester,  Combined strong and weak lensing analysis of 28 clusters from the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 420, Issue 4, March 2012, Pages 3213\u20133239, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x\">https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\r\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Combined%20strong%20and%20weak%20lensing%20analysis%20of%2028%20clusters%20from%20the%20Sloan%20Giant%20Arcs%20Survey%26lt%3Bspan%20class%3D%26quot%3BxrefLink%26quot%3B%20id%3D%26quot%3Bjumplink-fn2%26quot%3B%26gt%3B%26lt%3B%2Fspan%26gt%3B%26lt%3Ba%20href%3D%26quot%3Bjavascript%3A%3B%26quot%3B%20reveal-id%3D%26quot%3Bfn2%26quot%3B%20data-open%3D%26quot%3Bfn2%26quot%3B%20class%3D%26quot%3Blink%20link-ref%20link-reveal%20xref-fn%20js-xref-fn%26quot%3B%26gt%3B%2A%26lt%3B%2Fa%26gt%3B&amp;publicationDate=2012-03-01&amp;volumeNum=420&amp;issueNum=4&amp;author=Oguri%2C%20Masamune%3B%20Bayliss%2C%20Matthew%20B.&amp;startPage=3213&amp;endPage=3239&amp;contentId=10.1111%2Fj.1365-2966.2011.20248.x&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\" class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767784 id=\"16767784\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We study the mass distribution of a sample of 28 galaxy clusters using strong and weak lensing observations. The clusters are selected via their strong lensing properties as part of the Sloan Giant Arcs Survey (SGAS) from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Mass modelling of the strong lensing information from the giant arcs is combined with weak lensing measurements from deep Subaru/Suprime-cam images to primarily obtain robust constraints on the concentration parameter and the shape of the mass distribution. We find that the concentration <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> is a steep function of the mass, <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u221d<em>M</em><sup>\u22120.59\u00b10.12</sup><sub>vir</sub>, with the value roughly consistent with the lensing-bias-corrected theoretical expectation for high-mass (\u223c10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>) clusters. However, the observationally inferred concentration parameters appear to be much higher at lower masses (\u223c10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>), possibly a consequence of the modification to the inner density profiles provided by baryon cooling. The steep mass\u2013concentration relation is also supported from direct stacking analysis of the tangential shear profiles. In addition, we explore the 2D shape of the projected mass distribution by stacking weak lensing shear maps of individual clusters with prior information on the position angle from strong lens modelling, and find significant evidence for a large mean ellipticity with the best-fitting value of \u3008<em>e</em>\u3009= 0.47 \u00b1 0.06 for the mass distribution of the stacked sample. We find that the luminous cluster member galaxy distribution traces the overall mass distribution very well, although the distribution of fainter cluster galaxies appears to be more extended than the total mass.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: weak&quot;\">gravitational lensing: weak</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767786 id=\"16767786\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1\u2002INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing plays a dominant role in determining the mass distribution of distant galaxies and clusters of galaxies, because it allows direct measurements of the distribution of dark matter which accounts for \u223c90 per cent of the total matter content of the Universe. Precise measurements of dark matter distributions are important not only for understanding the formation of galaxies in the context of the hierarchical structure formation scenario, but also for testing the properties of the putative dark matter particle, in particular its cold and collisionless nature. Observations of clusters are suitable and very apt for the latter purpose, as the long cooling time-scale for hot gas in clusters indicates that the cluster gravitational potential is mainly determined by the dynamics of the dominant dark matter component which are well predicted by <em>N</em>-body simulations. However, it is also expected that the baryonic component in clusters, which dominates the mass in the innermost regions, should play an important role at some point.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are two regimes of gravitational lensing that can be employed to measure and map the mass distribution in clusters. One is strong lensing, i.e. the regime that produces drastic lensing events with highly elongated arcs or multiple images of background objects (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kochanek 2006</a>; Kneib &amp; Natarajan 2011, for reviews). The other lensing regime is weak lensing wherein statistical measurements of small distortions in the shapes of background galaxies are produced by a massive, foreground cluster (see e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bartelmann &amp; Schneider 2001</a>, for a review). Since strong and weak lensing probe mass distributions at different radii, the combination of these two is powerful and essential for the full understanding and detailed mapping of the gravitational potential of clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing studies of clusters have indeed confirmed several important predictions of the standard \u039b-dominated cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model. For instance, from numerical simulations, the radial run of the density of the mass distribution is predicted to have a universal form, that of the Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW) profile (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro, Frenk &amp; White 1996</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Detailed lensing measurements of massive clusters have confirmed this prediction by and large, although there does appear to be some cluster to cluster variations (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>). Another important prediction is that massive clusters are on average highly non-spherical with a typical major-to-minor axial ratio of \u223c2:1 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto 2002</a>). Weak lensing measurements of dark matter distributions in a sample of massive clusters have directly confirmed this prediction as well (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2010</a>). Furthermore, lensing analysis of several merging clusters of galaxies strongly supports the collisionless nature of dark matter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b85\" data-open=\"b85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Merten et al. 2011</a>), although a possible case against the collisionless nature has also been discovered (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b74\" data-open=\"b74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mahdavi et al. 2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, measurements of the concentration parameter, which appears in the NFW profile, from gravitational lensing observations for clusters have been controversial. The concentration parameter is defined as the ratio of the virial radius to the scale radius, and is a dimensionless parameter that quantifies the degree of the mass accumulation in the innermost regions. The standard \u039bCDM model makes a prediction about this parameter too, namely that more massive haloes or haloes at higher redshifts have smaller values of the concentration parameter on average (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>). However, measurements of the dark matter distribution in the massive lensing cluster A1689 for instance, using both strong and weak lensing, have indicated that the mass distribution is surprisingly highly concentrated with an estimated concentration parameter of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 12, which is significantly higher than the expected standard \u039bCDM prediction of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 4 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b129\" data-open=\"b129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The interpretation of this result of lensing clusters being overconcentrated requires careful consideration due to the role played by projection and selection effects. This is because lensing observables can only measure the projected mass distribution, and hence the recovery of the 3D mass distribution requires additional assumptions about the elongation along the line-of-sight direction. For instance, because of the large triaxiality of dark matter haloes, the mass and concentration parameter inferred from gravitational lensing depend strongly on the orientation with respect to the line-of-sight direction. This naturally implies that both the mass and concentration are significantly overestimated when observed along the major axis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe, De Lucia &amp; King 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b103\" data-open=\"b103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless &amp; King 2007</a>). The large orientation dependence in turn suggests that strong-lensing-selected clusters represent a highly biased population with their major axes preferentially aligned with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2010</a>). Thus, the dark matter distribution of A1689 alone does not pose a severe challenge to the \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b103\" data-open=\"b103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless, King &amp; Clowe 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b127\" data-open=\"b127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno, Jetzer &amp; Lubini 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Morandi et al. 2011a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Morandi, Pedersen &amp; Limousin 2011b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b126\" data-open=\"b126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno &amp; Umetsu 2011</a>), although such high values of the concentration parameter appear to be common in the combined strong and weak lensing analysis of massive clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Comerford &amp; Natarajan 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b140\" data-open=\"b140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011b</a>). High concentrations can be tested with the distribution of the Einstein radii, but the results have still not converged (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b117\" data-open=\"b117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b139\" data-open=\"b139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b141\" data-open=\"b141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>). Also puzzling is the fact that such high concentrations have not been claimed in weak lensing analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>) or X-ray analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Buote et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori et al. 2010</a>) for samples of massive clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the combined strong and weak lensing analysis allows accurate and robust measurements of the concentration parameter, the current main limitation is the small number of clusters available for such a detailed combined analysis. The Sloan Giant Arcs Survey (SGAS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011a</a>), which is a survey of strongly lensed giant arcs from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b135\" data-open=\"b135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">York et al. 2000</a>), has already discovered more than 30 bright giant arcs and therefore offers an ideal technique to expand the sample of clusters appropriate for detailed lensing analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present a systematic study of strong and weak lensing analysis for a sample of 28 clusters from the SGAS, based on our extensive follow-up imaging observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2002</a>). We study the radial dark matter distributions of the clusters in detail to measure the concentration parameters for these clusters. For this purpose we conduct a stacked lensing analysis as well as individual modelling of clusters. With the stacked lensing technique we also study the 2D mass distribution, and constrain the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The structure of this paper is as follows. We describe our cluster sample and follow-up imaging observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>, and present the strong and weak lensing analysis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. The results are combined to discuss the mass\u2013concentration relation in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>. We also conduct a stacked lensing analysis, which is detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>. We then study the cluster member galaxy distribution in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss6\"></span><a href=\"#ss6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 6</a>, and summarize the main conclusions in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss7\"></span><a href=\"#ss7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 7</a>. In Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> we conduct semi-analytic calculations to evaluate the effect of the lensing bias on various observables. Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a> summarizes the strong and weak lensing analysis results of individual clusters. Throughout the paper we assume the standard \u039b-dominated flat cosmological model with the matter density \u03a9<sub>M</sub>= 1 \u2212\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>= 0.275, the dimensionless Hubble constant <em>h</em>= 0.702, the baryon density \u03a9<sub>b</sub><em>h</em><sup>2</sup>= 0.022\u200355, the spectral index <em>n</em><sub>s</sub>= 0.968, and a normalization for the matter power spectrum \u03c3<sub>8</sub>= 0.816 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b65\" data-open=\"b65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Komatsu et al. 2011</a>) where needed.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767795 id=\"16767795\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2\u2002CLUSTER SAMPLE AND FOLLOW-UP OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767796 id=\"16767796\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-1>2.1\u2002Cluster sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We draw our sample of clusters for detailed lensing analysis from SGAS, which involved an initial extensive visual search of giant arcs in red-sequence-selected clusters in the SDSS. The sample is constructed utilizing two selection methods. One is the SDSS \u2018Visual\u2019 survey which selects giant arc candidates from the visual inspection of the SDSS imaging data (Gladders et al., in preparation). The other survey is the SDSS \u2018Blind\u2019 survey which searches for giant arcs from <em>g</em>-band follow-up imaging of the most massive \u223c200 clusters selected from the SDSS imaging data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2008</a>). Some of the clusters have also been reported in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b133\" data-open=\"b133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wen, Han &amp; Jiang (2011)</a>. We are conducting massive spectroscopic follow-up observations of these new giant arcs with the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hook et al. 2004</a>) to measure redshifts for the newly discovered arcs as well as redshifts for the lensing clusters. See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a> for details of our spectroscopic follow-up and successful redshift measurements for more than 20 giant arcs. We note that this paper includes a few new GMOS spectroscopy results obtained after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>. We also include two cluster-scale quasar lenses discovered from the SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b104\" data-open=\"b104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b105\" data-open=\"b105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. 2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), as they satisfy similar selection criteria to the SGAS lens sample, and have also been observed at the Subaru telescope.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767798 id=\"16767798\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2>2.2\u2002Observations with Subaru/Suprime-cam</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed the SGAS giant arc clusters with Suprime-cam (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2002</a>) at the Subaru 8.2-m telescope, primarily for the wide-field weak lensing analysis, between 2007 June and 2011 April. Combined with a few images retrieved from the archive system named SMOKA (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Baba et al. 2002</a>), our sample comprises 28 clusters with Subaru/Suprime-cam multicolour follow-up imaging. The Suprime-cam has a large field of view of \u223c34 \u00d7 27\u2003arcmin<sup>2</sup> with a pixel scale of 0.202\u2003arcsec, and is therefore ideal for weak lensing studies of massive clusters at intermediate redshifts whose typical virial radius is \u2272 10\u2003arcmin. Our strategy is to obtain deep images in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em> and <em>i</em> bands, with the longest exposure in <em>r</em> band. The deep <em>r</em>-band imaging is performed to conduct weak lensing analysis using <em>r</em>-band images, but the additional colour information from <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> bands are crucial for reliable selection of background galaxies for the weak lensing analysis (more details presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>) as well as secure identifications of multiply imaged arcs in the cluster cores. We note that the weak lensing analysis results of the first four SGAS clusters have been published in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data are reduced using <span class=\"small-caps\">sdfred</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">sdfred</span>2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b134\" data-open=\"b134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Yagi et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b111\" data-open=\"b111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ouchi et al. 2004</a>). The reduction procedure includes bias subtraction, flat-fielding, distortion correction, sky subtraction, and co-adding to generate the final mosaic images. When co-adding, we remove some of the frames which have significantly worse seeing sizes than other frames. We derive the magnitude zero-points by comparing objects in the reduced images with the photometric catalogue of the SDSS data. The astrometric calibration is performed with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin 2006</a>), again using objects in the SDSS data as astrometric reference sources. The photometric galaxy catalogue of each cluster is constructed using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>), with the Galactic extinction correction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b123\" data-open=\"b123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schlegel, Finkbeiner &amp; Davis 1998</a>). Our 28 cluster sample and basic parameters of follow-up images are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767801\" scrollto-destination=\"16767801\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster sample and summary of Subaru/Suprime-cam imaging observations. The redshifts of the clusters are taken from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>Name\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000)\u00a0</td><td>Dec. telescope.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note282\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note282\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>We use deep <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band images retrieved from SMOKA instead of obtaining <em>r</em>-band follow-up images. This field includes two separate cluster cores, both of which act as strong lenses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note283\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note283\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Based on the new spectroscopic observation with Gemini/GMOS conducted after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al.
