class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t1_note280\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note280\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Photometric redshifts estimated from the SDSS data, as spectroscopic cluster redshifts are not available for these clusters.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note281\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note281\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Based on the spectroscopy of the brightest cluster galaxy at Apache Point Observatory 3.5-m telescope.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note282\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note282\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>We use deep <em>R</em><sub>c</sub>-band images retrieved from SMOKA instead of obtaining <em>r</em>-band follow-up images. This field includes two separate cluster cores, both of which act as strong lenses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t1_note283\"></span><div content-id=\"t1_note283\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Based on the new spectroscopic observation with Gemini/GMOS conducted after the publication of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767801\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767802 id=\"16767802\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3\u2002STRONG AND WEAK LENSING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767803 id=\"16767803\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1\u2002Strong lensing analysis</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We mostly follow <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a> for the strong lens modelling methodology. Basically we assume the elliptical extension of the NFW profile (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. 1996</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) to model the mass distribution of a dark halo, and add contributions from member galaxies assuming the pseudo-Jaffe model. The velocity dispersion \u03c3 and cut-off scale <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> of the pseudo-Jaffe model are assumed to scale with the luminosity as <em>L</em>\u221d\u03c3<sup>1/4</sup> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>\u221d<em>L</em><sup>1/2</sup>. The normalization and cut-off radius may be fixed to a typical value if there are not enough observational constraints. We may also fix the centre of the main halo to the position of the brightest cluster galaxy, depending on the number of available constraints and the configuration of multiple images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify multiple images based on spectroscopic follow-up results of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a> as well as colours of lensed arcs measured from the Subaru/Suprime-cam images. While redshifts of arcs are available for many of our sample clusters, for clusters without any arc spectroscopy information we assume that the redshift of the main arc is <em>z</em><sub>arc</sub>= 2 with the conservative 1\u03c3 error of \u03c3(<em>z</em><sub>arc</sub>) = 1, because our extensive spectroscopic observations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011a</a>) as well as photometric analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss 2011</a>) have convincingly shown that most of the arcs in our sample fall in this redshift range. The positional uncertainties of all the arcs are assumed to be 1\u2003arcsec in the image plane, which is much larger than measurement uncertainties, but is typical of the uncertainties associated with parametric strong lens modelling of clusters.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We perform strong lens modelling using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>), using the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization in the source plane (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). From the derived best-fitting mass model, we compute the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> of the system by solving the following equation:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m1.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m1.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=N56gzYMIzWQ6cIQ1sakwH-jOH1p6F5EOFjDjbpotOaKWgpIn~SdAoYYV4Qgo9cgEyDWi2ybYgAJ48CxC7S7hClEyE7HjdMTW0Flgz~422cIFc6vDmZ1XL-QU52nq6ZgF95jt9pJPq8mVJKn5gz4YQLoN9EkT9GElEuxdeUVRULNFesST~BccRLEwdk606MMhjWYFPTlO7Iz7J~YieiTLfMtrxbHqx28-9LtbFE0VBxuFZme1tfuZAy4tS3JGMbE55QmdlFJgBn-nH9E0SedXGrHIPw~efNj-5Qv-azLw2Q4K73PV8jgEb9cnG39kn7zfi5Rp7tkZVc-Vsm~qI6ek~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m1.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">1</span></div> and use only this Einstein radius determination as the constraint from our strong lensing analysis. We use the Einstein radius as it is a robust quantity that is well constrained from the strong lensing modelling and is fairly insensitive to our model assumptions (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>). We estimate the error on the Einstein radius by changing one (usually mass) of the parameters from the best-fitting values, optimizing other parameters, and monitoring the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> differences. However, to be conservative in our estimates, we always assign a minimum error of 10 per cent to the Einstein radius, even if the procedure above returns smaller errors, given the unaccounted complexity of cluster mass distributions and projections along line of sight (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">D\u2019Aloisio &amp; Natarajan 2011</a>). For clusters without arc spectroscopy, we conservatively estimate the 1\u03c3 error on the Einstein radius by changing the arc redshift by \u00b11. The Einstein radii are computed for both the arc redshift <em>z</em><sub>arc</sub> and the fixed source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2. We use the former value for the combined strong and weak lensing analysis, whereas the latter value is used for the statistical, stacked lensing analysis.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the definition of the Einstein radius adopted here differs from that in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>. In this new definition the contribution of stellar masses is explicitly included, while in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a> the Einstein radius was computed from the dark halo component alone. The use of this modified definition is because the separation of dark and luminous components is not obvious, and has to rely on several assumptions, unless we have additional data such as the velocity dispersion measurement of the central galaxy (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b122\" data-open=\"b122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b94\" data-open=\"b94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newman et al. 2009</a>). Thus the effect of baryonic components has been taken into account in interpreting our results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> lists the Einstein radii derived from strong lensing modelling. SDSS\u2003J1226+2149 and SDSS\u2003J1226+2152 are two nearby strong lensing cores in a highly complex massive structure, both of which are covered by our Subaru/Suprime-cam imaging (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011b</a>). We perform strong lensing analysis for both cores. We also show the best-fitting ellipticity <em>e</em> and the position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> of the best-fitting main NFW component, as they are used later for 2D stacking analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5.2</a>). The best-fitting critical curves for individual clusters are presented in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767809\" scrollto-destination=\"16767809\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of strong lensing analysis. We tabulate the Einstein radii both for arc redshifts and for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2, the total number of multiple images used for strong lens modelling (<em>N</em><sub>img</sub>; the number of multiple image sets is shown in parentheses), the best-fitting ellipticity (<em>e</em>) and position angle (\u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub>) of the main dark halo component, and references for arc redshifts.</p></div> </div><div \u00b1 1\u00a0</td><td>4(1)\u00a0</td><td>14.3<sup>+12.6</sup><sub>\u22122.1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.3<sup>+12.6</sup><sub>\u22122.1</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.30\u00a0</td><td>\u221261.9\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS\u2003J2111\u22120114\u00a0</td><td>2.858\u00a0</td><td>9(3)\u00a0</td><td>17.7<sup>+10.6</sup><sub>\u22125.8</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.5<sup>+9.2</sup><sub>\u22124.8</sub>\u00a0</td><td>0.24\u00a0</td><td>10.0\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><td>Name\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em><sub>arc</sub><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em><sub>img</sub>\u00a0</td><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub> clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t2_note232\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note232\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup>Note that for some clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. In this case we show the redshift of the main arc.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note233\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note233\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> is measured east of north.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note234\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note234\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup><em>References.</em> 1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2011b)</a>; 2 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2010)</a>; 3 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kubo et al. (2010)</a>; 4 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. (2003)</a>; 5 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b128\" data-open=\"b128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sharon et al. (2005)</a>; 6 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. (2006)</a>; 7 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2008b)</a>; 8 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Belokurov et al. (2009)</a>; 9 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b66\" data-open=\"b66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kubo et al. (2009)</a>; 10 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b96\" data-open=\"b96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ofek, Seitz &amp; Klein (2008)</a>; 11 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koester et al. (2010)</a>; 12 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2008)</a>; 13 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b116\" data-open=\"b116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>; 14 \u2013 new redshift not yet published in the literature; 15 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Diehl et al. (2009)</a>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767809\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong lensing analysis for some of these clusters has been published in the literature (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koester et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. 2011</a>). Our estimates of the Einstein radii presented here generally agree with these previous results. For A1703, our best-fitting Einstein radius is in excellent agreement with that of the independent strong lens modelling by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b116\" data-open=\"b116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>. An exception is SDSS\u2003J1343+4155 whose Einstein radius in our strong lens modelling result is much smaller than what presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. (2010)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gralla et al. (2011)</a> because a large offset of the halo centre from the brightest cluster galaxy has been found in the previous analysis, whereas in the present paper the centre of the halo is fixed to the location of the brightest cluster galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767811 id=\"16767811\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2\u2002Weak lensing analysis</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For weak lensing measurements, we follow the formalism outlined in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kaiser, Squires &amp; Broadhurst (KSB; 1995)</a> using the software package <span class=\"small-caps\">imcat</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a> We first detect objects in the reduced images using a hierarchical peak finding algorithm. For all the clusters in our sample, we use <em>r</em>-band images for weak lensing shear measurements. We then measure the shapes of objects by iteratively refining the centroid of each object. Stars for correcting the distortion of the point spread function (PSF) are selected in a standard way by identifying the appropriate branch in the magnitude half-light radius <em>r</em><sub>h</sub> plane, along with the peak significance cut \u03bd &gt; 15. Shapes of the stars are measured as a function of the size of the weight function, <em>r</em><sub>g</sub>, in order to make PSF corrections with matched <em>r</em><sub>g</sub> values. We divide each co-added image into 4 \u00d7 3 chunks and fit the PSF in each chunk independently with second-order bi-polynomials. The smear polarizability is corrected by computing a scalar polarizability <em>P</em><sub>s</sub> from the trace of the matrix, and then fitting <em>P</em><sub>s</sub> as a function of magnitude, <em>r</em><sub>g</sub>, and the galaxy ellipticity. For our weak lensing analysis, we only use galaxies with \u03bd &gt; 15 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=DhjJkfRAAtwxblzUir9KCd86UhL~GyJDbwWNWk5BcsLfzCcBy8uSS9DJSCNrtvyCplb92azHNXn6UwRFyhGB8HGT3sNJmh3FDJ~NKa31BL~EHEuqE~JDAh5RzavgRobmre-~h~FvlproByPVEfIebhqTThpxJwAbwYU7ALCbmUcXQ2FccUDU5NcN8lzaJEXNEP6JO1W40FeAVhTKE-YgR38hLKai~K2rzXjD8C-2-bd7OW6YJ1TWW38w32M8KCWMhpzkNThBxt~73DfTA8bEfc11AhTSpf2TRKItfoXq3rwIMKlX3wNPniM6mfNZSBP0nA6AZqxdFRl16s2mttzLHw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu2.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=NWHWPR4mCVXIiCs2gnfKigIL0-6~KdWLt1DHG8nUp6Ftn95DbyrW1OSaPYLr-X5BjTzaj7Sn9esgokEjJv9j0cuagYRNjLlmoZv2UgU8NRf9O7PWeyhbLKDxnA8o~l8PtYaq2xi1fcj-oblclmd7MX2j6QrFQAmovac1vp6PXfKLbLzwoOST1w3CO6XIFmztWzqknVjrcr4MChjDWLM0Vsrv~Azbd62DvI4RqDeLieeH7yaNj-dZaITFPyf~Hky9KWOUhWeyCGdM5VzqSJPJvtCQt~QcnVTFQwiRjU9qrVN9mmT8uzI-URlwNodZpIxUXebLELdVoocH-RoEKGIBPw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu2.gif\" /></span> and \u03c3 (<em>r</em>*<sub>h</sub>) are median and rms dispersion of half-light radii for the stars selected above. Given the general tendency of the KSB algorithm to underestimate the weak lensing shear (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Erben et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Heymans et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Massey et al. 2007</a>), we include a calibration factor of 1/0.9, i.e. this factor is multiplied to all the estimated shear values. For each object we assign the statistical weight <em>w</em><sub>g</sub> defined by (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hamana et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hamana et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b110\" data-open=\"b110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe, Okura &amp; Futamase 2010b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b130\" data-open=\"b130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>)<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m2.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=laMfuBV02wVjJAKaYMfolKgtGG8Q1Ujv7yS4NGpgry82oeWNeOBNSzyy0pQDpON6FgP8EJbjtD0E-oahR1jsyHB6VZriTPgIpa74d8P-f1feal8OiE47ZujwP5Ifn5uKKBCfBbK45BKqiZkQaUAKTg95SCvmnfw0mngBIBk8IjYy4XVvVCuo9YwlJooYZy-x6oI0360W~7c3IZ8eTEI6K1E5CSxkM01Q2NM6dpOKW4rPQKJd2BbGYZuDSERgdIZlgD9-bQZDjrdIeKJ1VNT7BODI89JODrHd2NgGYo9r8w8c~zZuTvAk4nA0pq~xNJnlPQwKFTfP-5mKO7zXyCD1Pg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m2.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div> with \u03b1= 0.4 and \u03c3<sub>g</sub> is the variance of the shear computed from 20 neighbours in the magnitude\u2013<em>r</em><sub>g</sub> plane. When computing shear by averaging shear measurements of galaxies in a bin, we also apply a 3\u03c3 clipping which appears to reduce the shear measurement bias.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To check the accuracy of the weak lensing shear measurement, we perform a series of image simulations. Specifically, we generate a galaxy catalogue using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">stuff</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin 2009</a>). Each galaxy is described by the sum of bulge and disc components, which we model with S\u00e9rsic profiles with the index <em>n</em>= 4 and 1, respectively. We also add stars in the catalogue. We convolve the image with a PSF which we assume follows the Moffat profile \u03a3(<em>r</em>) \u221d [1 + (<em>r</em>/<em>a</em>)<sup>2</sup>]<sup>\u2212\u03b2</sup> with an elliptical extension. Based on the catalogue, we generate a number of realistic Subaru/Suprime-cam like images with different seeing sizes (0.5\u20131.1\u2003arcsec) and \u03b2 (3 &lt; \u03b2 &lt; 12) using the software <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). We find that the resulting shear multiplicative error (the parameter <em>m</em> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Heymans et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Massey et al. 2007</a>) depends on both seeing size and \u03b2 such that <em>m</em> is smaller for larger seeing sizes or smaller \u03b2, but our algorithm generally yields |<em>m</em>| \u2272 0.05 for a wide range of PSF parameters examined here.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767814 id=\"16767814\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3\u2002Galaxy selection in colour\u2013colour space</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A careful selection of background galaxies is essential for cluster weak lensing studies, because contamination by cluster member galaxies is known to dilute the detected weak lensing signal significantly, particularly near the cluster centres (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b80\" data-open=\"b80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2007</a>). Our <em>gri</em>-band imaging is very powerful for reliable background galaxy selection, because we can select galaxies efficiently in colour\u2013colour space (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2010</a>).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We determine the colour cut that is appropriate for our cluster sample based on the COSMOS photometric galaxy catalogue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ilbert et al. 2009</a>). Thanks to the wide wavelength coverage from the ultraviolet to mid-infrared, the photometric redshifts are very accurate down to <em>i</em>\u223c 25. By inspecting the photometric redshift distributions in each point of the <em>g</em>\u2212<em>r</em> versus <em>r</em>\u2212<em>i</em> colour space, we determine the colour cut for our analysis as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m3.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=gdGZ3YhThXjTdqcKnINKQQjDDTvW9JyznJRmvYlAMZj~9O1a8T~wWdFz7SmhjVbSLDGPcb9nuV5BolmGwyESsU3aKGCb5P4khlShZw6g6cDC7DhSPRrCir9HM81317CVzk4MButQruCfvHye2mM0cshQa482qwre6sgotqguLJ61UIu2DTZ5Vp~MCrGmYToNPXE5Lydf~rGXjdauExxs337fLcqgIht6RGt4SJgiKUIbE8z43AImeYshFTufBwG8p76rdZX9aIZ9WUi-vWD252QxI9Y~6ooaxzhcqSKzyb9~vNqBM3RP49uNcxLI~cU0lth9oEiOf~F0C4B727hTvg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m3.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">3</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m4.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=mLA5PCjbJb5xH3aw24ffIo4NlxQxiwQdrrCzIvtVBzons8yyX07yBCZp~0Y1~VkyAHl1tIJ0vwhwNXbyfZx6viOYJIEZWFKbMgH4ZKoHnh8uVxA8EdS4vl~1ulDRZG3i5fHlHmNEvv7SxTyXIv6H4t~DQiAHzXmnsoeP2rf6weWHwUM3RR0NhkWWAeU3DreDO4rCc5aedNVS~sRtzXQ-Zh1SLbHPDGlL9ddvxoFItLv1hEM2t667Oa0Wxr8jzDsBRuM7oGyjjtDO-0QCzBFF2NrnH6jKDLwDFf1EmaSMsOPvijj5U4h6nCEIoT~BTQm5GkliGKGgPjAY2NkX9AJxZw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m4.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m5\" content-id=\"m5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m5.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m5.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=Aio5w~~p1zDH96yfoE1ljX1vGtG7y36nlMDHjfZdsHFMm4DCZ8ZthCc~kzbzQ5HDOMyi6RPdlUcspCJB6WJn3lHmhi9tnpwfKSmTOAImNEyibdWkDpS34pTBIH7C6p3SZ9oAI3V~FSxcrcWwxGYKkMxSnwvn0y4wS9c0g2rX84bULBRMUTzyt~kEVhBjxgJtAV-3NFjIBG~csSSFTRDLCApbs209cbc5mc63pnqFznwhZ53QjsLMG-d~bBsB8ytFEKGM3ftDYc412iweFVTKItuPrYvg2d9fmm8QSjaCJYoHmpFArUJBJia7KtOCSo0PKdo2sgyRk8MWi-AVTlaTJQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m5.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">5</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m6\" content-id=\"m6\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m6.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m6.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=xkuDZZeUjTpz1ozOa1qkC7nKdnL5eBG5TwqAFYDY~NwmVvz0o9rDUGHB5rAYVUGQUPvrtJEaDRakBKoVytgls55Z17mCXJk6hMbvXchV3JpK7E0rJXBNco0nVZlb0Czp4vhMqRK3KDwQ4efl-~~cQFeqNyH~dQ-4Ao-BT0POhPJeoJ7~GnAk8XMK~--5F-8bBG3ZYTZuRJqk9xEBm562z-rF8HV~ygUhBz3FfmUaYncPrdpwH~PXAPSIWfKVMR-lVHrx5V1bmhXyubeShxzMs3IUaDLLfzP~kk36qayM6OWOtfhb6UceG6Xp4s5E5nwmFo9~UBeynXRi81~VxTyDQQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m6.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">6</span></div><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a> shows the cut and resulting COSMOS photometric redshift distribution. It is seen that our cut efficiently selects galaxies at <em>z</em>\u2273 0.7, the redshifts higher than any cluster redshifts in our sample. In our weak lensing analysis, we also limit the range of <em>r</em>-band magnitude to 21 &lt; <em>r</em> &lt; <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub>, where the limiting magnitude <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub> is determined from the galaxy number counts of each cluster field image (see below).</div>                        <a id=\"16767817\" scrollto-destination=\"16767817\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=JZvQa6aZ7kjhZR8VwgdAS9RjivuDiS0GoTQxCauHjw5BIPxiA35-vAJgwAruMSnwSl6PhvzLZ05mAgtDWv7y9iTLD8USDFJx-i-Vm8UU7-nNzPDScwD7RRGsFUAGbj7qjd8759HSELOwkGrTfFV6Tzr4uIQz62N1TjP8tZ0xWSZrYU-wvYbkQpt0Q4ybPCxqZrsyrFJvGCbYwbv5NLcTIxGKtR0H5yR8DIpkbWBcOHFfDF8iuBe56nn0Nq9N-CVqInfh6RapNTpg8PuHHNN3SPyNKELvU~q8wB8oCNnH~mgoS63GWG~Uk7ZrqKk104a~hXacYHoXoTf7pjjy28EHhA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). The colour cut for red member galaxy selection is indicated by dotted lines. The four regions correspond to colour cuts for different cluster redshifts. Solid contours indicate galaxy number density in the COSMOS catalogue (i &lt; 25). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767817/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=vxeARjJWcepWmZlvoMQ7Vv7aehbevpLjfQWg0ntF0jngsLCFYDj6BC7l~VpSgDsAzTAtekshNTwmARNH~sk5BcjxgT6JfnRA6nI-IX2vnI6S8ekaCKIDGWZcaUfyr4dUves1YU~98D2LQs3pknRBKwYA7k3-SCG5sg~Saj9YoIufxZYR19UIfXEFR0LjmpVqGCUtwXoyiajNr1ASB8lziDRigKyISxP8rk0E5n607eRelWguDX7tvdyznYRYFS~m7q1FOH6BOij~XcjyX-~lSsC0u0bDdSPooelEjR4F~ABce2MM-fYGq9yR6eS~q28EqrRslPKy4AvJbUxBcZq6mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767817&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=JZvQa6aZ7kjhZR8VwgdAS9RjivuDiS0GoTQxCauHjw5BIPxiA35-vAJgwAruMSnwSl6PhvzLZ05mAgtDWv7y9iTLD8USDFJx-i-Vm8UU7-nNzPDScwD7RRGsFUAGbj7qjd8759HSELOwkGrTfFV6Tzr4uIQz62N1TjP8tZ0xWSZrYU-wvYbkQpt0Q4ybPCxqZrsyrFJvGCbYwbv5NLcTIxGKtR0H5yR8DIpkbWBcOHFfDF8iuBe56nn0Nq9N-CVqInfh6RapNTpg8PuHHNN3SPyNKELvU~q8wB8oCNnH~mgoS63GWG~Uk7ZrqKk104a~hXacYHoXoTf7pjjy28EHhA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767817/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767817\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=vxeARjJWcepWmZlvoMQ7Vv7aehbevpLjfQWg0ntF0jngsLCFYDj6BC7l~VpSgDsAzTAtekshNTwmARNH~sk5BcjxgT6JfnRA6nI-IX2vnI6S8ekaCKIDGWZcaUfyr4dUves1YU~98D2LQs3pknRBKwYA7k3-SCG5sg~Saj9YoIufxZYR19UIfXEFR0LjmpVqGCUtwXoyiajNr1ASB8lziDRigKyISxP8rk0E5n607eRelWguDX7tvdyznYRYFS~m7q1FOH6BOij~XcjyX-~lSsC0u0bDdSPooelEjR4F~ABce2MM-fYGq9yR6eS~q28EqrRslPKy4AvJbUxBcZq6mw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767817&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the colour cut selecting background galaxies for weak lensing analysis (shading). Lower: photometric redshift distributions of galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue, before (dotted) and after (solid) the colour cut.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In addition to background galaxies, we identify cluster (red) member galaxies by the following criteria:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m7\" content-id=\"m7\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m7.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m7.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=WzEE7LLu-1kX55vSIP0Oks0qJ~kYmxqWufAOOz3HuRiGqsBjH7TRGmAsMYK~qWsbSf2omcOhNlaPCPwLH44-Ih4eAHdeKh2bRtcjt6h~b82Gf7oXZxgrJF9DpXCREasoqipHigw17qphxyuOBiesCTQb7~VmBeL89ZEteSB~HXYnuHAT9J4Q~VveHnr7~dMUr5l~vbdo9oKG3UFXu1zjSZ0mGOzkVMK8kFNwJkR2SLfGaRudt9aXFaV2OTFUfYqz0Sp9GDFXKEm7e7wwSMeu~cRY9byGX~8VlAugRWTrD0uzRtZxzcxuOZXj6kjrstGZVms8UOUykRhW2NjkeLWZxw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m7.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">7</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m8\" content-id=\"m8\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m8.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m8.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=0FrsdgmJw8HrtJRovL0AvfCFfCx1jjN~KOGjMun7~OZqFXISyiyPPlqxsawXpk8GE1RKFts3nZ-1s69FRdFWp2Cok4CS~L-aA88ZmW7N8qoHtKuVfhz1DAOHq7~zzJ1NgoBdnu0LTKYbMSdqLHS76nfGLmdFVE6ykrSdgpt-N0lzGLWnY2ibGKO6Fi1GngXD-6Elm7Tvxr4AnqMCwwGc836hDdKnQR30~rsg4r3OX1jTA08X0Wun0ikwQf5ex3TgxASoPYNp1idXkhrQ8lPlRz4NbbBpU6uASsur8MKHoTj7VyArUcukI89GBNPQX~B8jv7Ja1oRkHq9flyJMx8afw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m8.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">8</span></div> with (<em>a</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>a</em><sub>2</sub>) are (1.5, \u22120.25) for <em>z</em> &lt; 0.35, (1.6, \u22120.22) for 0.35 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.45, (1.6, 0) for 0.45 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.55, and (1.7, 0.05) for 0.55 &lt; <em>z</em>. These cuts are also indicated by the upper panel of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a> shows the average radial number density distributions of galaxies, background, member, and field (i.e. galaxies which are neither background nor member) galaxies in our 28 cluster sample. As expected, the member galaxy density is steeply rising near the cluster. Field galaxies do not show strong dependence on the distance from the centre, as that should be dominated by local foreground galaxies. A slight increase at small radius suggests that some blue cluster member galaxies are included in the field galaxy sample. On the other hand, background galaxy density decreases near the centre, which is in fact expected because of the lensing magnification and dilution effect of clusters (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b131\" data-open=\"b131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011a</a>). These distributions basically support the successful colour cut for selecting background galaxies.</p>                        <a id=\"16767820\" scrollto-destination=\"16767820\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=vSCj2dV1Fx2IP1SgMh5vjEvgK1KKwWiqOBA8MTZ~ewzZBree0brn2OJtH5m5SAv1EaByfmnyCu38DsoVUtCWoxy4cSI7VegqM3VEqS26mu~onQQH4h~qJPjXck8Nqeji6xVJGqB~fwk0WGNzeWA7QVgcQ-Ac-mOGn7wCk5luixLb0QRuePqTyaoqreNRVe3stScdZoSNOwpsZTbZD8MK~k0CtB0YUu8dFiXHDsLvfuOSrh5Bdzo2z94lmqnlntTYh2NO1grI4gUAq10BD-uJt50E2M4i06cAmCMk2w0Ta4atgNnE34hk2Kyz6-C08HciYpdEuxgzspE8VN8aYwkffw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The radial number density distributions of galaxies, which are obtained by averaging distributions over all 28 clusters. We show distributions for background galaxies (open circles), cluster member galaxies (filled squares), and \u2018field\u2019 galaxies (filled triangles) that are simply defined as being neither member nor background galaxies. Note that the distributions are normalized by the overall number densities.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767820/mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767820\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=gPAemGVppBdONSBZcM4ml58TxEj9oJzL9d0ONCXtHoKDmdIZQ09ogYdbH0dnFS9Hhj01MMmcYYDleZ0lNXOl~Md4lfRVF4SBAH7jlj7VsLnvZjjo-TABrWO4w4NTnAauwzdMcN1QwaHiyPTFZPbpRyfnpob2AxzPC1ah9~a9Hlino6IuDEhP~rgsGCcw58GZNJtWlL-6W8Xe2jyvQOBunu3Ua0YMlOrgB4LeObxVPRFkIND7fbx3BHbrQmzZorYqVkYw~In16FybZtrssaRGLnDm0QRYpwni0E829vSWBJ19G4SxfkAWxfZ13DXKsOEZGaKjdtrTp~Qsvx-9DNVQXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767820&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The radial number density distributions of galaxies, which are obtained by averaging distributions over all 28 clusters. We show distributions for background galaxies (open circles), cluster member galaxies (filled squares), and \u2018field\u2019 galaxies (filled triangles) that are simply defined as being neither member nor background galaxies. Note that the distributions are normalized by the overall number densities.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=vSCj2dV1Fx2IP1SgMh5vjEvgK1KKwWiqOBA8MTZ~ewzZBree0brn2OJtH5m5SAv1EaByfmnyCu38DsoVUtCWoxy4cSI7VegqM3VEqS26mu~onQQH4h~qJPjXck8Nqeji6xVJGqB~fwk0WGNzeWA7QVgcQ-Ac-mOGn7wCk5luixLb0QRuePqTyaoqreNRVe3stScdZoSNOwpsZTbZD8MK~k0CtB0YUu8dFiXHDsLvfuOSrh5Bdzo2z94lmqnlntTYh2NO1grI4gUAq10BD-uJt50E2M4i06cAmCMk2w0Ta4atgNnE34hk2Kyz6-C08HciYpdEuxgzspE8VN8aYwkffw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The radial number density distributions of galaxies, which are obtained by averaging distributions over all 28 clusters. We show distributions for background galaxies (open circles), cluster member galaxies (filled squares), and \u2018field\u2019 galaxies (filled triangles) that are simply defined as being neither member nor background galaxies. Note that the distributions are normalized by the overall number densities.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767820/mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767820\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=gPAemGVppBdONSBZcM4ml58TxEj9oJzL9d0ONCXtHoKDmdIZQ09ogYdbH0dnFS9Hhj01MMmcYYDleZ0lNXOl~Md4lfRVF4SBAH7jlj7VsLnvZjjo-TABrWO4w4NTnAauwzdMcN1QwaHiyPTFZPbpRyfnpob2AxzPC1ah9~a9Hlino6IuDEhP~rgsGCcw58GZNJtWlL-6W8Xe2jyvQOBunu3Ua0YMlOrgB4LeObxVPRFkIND7fbx3BHbrQmzZorYqVkYw~In16FybZtrssaRGLnDm0QRYpwni0E829vSWBJ19G4SxfkAWxfZ13DXKsOEZGaKjdtrTp~Qsvx-9DNVQXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767820&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The radial number density distributions of galaxies, which are obtained by averaging distributions over all 28 clusters. We show distributions for background galaxies (open circles), cluster member galaxies (filled squares), and \u2018field\u2019 galaxies (filled triangles) that are simply defined as being neither member nor background galaxies. Note that the distributions are normalized by the overall number densities.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to extract physical quantities for clusters from weak lensing signals, we need an estimate of the lensing depth of our source galaxy sample. Again, the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue is useful for this purpose, but one problem is that many of our source galaxies are fainter than the magnitude limit of the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue. To overcome this problem, we adopt the following procedure to estimate the lensing depth. First, from the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ilbert et al. 2009</a>) we derive the response function for our colour cut as \u03c6<sub>cut</sub>(<em>z</em>) =<em>n</em><sub>cut</sub>(<em>z</em>)/<em>n</em><sub>tot</sub>(<em>z</em>), where <em>n</em><sub>tot</sub>(<em>z</em>) and <em>n</em><sub>cut</sub>(<em>z</em>) are photometric redshift distributions of galaxies before and after the colour cut, respectively. Our weak lensing analysis involves the statistical weight <em>w</em><sub>g</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m2\"></span><a href=\"#m2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 2</a>), and hence we compute the mean weight as a function of <em>i</em>-band magnitude as well, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu3.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=oRLyPciRPgSufB0efEB3smFbgIRfZ4ccnDwNjtkBEb-6e75grr~EzArntncBa4ml7eZgT~rkcx9p7rGdg4P30PVHoyVczMV6Ha5GmlzMF9jFaLRutyY2rJMP~xznrGna16M~uG30hQ8sghfIKNQrSlpxwlyWvNmVbyCPAqp6XCiUmxXGGO4Egb-AfPn7GmV9EhnJ93UTob9xYT8AAM4mX-RVpTwCKvJaVg~4f0ehI1UQSxnQGHlLFsryyykPBZOmumXyjdaln6Ek6kY9SoesFqEa3ioE~0XYnhUC2o~KxXavgYjBpvAX2l7kiW2wC0jVjhazrMWE1uO57M14AmJ~BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu3.gif\" />\u2060</span>, from the background galaxy catalogue. Next we derive the redshift distribution of galaxies as a function of the <em>i</em>-band magnitude as follows. First, we adopt the functional form proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b125\" data-open=\"b125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schrabback et al. (2010)</a>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m9\" content-id=\"m9\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m9.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m9.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=kDFvJn0xuvj7-lpwm4hStukZdcQpHLFDCybyDIkUyoYAt1IzC-7QnLppPobWHZuBMt~RWbBKoaUMSMUJ7o~V4HLBrGeOiMqSGygUULRVmMvOJZ5f-aeRjxLgECztIM0qD4Mes2BdeiL5lHZGy5BcEf3PoSDqk0j3XVxYXNTUGNotOfYjWVScWzmwOHFGyP230-DetCy9dJSmppsGYUq4L~8M1r772uctHBxRAvup~f7QKZ~22mKFZGIWPnmE9txAr0aaXlu40VSrKb8LxRrp1b5rBfzxaBEsA6M8CHtEFviQBFDAtZWQZPO7CZze11hN0FJBi623MmDZ2qy6cFUyrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m9.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">9</span></div> with <em>u</em>= max(0, <em>i</em>\u2212 23) and (\u03b1, \u03b2, <em>c</em>, <em>d</em>, \u03b3) = (0.678, 5.606, 0.581, 1.851, 1.464). We then recompute the mean galaxy redshift as a function of <em>i</em>-band magnitude for the range 17 &lt; <em>i</em> &lt; 25 using the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue. The result shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a> suggests that it is well approximated by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m10\" content-id=\"m10\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m10.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m10.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=XFuFVHq8QQdOfAtRLScqayHz8ojP8jO4I2RVx51pqVsnMwaUL8LAuZfLPdnZIW9-AwXrsr0yueMPFW7sTJxdP-Bs83uCLb16d-EB26LI-JM172nP-eE59zw9iqXCGOEG6LMBBgSZ11XRm~iYEnb4zyG8OD~v8nvZMerk36HkGGWT~h82NfKSO1atINE6u8arIr8geGCPnh7IVaKyKizk-L9fzkOs~jAfeWSerU8fDAdqSddnpEv6Gzdu~A98V3sXt1i-klhF74BZelfriawHd3NEZoHbtWJ6qGd1jX23zPD-6Bqu0CqH-yuq~oiDCIlFI0RF~9IPyQR8VpqL7iviPQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m10.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">10</span></div> We extrapolate this linear relation to a fainter magnitude of <em>i</em> &gt; 25, because <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b125\" data-open=\"b125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schrabback et al. (2010)</a> have explicitly shown that such extrapolation can explain the redshift distribution of galaxies reasonably well down to <em>i</em>\u223c 27. Using this relation, we derive the relation between <em>z</em><sub>0</sub> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m9\"></span><a href=\"#m9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (9)</a> and <em>i</em>-band magnitude, which is approximated by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m11\" content-id=\"m11\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m11.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m11.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=SJMdQ-Q7QwyMuxowb8wFUqnj7sB-PvQvg0J6M~Hc37Q2EcPUP8Bde~sukMCH-U4qlmsXBi1kMQjAF9LdlxWVDZbr1lmFajTJFeVAad~5Ki72~kAbxhegZHFERDtOapQWbQrXMXVuDvE8kr~A52FdX1JaBtwtkOeacXfW4S~cfvR4qhLuMIBksqao8UPXH6xY5gG0pQX8D~-UDc-HumkByNlMnCVLeX1i2dyVjE~fy-cXHVYSW5Cuu7djJJraekG~Hw8rq1paPVvf6IXuiFprPP9OYT6mRf1k-q4beFIpvl5k4bmluOBFHbxokVMewzMlzMvDIzTkFU2x1uAMZN1V5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m11.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">11</span></div> Using this redshift distribution, we derive the mean depth as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m12\" content-id=\"m12\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m12.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m12.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=KRPg6W9dA-q~QQ7N8fYg1J2nzCESOgHzgnyLeBezDxmZqmZ~rt3mVVWaMznMk5uxktRcsrvqzJ1vwVKfSAl4Xi0V4da1KnSaCzlyeZkyozqUYDFSG5x7zC8wl7WJelR3I-IahFkRWDTW-QbwPuciIoO6Jy3OqxpXp7OdpwOMfWe2qh0SxQadFc8XBDInj~h8uf0F5hoKctUmB5nPYPcPTgA0vJOECaTmR2liu3ShoqQtK3UhGk1f8yKaJY9OaiFTHWZ4hatqsttyI3Zafqk~rNiVX2p4JlXXz-P9zozUwmPMGWzpa8bOt~2vooB~h-UkoUZKDp9Qh7FbEhKj5UZoBQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m12.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">12</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m13\" content-id=\"m13\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m13.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m13.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=m1kAuTzUwQ9LHposc8EzUlAUmKYkRmn5zO4Vitw~ktNFmbrX6jTjsZ-GUtndFSTemNrkOVozM8aADgOwCVbcsies~ab-926byrt5O9-x5Omjyvu8-2ApXkYIKw~-F8~HS-uLb7ccp0Rh7Bd4J4TO3rqqZ7yhVjOJSfcQVYFqq2dxfMvdMk2bvfMqs-zf5s4apCdVXua-6CPi4-yJfsrgYAo1Edgg1gnE4gkmdKPRr0-4I4eOBC5No5T8AEx8jAciIwypGJMXtV2begkEP2G0MEdEYhwO2X8R73f71bJXK2KFWtsimWBpRsFSmgeQZBpGlxKbQByJ3F9DtAvi5LMkAg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m13.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">13</span></div> where d<em>N</em>/d<em>i</em> are the <em>i</em>-band number counts of background galaxies used for weak lensing analysis. We define the effective source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s, eff</sub> such that it reproduces the mean depth:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m14\" content-id=\"m14\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m14.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m14.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=Shjb~4IOiSUsdA41PXwG4YPci12mfSIU6DMsiV6qX8ip40YTvX8TxQgBeKGiWDwsLnY~O5wWm1OZqHPWKQFxj54-JePOaKuPgHnv58E7lrJa9eO799QzHs9Xzja6HLqVWKy~kIASo0WGzo1idS26U-LVBpqXSuEUTdpIhk1LMLjqaMdnLM3tlQLMKTrJ6zpYYNWOIVyKvok6CsyPrmbYc-HpBlWlIK9AO6uV1q6U55h~RdSK7YnHNm0vdTZy-IKbFJFfKbKFN5~100VtlxAKANTBwQquxGH6N8U90B0yWoiBbR1AV3h3XHqpxqAJYuQsPrZLyH67gRPa8T6bRSGSRg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m14.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">14</span></div> Throughout this paper, we assume that all the galaxies are located at <em>z</em><sub>s, eff</sub> for our weak lensing analysis.</div>                        <a id=\"16767822\" scrollto-destination=\"16767822\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=GscIsQSpGTsFG7CXd136Hj858Z~~yfdNIrAGp2Dd1y3e0Y8iqT99X8oA3b9FUI8HWXXSagMsTDmSBBgX1QloovYgX-WG~KFodc4ptCIMK7ITabNzkct66qHzehrRB~fqFrstN5t-6JVUC4Qk55ze-QGjMUUrIsBsKarj5uvD~iprAlF9uf5GQeVL236hQVb-x4qNl2jP17jJNH-QqhVKjQP9QUXuLweJg2GarMdVPNLPYpTo8jJHRE8XqwNJeHP5aD9nllzT2ziOfrW-gIlt72Exz6MPGrOqugZ4Gg~czf9wIvxYXt49tC6xaFkKYCoBujTxza-9XOu9jbLOsyaNuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean galaxy redshift as a function of i-band magnitude, which is derived from the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue (Ilbert et al. 2009). The solid line plots our fit given by equation (10).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767822/mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767822\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=LXtnUlVR5-GOvMJPudzQsm1P7YIOv9~M5slHp4W~1F370sFk52bFnNynCnpNaHn7Pw3LBUOIdTvyJPYi-21XoLaXCbRuBDLNL-h3FQEKnM7hkKBPv70DzaO9C3U8F~wHxpUwamMsSBvyZIQkZQO8LJAcA0UrDd6fxdej0uZyFBpove2fNwbuApw6qRlivWqUDSTDsO4EFzEGlnJn8VNRDVBmBBPfykoK9OrwAEB1uiMX70syVOH8qfFdh9jtqzEHy9u8s-AqO7ep51MRxklJX7himMEQRvRuQrZC5fTyMx~LkJNdwMqK3gZBeQnAxMAyK~KckmNi3sZcnhRjiiSEFQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767822&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mean galaxy redshift as a function of <em>i</em>-band magnitude, which is derived from the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ilbert et al. 2009</a>). The solid line plots our fit given by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m10\"></span><a href=\"#m10\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (10)</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=GscIsQSpGTsFG7CXd136Hj858Z~~yfdNIrAGp2Dd1y3e0Y8iqT99X8oA3b9FUI8HWXXSagMsTDmSBBgX1QloovYgX-WG~KFodc4ptCIMK7ITabNzkct66qHzehrRB~fqFrstN5t-6JVUC4Qk55ze-QGjMUUrIsBsKarj5uvD~iprAlF9uf5GQeVL236hQVb-x4qNl2jP17jJNH-QqhVKjQP9QUXuLweJg2GarMdVPNLPYpTo8jJHRE8XqwNJeHP5aD9nllzT2ziOfrW-gIlt72Exz6MPGrOqugZ4Gg~czf9wIvxYXt49tC6xaFkKYCoBujTxza-9XOu9jbLOsyaNuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mean galaxy redshift as a function of i-band magnitude, which is derived from the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue (Ilbert et al. 2009). The solid line plots our fit given by equation (10).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767822/mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767822\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265595&Signature=LXtnUlVR5-GOvMJPudzQsm1P7YIOv9~M5slHp4W~1F370sFk52bFnNynCnpNaHn7Pw3LBUOIdTvyJPYi-21XoLaXCbRuBDLNL-h3FQEKnM7hkKBPv70DzaO9C3U8F~wHxpUwamMsSBvyZIQkZQO8LJAcA0UrDd6fxdej0uZyFBpove2fNwbuApw6qRlivWqUDSTDsO4EFzEGlnJn8VNRDVBmBBPfykoK9OrwAEB1uiMX70syVOH8qfFdh9jtqzEHy9u8s-AqO7ep51MRxklJX7himMEQRvRuQrZC5fTyMx~LkJNdwMqK3gZBeQnAxMAyK~KckmNi3sZcnhRjiiSEFQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767822&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mean galaxy redshift as a function of <em>i</em>-band magnitude, which is derived from the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ilbert et al. 2009</a>). The solid line plots our fit given by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m10\"></span><a href=\"#m10\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (10)</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The depth estimate above can be affected by the lensing magnification, because the magnification enhances the effective lensing depth. However, the magnification factor tends to decrease rapidly beyond the Einstein radius such that a typical magnification factor of the innermost radial bin for our weak lensing analysis is \u223c20 per cent or so. This corresponds to the enhancement of the shear amplitude of \u223c5 per cent, which is not significant compared with other uncertainties. Moreover, the effect is much smaller at radii where weak lensing signals mostly come from. Thus we conclude that the magnification effect is insignificant for our analysis. Photometric errors that become larger for fainter galaxies can smear the distribution in the colour\u2013colour space, and hence can affect the lensing depth estimate, but photometric errors are included in the COSMOS photometric redshift catalogue as well. Photometric errors for the faintest galaxies in our weak lensing analysis are similar to those for the faintest galaxies in the COSMOS catalogue. Another possible systematic effect is the size cut, which may systematically eliminate galaxies at high redshifts and hence bias the lensing depth estimate. While we expect the effect to be small because of the conservative magnitude limit we adopt and the narrow redshift distribution after the colour cut, we leave the detailed exploration of this effect for future work.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a> summarizes our weak lensing analysis. It is seen that our PSF correction algorithm successfully reduces the stellar ellipticities to the level that is much smaller than typical lensing shear amplitudes for our cluster sample (\u03b3\u2273 0.01). The relatively small number density of <em>n</em><sub>g</sub>\u223c 10\u2003arcmin<sup>\u22122</sup> is due to the colour cut for selecting background galaxies. From the shear catalogues we compute tangential shear profiles. The tangential shear <em>g</em><sub>+</sub> is computed from the reduced shear <strong><em>g</em></strong>= (<em>g</em><sub>1</sub>, \u2003<em>g</em><sub>2</sub>) as<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m15\" content-id=\"m15\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m15.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m15.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=WVFsG9pQITVp1lfUHaXk78soOVV7o-hstgpoP3BvZjY-pLZIrvrIJgLJs7WLB656MFCNv4iP0X8w~aP0Xb89xizurWXLfToUhl02NkR3Jd-dFslQ4m7CaGY~DA4AOSkg6rtUiH1oZTRQ1iVLeohP156bAfOto8r5gaf0WooiHc1X9HW7S8tbdIqs~Ka-ljrw63fyCNNv-QEMPIf7vaYCpJiU4Gvtd0qCIlnCQVlCRM2Sk4MIGsklKHjo14BXIHrMoToghX4RwPpQ57mCF1xyaJ78y97weyYDPNb6a1N4JBqz1fyztL5Zt68RRrX8lgFUOKY80Oq3~QWvGl96PhoyWA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m15.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">15</span></div> where \u03c6 is the polar angle. Throughout the paper, we assume that the position of the brightest galaxy in the strong lensing region is coincident with the cluster centre. Although our strong lensing analysis suggests that the position of the mass peak can differ slightly from the central galaxy position, we find that any such offset is much smaller than the typical inner radial boundary of our weak lensing analysis. Hence the effect of off-centring on our results should be negligibly small. The average shear value in each radial bin is estimated by the weighted mean of the tangential shear as follows:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m16\" content-id=\"m16\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m16.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m16.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=FZO7ugmXikrnY7ZAZiP4MU~SXJMVC1Ab-9C7OPYcaujCONWTaQP-zDjVT~f1h2-0Q4pSmM2BPwvrhkzfcFQoMpQ-fq3l0BqmESR6Ou6ru1QqKI5kFRNxqPn9fd2fRPT8TOlCnr3cFoBt4djhG1rF2F5~8oTPIvHExRsZ2~m~Ytav~ys6smDHIcodph-zXfjzzLUh0RtgJH5mHqz9dBmIRRCR1utg1qkqxp8PemZrsesafULNVGO6dmz2O4-KU0QSYiU6JwVFCsuoJmhha35s2sHux8J-fzQK6CYXFzU~iOn3bULRISVEF9ZjlJqX2r8tjPV5LJT8Wm~S6YJqAAKOvg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m16.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">16</span></div> where the summation runs over all galaxies in the bin. Similarly the statistical error in the tangential shear measurement in each bin is computed from the weighted average of the variance of the shear, \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>g</sub> (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>). The total signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) of the tangential shear profile is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a> and indicates that weak lensing signals are detected significantly (S/N &gt; <em>rsim</em> 5) for most of our clusters. The mass maps reconstructed from the weak lensing analysis are shown in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>.</div>                        <a id=\"16767825\" scrollto-destination=\"16767825\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t3\" data-id=\"t3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the weak lensing analysis. We show the median of stellar ellipticities before (<em>e</em>*<sub>raw</sub>) and after (<em>e</em>*<sub>cor</sub>) the PSF correction (numbers in parentheses are standard deviations), the number of stars used for the PSF correction (<em>N</em>*), the number density of source background galaxies (<em>n</em><sub>g</sub>), the <em>r</em>-band magnitude limit of source background galaxies (<em>r</em><sub>lim</sub>), the mean lensing depth (\u3008<em>D</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>D</em><sub>os</sub>\u3009) and the effective source redshift (<em>z</em><sub>s, eff</sub>), the range of the radii for tangential shear fitting (\u03b8 range), and the total S/N of the tangential shear profile.</p></div> </div><div We show the median of stellar ellipticities before (<em>e</em>*<sub>raw</sub>) and after (<em>e</em>*<sub>cor</sub>) the PSF correction (numbers in parentheses are standard deviations), the number of stars used for the PSF correction (<em>N</em>*), the number density of source background galaxies (<em>n</em><sub>g</sub>), the <em>r</em>-band magnitude limit of source background galaxies
