      </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767826 id=\"16767826\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4\u2002COMBINING STRONG AND WEAK LENSING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767827 id=\"16767827\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1\u2002Methodology</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We combine constraints from the tangential shear profile with constraints from strong lensing. As in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>, we combine both sets of constraints by summing up \u03c7<sup>2</sup>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m17\" content-id=\"m17\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m17.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m17.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=l8Km9SO6-DkcoWfRtsLKs-CCsHG9SaNXP04gIgCrwqF0M-lQTISLC3F4d7r7PnuX8AVPveUcCOwvH0Rs~z1nhdJRFOBh2l9jhkN5F-HUu8XUilCjwbREvoJwpJ9YDP63Xmn1xAlkkY0b~WMXX-4jwjI0EWmZER0j0tXNKtHDI5u~AvVb4E~3cp~AWnrYTJd2e0Gzr4XL-28foCtF49eXServEeMY9s7X4nJ1b4LsobFgru6EUl8ltQ1AbBCquatKHPfQS5lCLblpgJW1yKrt~AVCaiA~n4S7Y9n0f7hKrlHmhtqsfIJJcO~EKFKRqlKcbVzmdek4twhLUgGRXLhsXQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m17.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">17</span></div> We include strong lensing constraints from the Einstein radius at the arc redshift:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m18\" content-id=\"m18\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m18.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m18.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=a0z-XiWUa3yr6RMfN-0xOGSFSgDS1Yuoicyyn58SJuMuaGHkMDYBF7LVosamMP7cb1C60egxMEtMulw2rWeTcLMLVltcPUVIczIw2LVYH8nlWBjNMeekigNHqBGzZWTXN51GprtE1dP4KdKc9ClzASXXOWkSw6JVX39KZcvBRgUNFfwS5iE2SOWqchVJAQpa21mFj-FhKRVvRn3uBZSRqvwMc2Fl5kgCOrbDU2MdQ8u4ijIa53rANoaXNuK821tgUutIQVQL~Fqg~RgqalpSAkfGO7Mp~Xkzmx9ing2Vz5zjjZW0c0dESRVL17UkDPHQ-kPtqnEBMMIUYVAvuYvOYA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m18.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">18</span></div> where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=gmY8cHe6i6xGjhjUL2iZ9Dagi1yMzwlPySjfxDyE8L2yf2fLaHp9GCc3rZcK-l3lDbmR~FZREAU-x-JSNua4JAeIKYKUVoDMuQMQpTdst-qyens2FjHW40qq6xZ9fOBUXaMplganN89fykkLkXKysw6rcQMZ6yAKxkN0mnGWqskH1PYX1ePTtW5T5O7jsyQgsT3yHT1SYS4C~hhMmBlPEFuuT84q3evp5X6I6f9ijillh9PJusMo2dkwKxB2UEJEsm7mqvnZ-KMwjnWdzTP~p5vYuGFSit3V4jMZxTna6qIsnsSkHpWIXTCFmaJCsiV9tu9AMtV7bEZucXTmXreU1Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu4.gif\" /></span> and \u03c3<sub>E</sub> are the best-fitting Einstein radius at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>=<em>z</em><sub>arc</sub> and its error presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>, and \u03b8<sub>E</sub>(<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>,\u2003<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>) is the predicted Einstein radius assuming the NFW profile. On the other hand, weak lensing constraints come from binned tangential shear measurements:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m19\" content-id=\"m19\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m19.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m19.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=pVxIJ8ip7urp8o2OWJcT9ian0shouQZicpyYgCXeWOHIL0XWNG~VcoEG~dn3IRb6GcUGAnb3CsfB8XKqIGR27hG~NmOZ0y28Wj1c5PTnqjxlqjXwQOnvLIFvjHnOTlqRrWgALcOMX-vUEq5zmN3K6-EDSiOu2cqSAgwbLsoptqe0-awOu96nDf-lXJKKN3ifrQ6p5LlB2pDCrgO7afCRiyEr1duQZqRFu7Vl1QacqcZOPJeZ1rVX6XSB3moxfmC1DSmqTEuBJMT98labRcwGm0RDdze4TgRGakUl8junRLUHJb39-ndwUYaZfVy~Sj6sBk6Tgl51M4Lk~RBXtdcktg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m19.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">19</span></div> where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=JFIVPKZvsD3hfAQ9TqFZacF7xA0Sd~jFXmFM2fDBDASsqZJL4tDI2DYs4KKSVG2fF7sMEiwPejcx5rr5XPDSg2Xo34FvworkzU39Uep~zcvGIkus18pIKdpJXQHP9tj-Ek1rODUpquFD517tful7WdUxEkYEcCvFQS6oDSffNmmmaA-4Bbyx8t0zCSob3yAE64jPZPX~udyOcRVe-NKr~oj0FS8i3I2lgNcW84M6BIFypqQE3pdG352UfHCpVpnPcxK8wKmK0glNIfVz~sHTN4G-my0u9RjMeqPeQhGq-6lgWyzQy8cetQfDpCmdSMnYfyeXuQG6jYfT8EhmLKz2wA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu5.gif\" /></span> and \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> are observed reduced shear and its error at <em>i</em>th radial bin, and \u2212<em>g</em><sub>+</sub>(\u03b8<sub><em>i</em></sub>;\u2003<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>,\u2003<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>) is the predicted reduced shear by the NFW model. The NFW profile, which we adopt as an analytical model for the radial mass distribution, has the 3D density profile of<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m20\" content-id=\"m20\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m20.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m20.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=k2~XCa~Ky1KRJjGg42gJFjHVPPVxenjWdkaTLfBu20x7xKz8aeYDAeqczavfJm9EsUhvsejQkefYYLguIaNSdIoqm6dZGV2RdizMzlmGg-GpVRYfz1eKjsMlG6LpJrCReh8XxZXgCgMhDAsmyhaNPtBuLYVIVEetfoo73HsflvzonvC-pC4ETsSMFqUwymt5XAcWBMpVth-y9NMd0Aas~3XqWEF-8WYf-eCNX2HLrLmhSLRtBta2jhlWUFNjyju1b8vItG5HKpGh0QQj-el1JpwA2QPIZoQixxeKN62r~kXxKRpBi8yTO1dyBJ56haY2tyVIb923LOQ7bo76FrGvwA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m20.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">20</span></div> where<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m21\" content-id=\"m21\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m21.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m21.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=Clp2SLFDgmRz44csTrOJIU8Pl1Ux3ti6XiZtm0OVHcoGP4E--qdPy0U~DltbwRtQ0iflMnqb6D-73losRjfKSuDra08vFIocD~evjWrqGqE0Yi04vwUb8JISi7Od3dmrBIL1m1a9-yKDAlsBEa3MORJSDiep7ta0uJ82ZxuUhI7pkH0pzIzT8~-ufDODV-lB70bkrGUMAU-7rjLfn8PcY~QYf7k1wI3yiaV41YwZbDATgnEVIgS-ne4391GEkl9peiX0a8C8cqQQ-R1~XoOmcYK7PVbZzbgM2odn9X-g60u3FBl-Zj3YWIxGxO5Nk~f6dIfN9x53PlmavDsTZRny7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m21.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">21</span></div> where \u0394(<em>z</em>) is the non-linear overdensity predicted by the spherical collapse model. We parametrize the profile with two parameters, the virial mass <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m22\" content-id=\"m22\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m22.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m22.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=pxeI4-f9-5I5bk1KXx7phrs4dDsxvv3lgJgdpWQcFuqtL6G2EfupyQEvqjXIYuCYU1GKqXgHj69ROc3TGuD1gymWWxenI8tLKQHv23FHg11GCjCsFKirYKxmQJp3LU286tcnuK4rioEGTcBH3A7TAAR1EtWKJEwMY2pr~3L3zmvIoW2pIxaEdChOND0ICf2jSM~YSO1n~IlEDd8vkth-kbzwF4lwshB8lSkC5e0COw1R8zHNVrecr-Y0zMmyIGpK5asw11ExEfuNg-3mBmvnNZ3W8krkmiOQZLlIsmiADv4u3x4z4c7Tuc5eaQMi6~3I1wjnnUC4d5kaGYaXorBsCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m22.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">22</span></div> and the concentration parameter <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m23\" content-id=\"m23\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m23.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m23.gif?Expires=1639265595&amp;Signature=uiADQ2PaeCRS3Hw5~GomgioIo~wX5u1HgF6r4LbXLl~qoCHPTEnTQQzDecGIMpuS8DIxnW3K7aDg0GYNed40jmMr0RUNkHifMt9UXh3PgGYrb1Ziw1SOaApSVnRZAbEPnnYiLgbOpvD1aTdUDP6ZUuOpuKGYAjD4vLLfRg34BRkR0~Ne78qXTHrNbPOtnpZwgso4WbwQ0sKG-BwQ4icL0sBlcMWjpPDP-RTXCwCxCcPgHWs8dpKzRNbZ4qwBxDWwjZqa8X6MsBjL9ZuR-Bsu-0kFK2dVv0nGaDcrosGOwMsEShzyYYy6a6dN5-NAm6kkK-AuHsnn9eEjFjYiUUPHhg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m23.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">23</span></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767829 id=\"16767829\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2\u2002Correlation between strong and weak lensing observables</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Before deriving best-fitting parameters for individual clusters, we first compare strong and weak lensing observables, namely the Einstein radius and the virial mass, which should serve as a sanity check for results of more detailed analysis presented in the following sections. For the strong lensing observable, we use the Einstein radius for the fixed source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2 in order to compare results for different clusters. Given the strong degeneracy between <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> in weak lensing analysis, we quantify the strength of the weak lensing signal by fitting the tangential shear profile for a fixed concentration parameter of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6, a typical value for the concentration when the lensing selection effect is taken into account (see below). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a> shows the correlation between the Einstein radius from strong lensing and the virial mass from weak lensing. We confirm that these two measurements are indeed correlated with each other such that the more massive clusters detected via their weak lensing have larger Einstein radii on average.</p>                        <a id=\"16767831\" scrollto-destination=\"16767831\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=G0OSPAeYLTkMGpad0~rzXurZSkCHzvaiiOfM5AuK2LdRKPfJ1DcC7Gu8roDb3ZrGkdV4IFb6LW~beuTKS8hbELVMBLqgPP-1Xwtqv1fsaKe~a9o6WCIYhtkx72lLFqmUKzf8qFgBnfviGZP2qmb8hRli7eVmeQ2VVd2uR50i9PP0BAytrN0lEAZUVMV5004j4lQo9pjuXwEd-6VBoGLgaWdUo9rQgYV6psmQT-P~CzdesAZN764h1w4xKDhhrVWSBOPkFsUubLkWfGQhLvjNwLslB1p7LKArHdwhZ8r-4~PPcCfrAGVkuRI2WuMZ8m1a96FbyhBl96HkPCUqzBg1sg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Correlation between strong and weak lensing observables. The best-fitting mass Mvir for a fixed concentration of cvir= 6 from just weak lensing is compared with the Einstein radius for the source redshift zs= 2 from strong lensing. The red line with shading shows the expected Mvir\u2013\u03b8E relation assuming the NFW profile with the concentration of cvir= 6 \u00b1 2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767831/mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767831\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=GgRvgDz2Rzvs3HvFYFFgRUvcOvpwi4yeLvsA2vVW5xvlgZ8BK6-Tp-YiO5KS~4ZLg2Fi~VusaGb3zJ~W40FEn4rGIgwsL-OQtUJ4tVywAq~A3EnUsXsxois-bS0XVaLEjbq8WQKEZ2KcNK9hkFbZt-1uABbJ5sWmy5hz78RkKZQBJXfpBuFwy4fCWVNjx3n3DN77noTzUBhyRIzUySXAlCL7WPPBa6JPaia5iRuSA5yVwJ9LadQBsj9qO0WbqOUSITJtqy4zdCKtZc-k9cj0SFL5Tq~6q6j3nPNRSGCwjvOIcLM2l4oGgqcyt3TKu2toEageVlu-K6XGyjzpO1YvLg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767831&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Correlation between strong and weak lensing observables. The best-fitting mass <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> for a fixed concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6 from just weak lensing is compared with the Einstein radius for the source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2 from strong lensing. The red line with shading shows the expected <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u2013\u03b8<sub>E</sub> relation assuming the NFW profile with the concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6 \u00b1 2.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=G0OSPAeYLTkMGpad0~rzXurZSkCHzvaiiOfM5AuK2LdRKPfJ1DcC7Gu8roDb3ZrGkdV4IFb6LW~beuTKS8hbELVMBLqgPP-1Xwtqv1fsaKe~a9o6WCIYhtkx72lLFqmUKzf8qFgBnfviGZP2qmb8hRli7eVmeQ2VVd2uR50i9PP0BAytrN0lEAZUVMV5004j4lQo9pjuXwEd-6VBoGLgaWdUo9rQgYV6psmQT-P~CzdesAZN764h1w4xKDhhrVWSBOPkFsUubLkWfGQhLvjNwLslB1p7LKArHdwhZ8r-4~PPcCfrAGVkuRI2WuMZ8m1a96FbyhBl96HkPCUqzBg1sg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Correlation between strong and weak lensing observables. The best-fitting mass Mvir for a fixed concentration of cvir= 6 from just weak lensing is compared with the Einstein radius for the source redshift zs= 2 from strong lensing. The red line with shading shows the expected Mvir\u2013\u03b8E relation assuming the NFW profile with the concentration of cvir= 6 \u00b1 2.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767831/mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767831\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=GgRvgDz2Rzvs3HvFYFFgRUvcOvpwi4yeLvsA2vVW5xvlgZ8BK6-Tp-YiO5KS~4ZLg2Fi~VusaGb3zJ~W40FEn4rGIgwsL-OQtUJ4tVywAq~A3EnUsXsxois-bS0XVaLEjbq8WQKEZ2KcNK9hkFbZt-1uABbJ5sWmy5hz78RkKZQBJXfpBuFwy4fCWVNjx3n3DN77noTzUBhyRIzUySXAlCL7WPPBa6JPaia5iRuSA5yVwJ9LadQBsj9qO0WbqOUSITJtqy4zdCKtZc-k9cj0SFL5Tq~6q6j3nPNRSGCwjvOIcLM2l4oGgqcyt3TKu2toEageVlu-K6XGyjzpO1YvLg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767831&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Correlation between strong and weak lensing observables. The best-fitting mass <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> for a fixed concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6 from just weak lensing is compared with the Einstein radius for the source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2 from strong lensing. The red line with shading shows the expected <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u2013\u03b8<sub>E</sub> relation assuming the NFW profile with the concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6 \u00b1 2.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming the NFW profile, the relation between mass and Einstein radius is determined by the concentration parameter. We also plot the expected correlation for the concentration assuming <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6, as well as the scatter of the relation originating from the shift of the concentration by \u00b12, for the lens redshift <em>z</em>= 0.46 which corresponds to the median redshift of our cluster sample. We find that the observed correlation roughly follows the expectation for <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 6, although there is a tendency for the Einstein radii to be larger than expected, particularly for low-mass clusters. This analysis suggests that our sample of clusters are slightly more concentrated than <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 6, and that clusters with lower masses on average have higher concentration values.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767833 id=\"16767833\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-3>4.3\u2002Fitting results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a> summarizes the results of the combined analysis, i.e. simultaneous fitting of the observed Einstein radius and tangential shear profile with the NFW model predictions. The tangential shear profiles for individual clusters are compared with best-fitting models in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss12\"></span><a href=\"#ss12\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">B</a>. Fitting is performed in the parameter range 10<sup>13</sup> &lt; <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> &lt; 10<sup>16</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> and 0.01 &lt; <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> &lt; 39.81. For four clusters studied previously in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>, our new results are fully consistent with the old result. In addition, the best-fitting mass and concentration parameter for A1703 are in good agreement with the result of an independent strong and weak lensing analysis by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b138\" data-open=\"b138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2010)</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767835\" scrollto-destination=\"16767835\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t4\" data-id=\"t4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraints on the mass <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and concentration parameter <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> from weak lensing and combined strong and weak lensing analysis. Errors indicate 1\u03c3 errors on each parameter after marginalizing over the other parameter.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td rowspan=\"2\">Name\u00a0</td><td tr><tr><td>SDSS\u2003J2111\u22120114\u00a0</td><td>2.2/7\u00a0</td><td>6.03<sup>+2.58</sup><sub>\u22122.14</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.91<sup>+1.68</sup><sub>\u22121.01</sub>\u00a0</td><td>3.76<sup>+1.31</sup><sub>\u22121.25</sub>\u00a0</td><td>6.0/8\u00a0</td><td>5.25<sup>+2.43</sup><sub>\u22121.94</sub>\u00a0</td><td>4.79<sup>+3.16</sup><sub>\u22121.62</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767835\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">With a large sample of clusters with measurements of the concentration parameter from combined strong and weak lensing, we can study the mass\u2013concentration relation quite well. A caveat is that our sample of clusters are selected as those having prominent arcs. It has been noted that clusters selected by strong lensing (e.g. by giant arcs or large Einstein radii) represent a strongly biased population such that the concentration parameter inferred from the projected mass distribution is on average much larger mostly due to the halo triaxiality (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2010</a>). Although in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a> we assumed the constant enhancement of the concentration parameter due to the lensing bias, simple considerations suggest that the lensing bias of the mass\u2013concentration relation should depend strongly on the mass. To derive more accurate theoretical predictions based on the \u039bCDM model, in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> we conduct a series of semi-analytic calculations with ray-tracing of extended sources to estimate the effect of the lensing bias, based on a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. For reference, we find that the mean mass\u2013concentration relation at <em>z</em>= 0.45 with the lensing bias predicted by this model is roughly described by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m24\" content-id=\"m24\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m24.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m24.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=PLApHEdPt1Z4b5OL51e-R8B~aOMH~5EFGX2RE5LBDGPsc-1m7Wt2cmhfpa5hRf6C5flunfkQ3e6G4VoN78QB~Q2~9PcpmNZDDmYnGdATh5MjDIezukQGIPJFdiPe9cM1n81Iz51dxb-3qwW2NbNSVidvao94KvOGeCcnpoJ-zN3mQLhHvN~po8iu1l7ec1REl~olW6DRZLYmLUeQSPH5u~xlNc1aLG~zCbhY-mHWqHxso3JSRJQ3xyTfXBH8hCMt4vZT3Yferb-i0pMHiJgH4U1QW~JY5AwuZhhr5FZ51HU~FeNHHPQduLWZf8zQZQRXeLps7jxgkcMifBOgyq53kw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m24.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">24</span></div> which shows relatively strong dependence on the halo mass, simply because of the mass dependence of the lensing bias (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>). The scatter of the relation is estimated to be \u03c3<sub>log\u2003<em>c</em></sub>\u2243 0.12.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a> shows the mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from our lensing analysis for 28 systems. For comparison, we also show accurate lensing measurements of the concentration parameters for five massive clusters from the literature (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b140\" data-open=\"b140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011b</a>). The figure clearly indicates that measured concentrations are correlated well with the mass. More massive clusters have on average smaller concentrations, which is consistent with the theoretical expectation, although the slope is obviously much steeper.</p>                        <a id=\"16767838\" scrollto-destination=\"16767838\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=2sEOqAwwY29lnVu6bcikGCMOCXz4fGAS3S2gbTE1ZmuejYgCATpk4Rt1GDoqUR9jQec3sfxutY84UOHwGd2KcqmAnL9Zlkscg8~mi8bxcAqUWni1IheS-AB40NazEZvQn8aoZNHpp238Q~bH6ge2BYr45MM8IKsqyCuPkNgP-z~-W~e64O0syv76VIC9RZTQKxkOL8BOna9zqAyOVs2P~cb4OPHihX0kHlboSCuT-r5B-8SChscRkCf8mm6zkq2NyYYRY4qj~AXDL5JiabTOfA~jtsL7tcWfuWIg8ihhV6JexuZkCfyGlkwRgxDIBR6QoAubz-KUlI2IyDi24u6YSg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from combined strong and weak lensing analysis. Filled triangles show our results presented in this paper, whereas filled squares show results from literature; A1689, A370, CL0024, RX\u2003J1347 (Umetsu et al. 2011b) and A383 (Zitrin et al. 2011b). The black shaded region indicates the predicted concentration parameters as a function of the halo mass with the lensing bias taken into account (see Appendix A, for details). The solid line is the best-fitting mass\u2013concentration relation from fitting of our cluster sample (i.e. filled triangles), with the 1\u03c3 range indicated by dotted lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767838/mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767838\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=ICLO5N6LmeCESFiCBk-zdYfocFj4ESdb5vS8sVL-CI30PyvSJG49gmEXNdUx6HixnwN9fKPq3Yu3iBIf7vY5oPTeXWSCwxvY0gUpaWRveOZl5ZBev7me99pUsd~N38Oax2T02GHq~ywfxTq~GuI92CgoU~2Ck9LT3oPZbZwtDS0~LnGpqXuC1cn7tKPe84wZFwFshZtRtggcwi5uqKc0G~rVbAVqUG0j2dWmaFNPC81PYMsZ-AMCBppEcaBgAuL23e8C1YUE2bd2qbLsThOUErxDWPlKi-IknElweL3YndiZIqJ1OIu~YHOnebdPea1lBFypKyWYE7csrnOJxWa9dg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767838&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from combined strong and weak lensing analysis. Filled triangles show our results presented in this paper, whereas filled squares show results from literature; A1689, A370, CL0024, RX\u2003J1347 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>) and A383 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b140\" data-open=\"b140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011b</a>). The black shaded region indicates the predicted concentration parameters as a function of the halo mass with the lensing bias taken into account (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details). The solid line is the best-fitting mass\u2013concentration relation from fitting of our cluster sample (i.e. filled triangles), with the 1\u03c3 range indicated by dotted lines.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=2sEOqAwwY29lnVu6bcikGCMOCXz4fGAS3S2gbTE1ZmuejYgCATpk4Rt1GDoqUR9jQec3sfxutY84UOHwGd2KcqmAnL9Zlkscg8~mi8bxcAqUWni1IheS-AB40NazEZvQn8aoZNHpp238Q~bH6ge2BYr45MM8IKsqyCuPkNgP-z~-W~e64O0syv76VIC9RZTQKxkOL8BOna9zqAyOVs2P~cb4OPHihX0kHlboSCuT-r5B-8SChscRkCf8mm6zkq2NyYYRY4qj~AXDL5JiabTOfA~jtsL7tcWfuWIg8ihhV6JexuZkCfyGlkwRgxDIBR6QoAubz-KUlI2IyDi24u6YSg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from combined strong and weak lensing analysis. Filled triangles show our results presented in this paper, whereas filled squares show results from literature; A1689, A370, CL0024, RX\u2003J1347 (Umetsu et al. 2011b) and A383 (Zitrin et al. 2011b). The black shaded region indicates the predicted concentration parameters as a function of the halo mass with the lensing bias taken into account (see Appendix A, for details). The solid line is the best-fitting mass\u2013concentration relation from fitting of our cluster sample (i.e. filled triangles), with the 1\u03c3 range indicated by dotted lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767838/mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767838\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=ICLO5N6LmeCESFiCBk-zdYfocFj4ESdb5vS8sVL-CI30PyvSJG49gmEXNdUx6HixnwN9fKPq3Yu3iBIf7vY5oPTeXWSCwxvY0gUpaWRveOZl5ZBev7me99pUsd~N38Oax2T02GHq~ywfxTq~GuI92CgoU~2Ck9LT3oPZbZwtDS0~LnGpqXuC1cn7tKPe84wZFwFshZtRtggcwi5uqKc0G~rVbAVqUG0j2dWmaFNPC81PYMsZ-AMCBppEcaBgAuL23e8C1YUE2bd2qbLsThOUErxDWPlKi-IknElweL3YndiZIqJ1OIu~YHOnebdPea1lBFypKyWYE7csrnOJxWa9dg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767838&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from combined strong and weak lensing analysis. Filled triangles show our results presented in this paper, whereas filled squares show results from literature; A1689, A370, CL0024, RX\u2003J1347 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>) and A383 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b140\" data-open=\"b140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2011b</a>). The black shaded region indicates the predicted concentration parameters as a function of the halo mass with the lensing bias taken into account (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details). The solid line is the best-fitting mass\u2013concentration relation from fitting of our cluster sample (i.e. filled triangles), with the 1\u03c3 range indicated by dotted lines.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">To put this on a more quantitative footing, we fit the mass\u2013concentration parameter with both the normalization and the mass slope as free parameters. Here we ignore the redshift dependence of the mass\u2013concentration relation, given the predicted little evolution of the concentration of massive haloes with redshift (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b137\" data-open=\"b137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. 2011</a>). We use the following estimator for fitting:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m25\" content-id=\"m25\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m25.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m25.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=QtGejBhDeC~~YqXUx6iwA8ZKjiBYyxfsVYzCr0glsex~kjQGW0wExlIGlD4A6zG9juuvMIhys62xelNtmiTy14NLQVeJaTQtiNChwn3kaOcyZ0N4jVu8lrZldQB-8f5cFHPFUfg3qXaw2Do2JD51cdXzuw6qJqGjT7jvRq9eH7wUnwY3Dem~SxiGxZvB4FNnVqcwkp2hFN5I2F4lWrtrVg4JjNctwo5QxB7a~CyqgSxoFSd9EmoZ1UUF88oNgvwolAxfv-ZqImJbOvqA8MZZ2iLb8W6lRGZPamD~7lOuqdNF41KERx~uROMCCJHNdAkn6zwFJ6HXx9HVfi4AG-FIVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m25.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">25</span></div> where \u03c3<sub>st</sub> is the 1\u03c3 measurement error on log\u2003(<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>) for individual clusters from the lensing analysis (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>), and \u03c3<sub>in</sub>= 0.12 is the intrinsic dispersion predicted by our calculations. We find that the best-fitting mass\u2013concentration relation from our lensing sample of 28 clusters is<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m26\" content-id=\"m26\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m26.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m26.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=fU2i38ERfOsUPDCVGD4aHhJ2piQ1pw~fAnOuE8KwLZt-ZIUj0UIepY2gMxFKTug6KYomwaWLwpbGE0S1z91rFx~oaA6hdFBSbTUKzxSgCPxM4oEd8hDdj9IwG6aBuPGYbFHFmutY34tvSn-VBIhXHDtcEdC9D97D-e2sTlJFNfpRpPYLBAET0zNbDD4osLAy086B-a6vH6C7CL7yGKdmuC8hqWtpl4CSYLOFICX020uEUpX7cehyT0D67qWznHLRpEcYrOfggSBszoMbHsmKVYtLlBPHMiBlWS3Nf6BMhD6NMMb4cb75b9v-Q0rFf4eUKwq7ufE09C1hut6tW9i0Mw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m26.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">26</span></div> where we also included 1\u03c3 errors on the normalization and the slope.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We detect a strong mass dependence of the concentration parameter with the slope of \u22120.59 \u00b1 0.12 in our lensing sample, which should be compared with the predicted slope of \u2248\u22120.2 for the strong-lensing-selected sample of clusters. We note that steeper mass\u2013concentration relations than theoretical expectations were also suggested by previous weak lensing (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>) and X-ray (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Buote et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b124\" data-open=\"b124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schmidt &amp; Allen 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ettori et al. 2010</a>) analysis (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Biviano 2008</a>). Our result suggests that the observed mass\u2013concentration relation is in reasonable agreement with the simulation results for very massive haloes of <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The agreement may be even better if we adopt recent results of <em>N</em>-body simulations by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a>, who argued that previous simulation work underestimated the mean concentrations at high-mass end (see also Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>). In contrast, we find that observed concentrations are much higher than theoretical expectations for less massive haloes of <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, even if we take account of the mass dependence of the lensing bias.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A possible concern is the correlation of <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> for fitting of individual clusters which has been ignored in deriving the mass\u2013concentration relation. We examine the possible effect of the degeneracy between <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> by the following Monte Carlo simulation. For each cluster, we change best-fitting values of <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> by randomly picking up a point within the 1\u03c3 confidence region in the <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u2013<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> plane. After choosing new best-fitting parameters for all the clusters, we refit the mass\u2013concentration relation to derive best-fitting values of the normalization and slope in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m26\"></span><a href=\"#m26\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (26)</a>. We repeat this simulation for 300 times to check how the correlated errors between <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> can affect our conclusion. We find that the resulting distribution of the best-fitting normalization value is 7.6 \u00b1 0.2, and that of the slope is \u22120.56 \u00b1 0.05, which are small compared with the statistical errors shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m26\"></span><a href=\"#m26\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (26)</a>, suggesting that the effect of the correlated error is not very significant. We note that <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. (2010a)</a> also explored potential impacts of the degeneracy between <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> and <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> on their mass\u2013concentration measurement very carefully, and concluded that the effect is insignificant, which is consistent with our finding.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are a few possible explanations for the excess concentration for small mass clusters. Perhaps the most significant effect is baryon cooling. The formation of the central galaxy, and the accompanying adiabatic contraction of dark matter distribution, enhances the core density of the cluster and increases the concentration parameter value for the total mass distribution. This effect is expected to be mass-dependent such that lower mass haloes are affected more pronouncedly, simply because the fraction of the mass of the central galaxy to the total mass is larger for smaller halo masses. Indeed, simulations with radiative cooling and star formation indicate that the concentration can be significantly enhanced by baryon physics particularly for low-mass haloes (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b120\" data-open=\"b120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rudd, Zentner &amp; Kravtsov 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mead et al. 2010</a>), although the effect strongly depends on the efficiency of feedback (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b73\" data-open=\"b73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">McCarthy et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2010</a>). Thus baryon cooling appears to be able to explain the observed strong mass dependence at least qualitatively. More quantitative estimates of this effect need to be made using a large sample of simulated clusters with the baryon physics as well as the proper feedback model included.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767843 id=\"16767843\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5\u2002STACKING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767844 id=\"16767844\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-1>5.1\u2002Stacked tangential shear profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We can study the average properties of a given sample by stacking lensing signals. This stacked lensing analysis has been successful for constraining mean dark matter distributions of cluster samples (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mandelbaum et al. 2006b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Johnston et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Leauthaud et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010a</a>). Here we conduct stacking analysis of the tangential shear profile for our lensing sample for studying the mass\u2013concentration relation from another viewpoint. Note that the off-centring effect, which has been known to be one of the most significant systematic errors in stacked lensing analysis (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Johnston et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Mandelbaum, Seljak &amp; Hirata 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b101\" data-open=\"b101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Takada 2011</a>), should be negligible for our analysis, because of the detection of weak lensing signals for individual clusters and the presence of giant arcs which assure that selected centres (positions of the brightest galaxies in the strong lensing region) indeed correspond to that of the mass distribution.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We perform stacking in the physical length scale. Specifically, we compute the differential surface density \u0394\u03a3<sub>+</sub>(<em>r</em>) which is define by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m27\" content-id=\"m27\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0420-3213-m27.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-m27.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=nu3P~JnTWuKMdK8h6CBWpNtLSRDJo0GCzfX1yj0ZZCrkyq61DhApkCg8S4w-fyid6hm57xNpVedGfZTfoeanhjl1bFmhAZf3Adl3UMmOApxgFRB2DHrApKf3tNz7G9zM4pdpt31yXgP-S~EoIcsXTjK3U4YTk9tTOsZb2O4olUhGkDDeG8rhMLCnSNTDjJGeLkBYa314mMuS5ZUOSkwV-7g6K7tG38V0IxJ872UPQCsAvF1RHdUiV-3K5IJECSEVhcTOW6rheFS8KKwNekz8iips1vM8O4i1f7rYRTcb55X-TNTCkuddfxIGQI4ctghiaWjgmnCdFEwRDV3QS-tzIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-m27.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">27</span></div> where \u03a3<sub>cr</sub> is the critical surface mass density for lensing. We stack \u0394\u03a3<sub>+</sub>(<em>r</em>) for different clusters to obtain the average differential surface density. We do not include SDSS\u2003J1226+2149 and SDSS\u2003J1226+2152 in our stacking analysis, because these fields clearly have complicated mass distributions with two strong lensing cores separated by only \u223c3\u2003arcmin. Furthermore, we exclude SDSS\u2003J1110+6459 as well because the 2D weak lensing map suggests the presence of a very complicated mass distribution around the system. We use the remaining 25 clusters for our stacked lensing analysis.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">It should be noted that the reduced shear <em>g</em><sub>+</sub> has a non-linear dependence on the mass profile. In fact, the reduced shear is defined by <em>g</em><sub>+</sub>\u2261\u03b3<sub>+</sub>/(1 \u2212\u03ba), where \u03b3<sub>+</sub> and \u03ba are tangential shear and convergence. Thus, the quantity defined by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m27\"></span><a href=\"#m27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (27)</a> still depends slightly on the source redshift via the factor 1/(1 \u2212\u03ba), particularly near the halo centre. Thus, in comparison with the NFW predictions, we assume the source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 1.1, which is the typical effective source redshift for our weak lensing analysis (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>). Also the non-linear dependence makes it somewhat difficult to interpret the average profile, and hence our stacked tangential profile measurement near the centre should be taken with caution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is known that the matter fluctuations along the line of sight contributes to the total error budget (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dodelson 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gruen et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra et al. 2011</a>). While we have ignored this effect for the analysis of individual clusters presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>, here we take into account the error from the large-scale structure in fitting the stacked tangential shear profile by including the full covariance between different radial bins (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b101\" data-open=\"b101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Takada 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>, for the calculation of the covariance matrix). We, however, comment that the error of the large-scale structure is subdominant in our analysis, because of the relatively small number density of background galaxies after the colour cut (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to weak lensing, we stack strong lensing constraints simply by averaging the Einstein radii for the fixed source redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2. This constraint is combined with the stacked tangential shear profile from weak lensing to obtain constraints on the mass and concentration parameter for the stacked profile. Note that the Einstein radius is related with the reduced shear as <em>g</em><sub>+</sub>(\u03b8<sub>E</sub>) = 1. Given the uncertainty from the non-linearity of the reduced shear and the possible bias coming from the uncertainty of the outer mass profile (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Becker &amp; Kravtsov 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Hamana 2011</a>), we restrict tangential shear fitting in the range 0.158 &lt; <em>r</em> &lt; 3.16\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc. However, we note that our results are not largely changed even if we conduct fitting in the whole radius range.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a> shows the stacking result for all the 25 clusters. The mean cluster redshift for this sample is \u3008<em>z</em>\u3009= 0.469. The total S/N in the whole radius range 0.063 &lt; <em>r</em> &lt; 5.01\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc is S/N = 32. We find that stacked tangential shear profile from weak lensing is fitted well by the NFW profile over a wide range in radius. The average Einstein radius from strong lensing (\u3008\u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u3009= 14.4<sup>+10.6</sup><sub>\u22127.0</sub>\u2003arcsec) is slightly larger than the best-fitting model predicts (\u03b8<sub>E</sub>= 9.1\u2003arcsec), although they are consistent with each other well within 1\u03c3. The best-fitting mass and concentration are \u3008<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u3009= 4.57<sup>+0.33</sup><sub>\u22120.31</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003 M<sub>\u2299</sub> and \u3008<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u3009= 5.75<sup>+0.70</sup><sub>\u22120.57</sub>. We note that the mean mass measured by the stacking analysis agrees well with the mean mass of strong-lens-selected clusters predicted by ray-tracing simulations, \u3008<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u3009\u223c 4.2 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bayliss et al. 2011b</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"16767851\" scrollto-destination=\"16767851\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=UJXk86sl539xucpaUWSphGGaCDA~qKA8E2AF1X3ylkH0OLBcj0dACg5-zFARXB4smqLyM8Xsgf5bZyL~67Xsg8SzQCVNpP6SNGL-7Go-mALbtEHA-09Lu4K2mJau9dRJ~BMvJit8nvipVfiX~pV5X7U4P37GD2pTJU2QiLKr7t6ojYmnjthEde548oOm0-ceV07r6t5Lbf3XJgWcyc-mIMmAxU66mj8jr~nZO7HKor-r~xz-dZtjYuUvq12WM2UsVsWirZQM8vrHRXRfifk1I0XsYghNvWw7pOlS9DrkeoLen-ll5BJe9E1OwK6TrWeTytgwUW27jZ2lKCmLrTCJfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The stacked tangential shear profile obtained by combining the 25 clusters. The average differential surface density \u3008\u0394\u03a3+(r)\u3009 (see equation 27) is plotted as a function of the physical radius r. Grey points indicate stacked tangential shear measurements from weak lensing that are not used for fitting. The upper-left point with a horizontal error bar is the constraint from the average Einstein radius. The solid line with shading is the best-fitting NFW model with 1\u03c3 error range. The lower panel plots the stacked profile of the 45\u00b0 rotated component, \u3008\u0394\u03a3\u00d7(r)\u3009.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767851/mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767851\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=EQ8zkGg7xqccD2ocbmRHLvfo2rffeAtsTfAP~0Krt9tI9yP~pHMHGztII2dny0wv5DWvXXGjxwZkkTIdhnh0d5U-I09E7BUGzFYFTIKzcqwS5z1yFLNXuvRDCukfRGCoydiSN4sBHn~z6iFFUnHSAXTQS09tMD0eoQAsIVgLbUn1L0Fg0srdL5QEQ7KTiDtM5~l8ErBAubvdhPalnMOKGDva9RbF8i~fSMn189ASbSpyfszoiF9oMJQ6DdP4yjnhKod8wrUZeLhnwLuzj~FlbGhfMSVa0HD5n6fM9IEHCpXJybTVLcePWQQHk3JwDJk0GXsGAlBe7wrlPIYVTXPY-Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767851&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stacked tangential shear profile obtained by combining the 25 clusters. The average differential surface density \u3008\u0394\u03a3<sub>+</sub>(<em>r</em>)\u3009 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m27\"></span><a href=\"#m27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 27</a>) is plotted as a function of the physical radius <em>r</em>. Grey points indicate stacked tangential shear measurements from weak lensing that are not used for fitting. The upper-left point with a horizontal error bar is the constraint from the average Einstein radius. The solid line with shading is the best-fitting NFW model with 1\u03c3 error range. The lower panel plots the stacked profile of the 45\u00b0 rotated component, \u3008\u0394\u03a3<sub>\u00d7</sub>(<em>r</em>)\u3009.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=UJXk86sl539xucpaUWSphGGaCDA~qKA8E2AF1X3ylkH0OLBcj0dACg5-zFARXB4smqLyM8Xsgf5bZyL~67Xsg8SzQCVNpP6SNGL-7Go-mALbtEHA-09Lu4K2mJau9dRJ~BMvJit8nvipVfiX~pV5X7U4P37GD2pTJU2QiLKr7t6ojYmnjthEde548oOm0-ceV07r6t5Lbf3XJgWcyc-mIMmAxU66mj8jr~nZO7HKor-r~xz-dZtjYuUvq12WM2UsVsWirZQM8vrHRXRfifk1I0XsYghNvWw7pOlS9DrkeoLen-ll5BJe9E1OwK6TrWeTytgwUW27jZ2lKCmLrTCJfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The stacked tangential shear profile obtained by combining the 25 clusters. The average differential surface density \u3008\u0394\u03a3+(r)\u3009 (see equation 27) is plotted as a function of the physical radius r. Grey points indicate stacked tangential shear measurements from weak lensing that are not used for fitting. The upper-left point with a horizontal error bar is the constraint from the average Einstein radius. The solid line with shading is the best-fitting NFW model with 1\u03c3 error range. The lower panel plots the stacked profile of the 45\u00b0 rotated component, \u3008\u0394\u03a3\u00d7(r)\u3009.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767851/mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767851\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=EQ8zkGg7xqccD2ocbmRHLvfo2rffeAtsTfAP~0Krt9tI9yP~pHMHGztII2dny0wv5DWvXXGjxwZkkTIdhnh0d5U-I09E7BUGzFYFTIKzcqwS5z1yFLNXuvRDCukfRGCoydiSN4sBHn~z6iFFUnHSAXTQS09tMD0eoQAsIVgLbUn1L0Fg0srdL5QEQ7KTiDtM5~l8ErBAubvdhPalnMOKGDva9RbF8i~fSMn189ASbSpyfszoiF9oMJQ6DdP4yjnhKod8wrUZeLhnwLuzj~FlbGhfMSVa0HD5n6fM9IEHCpXJybTVLcePWQQHk3JwDJk0GXsGAlBe7wrlPIYVTXPY-Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767851&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stacked tangential shear profile obtained by combining the 25 clusters. The average differential surface density \u3008\u0394\u03a3<sub>+</sub>(<em>r</em>)\u3009 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m27\"></span><a href=\"#m27\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 27</a>) is plotted as a function of the physical radius <em>r</em>. Grey points indicate stacked tangential shear measurements from weak lensing that are not used for fitting. The upper-left point with a horizontal error bar is the constraint from the average Einstein radius. The solid line with shading is the best-fitting NFW model with 1\u03c3 error range. The lower panel plots the stacked profile of the 45\u00b0 rotated component, \u3008\u0394\u03a3<sub>\u00d7</sub>(<em>r</em>)\u3009.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The concentration parameter measured in the stacked tangential shear profile is broadly consistent with the result of individual analysis (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>), but appears to be slightly smaller than the mass\u2013concentration relation constrained from our lensing sample. Here we estimate the impact of the possible averaging effect by computing an average shear profile from reduced shear profiles of the NFW profile with best-fitting values of the mass and concentration from individual cluster analysis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>), and comparing it with the reduced shear profile of the NFW profile with the median values of the mass and concentration. We find that both profiles agree well near the virial radius, but the averaged profile underestimates the shear profile towards the centre, with \u223c10 per cent systematic difference at around 0.2\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc. Both the profiles agree well again at the innermost radii of &lt;0.1\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc down to the strong lensing region. The systematic difference translates into the concentration parameter of \u0394<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c\u22121.2, and hence it can partly explain the smaller concentration parameter value from the stacked lensing analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another possible reason for the smaller concentration from the stacked tangential shear is a wide range of \u03b8<sub>E</sub> of our sample, which results in the large error on the mean Einstein radius and therefore in the much weaker constraints from strong lensing compared with individual modelling cases. Hence, we conduct the same stacking analysis by dividing our cluster sample into three \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins. In order to assure reasonable constraints from strong lensing, we remove nine clusters which have large errors on \u03b8<sub>E</sub> mostly because of the lack of arc redshift information. To test the mass dependence of the concentration, in addition to \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins we consider three <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> bins too. We use all the 25 clusters for the mass bin analysis.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Results of our stacking analysis in different \u03b8<sub>E</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> bins are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 7</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, respectively, and are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t5\" data-open=\"t5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>. We find that clusters in the largest \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bin are indeed most massive. However, the second and third \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins have similar mean virial masses, and the difference of the Einstein radii appears to be derived by the different concentrations. On the other hand, different mass bins have similar Einstein radii, but the concentrations are clearly larger for smaller masses.</p>                        <a id=\"16767855\" scrollto-destination=\"16767855\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=fE4CEQd4Zdqfp6jnwDTnZTq3ofRil5ITfTcR7HeEkpZyyjIvECQVwAJ5ZwARrC~ZqbaawwuxbPN1FiLQ3ihTNcjOKEkWHMVmLEoyQxaTw1Uikbs0CxqSvUQmRU-S-IyNpG-P01Apzk9gLnfifFiA8nwFUKkMVb-hAyFdZyaSLZXV6W1XEWJ5VC3CQD-Y-MayRiX6dlM-aQ5ne6BYmSAYTBRHu4Q72a0aX8XsVROUgRGePucd0j~pR8~cdLSpc6Tbsg4tdI7Yup3QDki0Ypuf53mAS3THBmlpieMnpBAvOjLNW8V1W5ZE9iNVM6i5GpmX7dBg63qx3FHCqmaRhwjhCQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Similar to Fig. 6, but the stacked lensing analysis in three \u03b8E bins is presented. From top to bottom, results for largest to smallest \u03b8E bins are shown. Curves and points for the largest and smallest \u03b8E bins are shifted vertically by \u00b10.5 dex respectively for illustrative purposes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767855/mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767855\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=2BD~Uqice42qE~vZzjjml04B47eGhOfbsB9E-zEWIv08Z~RwYH9trPVW2WRm~yUO4DkwTYUDxb8mkZnuOdyIb7hFmcssZQ3DgtYjFiQ8XfgXoV~wb1rgnuBklZukjH0ZmJsE0YQaa5KKz~yZUA~hYeMLKKKqdwiz3RQ8zN3YOxp~8~iG8XMGL6QIgNL0GaEHz9vHQ6UjRTxPgfJVt8Tq986-upfj3Eu6EDT5PPfLVI4Pj2S3ybPzPhh6s2YRXFU8gdgzk9m0xhq07AkUYU8kMqiEzYcuBGcFUjvMRk35mtKHryPxRE8dsSFiQDpa8ywhHn~veZ2SAYffBYqEv-5ejQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767855&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similar to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>, but the stacked lensing analysis in three \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins is presented. From top to bottom, results for largest to smallest \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins are shown. Curves and points for the largest and smallest \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins are shifted vertically by \u00b10.5 dex respectively for illustrative purposes.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=fE4CEQd4Zdqfp6jnwDTnZTq3ofRil5ITfTcR7HeEkpZyyjIvECQVwAJ5ZwARrC~ZqbaawwuxbPN1FiLQ3ihTNcjOKEkWHMVmLEoyQxaTw1Uikbs0CxqSvUQmRU-S-IyNpG-P01Apzk9gLnfifFiA8nwFUKkMVb-hAyFdZyaSLZXV6W1XEWJ5VC3CQD-Y-MayRiX6dlM-aQ5ne6BYmSAYTBRHu4Q72a0aX8XsVROUgRGePucd0j~pR8~cdLSpc6Tbsg4tdI7Yup3QDki0Ypuf53mAS3THBmlpieMnpBAvOjLNW8V1W5ZE9iNVM6i5GpmX7dBg63qx3FHCqmaRhwjhCQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Similar to Fig. 6, but the stacked lensing analysis in three \u03b8E bins is presented. From top to bottom, results for largest to smallest \u03b8E bins are shown. class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><td>Sample\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>z</em>\u3009\u00a0</td><td>\u3008\u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u3009 (10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0</td><td>\u3008<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u3009\u00a0</td></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>All\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>0.469\u00a0</td><td>14.4<sup>+10.6</sup><sub>\u22127.0</sub>\u00a0</td><td>4.57<sup>+0.33</sup><sub>\u22120.31</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.75<sup>+0.70</sup><sub>\u22120.57</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>0.379\u00a0</td><td>22.8<sup>+4.3</sup><sub>\u22122.8</sub>\u00a0</td><td>6.03<sup>+0.74</sup><sub>\u22120.72</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7.94<sup>+1.28</sup><sub>\u22121.02</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>0.416\u00a0</td><td>13.0<sup>+2.4</sup><sub>\u22122.8</sub>\u00a0</td><td>3.13<sup>+0.50</sup><sub>\u22120.50</sub>\u00a0</td><td>10.23<sup>+2.65</sup><sub>\u22121.82</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>7\u00a0</td><td>0.471\u00a0</td><td>8.3<sup>+2.6</sup><sub>\u22122.4</sub>\u00a0</td><td>3.51<sup>+0.52</sup><sub>\u22120.52</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7.08<sup>+1.53</sup><sub>\u22121.12</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-1\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>0.480\u00a0</td><td>17.1<sup>+12.9</sup><sub>\u22126.4</sub>\u00a0</td><td>9.55<sup>+1.17</sup><sub>\u22121.04</sub>\u00a0</td><td>4.90<sup>+0.79</sup><sub>\u22120.73</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-2\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>0.472\u00a0</td><td>14.7<sup>+10.2</sup><sub>\u22125.7</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.62<sup>+0.61</sup><sub>\u22120.55</sub>\u00a0</td><td>5.37<sup>+0.87</sup><sub>\u22120.75</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>-3\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>0.460\u00a0</td><td>12.6<sup>+9.3</sup><sub>\u22127.8</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.97<sup>+0.32</sup><sub>\u22120.29</sub>\u00a0</td><td>10.59<sup>+4.54</sup><sub>\u22122.83</sub>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16767857\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">These results can be used to check the mass\u2013concentration relation inferred from individual analysis of clusters. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a> shows the mass\u2013concentration relation similar to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>, but this time the relation obtained from stacked lensing analysis. We find that the mass\u2013concentration relation from stacking analysis is in reasonable agreement with the best-fitting relation constrained from individual analysis of strong and weak lensing (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m26\"></span><a href=\"#m26\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 26</a>). In particular, the strong mass dependence of the concentration is clearly seen in the stacking analysis as well. The slightly smaller normalization compared with individual analysis can partly be ascribed to the averaging effect as described above. Thus the stacking analysis further confirms the measurement of the mass\u2013concentration relation from our sample of clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"16767859\" scrollto-destination=\"16767859\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=hRB~CP1Qh5uVi3K1oYvm-mINRG28wlXXx8VEaRjD34YbDdAQ8DepVIPQWWzLBNEb3zUezKQPi9Y5Nl-mBB3ZcUK8YmlKKbGPtfY~~kHTBy1NdEUoHvFrCplaLvn8bgvTgtL~Nb74PALlgkf9jLaimfwBs1qhZbH6K25yMQgisOaVXikxb6NwV9FZvA1PoXSU72CKWF27EAYadLq98S8eJ36epVD5zyev9cDo-lLivPRHk2Y6dfNCjizui8EfIO-dTq3nExSVvNidGmiHIOYyEujiOiBsZ0mCVZ8bBcRHgoXtm1MnLCzXQJQRpDobtxOOVdafILfjMjNAEXQSJbdPyw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from the stacked lensing analysis. The solid and dotted lines are best-fitting relation from individual analysis shown in Fig. 5.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767859/mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767859\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=Nr4MiVLMIwmBUmRJq8rDfs3Dj3kVps6XdbYOG4V3AHFefUvyodzxaDmxEwYeLVK5Ksnfy9KseRqXOmkEcFM6coDxySuRLXcu53VytCLvTGca8uystN6dYp7DR3Hb5UwFswW6vTlwsavx4sCC~8oVvON638OCvrnBVWnaJojN2dKQ4BbTAfi3Cs9wfYBvrlp2nX0Mk~vFLLVko1KKirYnfyrIR5dV842I~GNKe3cHyLAzZwqnorY0RZswLbFHeBaPbre66mv3dP33ciNaQ3KGKa6OIY1YQo4oOrDKfCcM9ptQ8MZu6xoEqt5OxX~1QdFxy3LRhcuni3-Eq7iV8GUBew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767859&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass\u2013concentration relation obtained from the stacked lensing analysis. We show stacking results of three \u03b8<sub>E</sub> bins (filled squares) and three <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> bins (open circles). The mass and concentration measured from stacked strong and weak lensing analysis of four massive clusters at <em>z</em>\u223c 0.32 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2011b</a>) are indicated by a cross. The black shading region shows theoretically expected mass\u2013concentration relations with the lensing bias (see Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a>, for details). The solid and dotted lines are best-fitting relation from individual analysis shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a> we study the dependence of concentration parameters derived from the stacking analysis with the Einstein radius. In particular, we compare it with semi-analytic calculation conducted in Appendix <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss11\"></span><a href=\"#ss11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">A</a> which predicts that the clusters with larger Einstein radii are more concentrated. While it is hard to see this trend in our cluster sample, we find that the high concentration of massive lensing clusters presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. (2011b)</a> can be explained in this context. Our result suggests that the average concentration of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b132\" data-open=\"b132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. (2011b)</a> cluster sample is in good agreement with the theoretical expectation given the very large Einstein radii of \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u223c 40\u2003arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"16767862\" scrollto-destination=\"16767862\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=0KpvS9TcLygjJ58X90iom-YQJHbb7YHkx02IYMySih4Mx42YbAxQHSpvU6HrqvL3i0-gLavJIQMnRauqxfDTIAGtr4MceZGSrm8EDi4amA4uBiQyLA8MEM6Sq4AF498LmuojeRBkFgp5X05NtMlFHLdF4d-6QOAUuQSiGSW7hhO8s5zb7yaGOhWMZDSJkDVZd2eVdx1Yu-bkky6eqVucEX8n3zOZXc~Z4f-JX3GSDIUj0D7wCHet2ZY7uy~C8U8utaukD3fcQToLDK4ZJrp80AzWhRT-6kb9SfXDnLhmNhtntjPJGZ1CBhLpisZMuFGpFAd7nh7CwdTzFWbrIdHuXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Concentration parameters from stacking lensing analysis as a function of the Einstein radius for the source redshift zs= 2.
