class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2010.408.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.408.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.408.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b139\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b139\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b139\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b139\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b139\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b139\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Barkana</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Rephaeli</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Y.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ben\u00edtez</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2011a</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">410</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1939</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b140\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b140\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b140\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b140\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b140\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b140\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div></span> <em>et al.</em>, <div class=\"year\">2011b</div>, preprint (arXiv:1103.5618)</p></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b141\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b141\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b141\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b141\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b141\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b141\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Zitrin</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Broadhurst</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bartelmann</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Rephaeli</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Y.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Oguri</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ben\u00edtez</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">N.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Hao</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div></div>\r\n <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Umetsu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">K.</div></div></span>, <div class=\"year\">2011c</div>, preprint (arXiv:1105.2295)</p></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16767966 id=\"16767966\" class=\"backappendixgroup-title js-splitscreen-backappendixgroup-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendices</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767968 id=\"16767968\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss11>APPENDIX A:\u2002EXPECTED PROPERTIES OF STRONG-LENSING-SELECTED CLUSTERS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We predict properties of clusters in our strong-lens-selected cluster sample using a semi-analytic model developed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a>, which is based on a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. In brief, a catalogue of haloes is generated according to the mass function and axial ratio distribution derived from <em>N</em>-body simulations, and each halo is projected along random direction to compute its lensing property (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b102\" data-open=\"b102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Keeton 2004</a>). The projected convergence profile is compared with that of a spherical NFW profile to estimate the mass <em>M</em><sub>vir,\u20032D</sub>, the concentration <em>c</em><sub>vir,\u20032D</sub>, and the ellipticity <em>e</em> of the projected mass distribution. Here we fix the lens (cluster) and source redshift to <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>= 0.45 and <em>z</em>= 2, respectively, which are typical for our cluster lens sample analysed in the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compute a giant arc cross-section \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> of each halo from ray-tracing of extended sources using <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri 2010</a>). The source is assumed to have a S\u00e9rsic profile with <em>r</em><sub><em>e</em></sub>= 0.4\u2003arcsec and the ellipticity randomly assigned between 0 and 0.5. For each cluster we compute the arc cross-section for the length-to-width ratio of <em>l</em>/<em>w</em> &gt; 5 by randomly throwing source galaxies in the source plane. Output images are convolved with the Gaussian kernel with the full width at half-maximum of 0.8\u2003arcsec in order to take account of the seeing effect.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We study the impact of the lensing bias by averaging concentrations and ellipticities of the halo catalogue with an appropriate weight that mimics our selection criteria. Obviously our cluster sample is weighted by the arc cross-section \u03c3<sub>arc</sub>, which can be a reasonable choice of the weight. Furthermore, we preferentially conduct follow-up observations for clusters with larger Einstein radii (i.e. giant arcs located more distant from the cluster centre), because they are expected to be more massive. We can model this selection effect, e.g. by multiplying <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-mu7.gif?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=Bk1UZ8Im5RbZMhrvQqI4LPK4I0QwwUzyw21SlbrCb3Oa1YW5P3H25NQM34YF~5QNvOKP0RyJV30eJq6LsiJVfGQfl4RFP9pCIiLKo0bWbTa0WS1raGV3Bcqxp35EjF9NWjCnY0iAvct3yKHcfpZPJsVYL1X2bEEw1ZvK-9QoogGP~B3uzjFvbN9~ZBFGEkN1DA6ln30KP0AdQCT71D5BW2-qn7a~Sq55h5VBcaHRajlU8Njf6fnhVHWUXXmCC-vLU0GzaGJAv1jaoyykblXxQ7mWkXhKD1J~wAI3BvFzGDnPfjjBQ7-5LVSaHN~2fEND0LqS0tUXuqiTcn0Q2RdAQA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-mu7.gif\" /></span> to the weight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f16\" data-open=\"f16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A1</a> shows the mass\u2013concentration relation derived from the projected mass distribution assuming a spherical mass distribution, which is relevant for the comparison with our lensing measurement, based on the semi-analytic calculation described above. We find that the enhancement of the concentration parameter due to the lensing bias is a strong function of the mass. For instance, when both the arc cross-section and the Einstein radius are used for computing the lensing bias, the concentration parameter is enhanced by \u223c80 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 8 \u00d7 10<sup>13</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, \u223c30 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 4 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> and \u223c20 per cent for <em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"16767982\" scrollto-destination=\"16767982\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=TLRM3PFi1pbNU~v4DEDzyhXvmoKOtrqUqvs~SR1aoBuveWEPN6lecme0oFccvnXp8xlgrvoZ0~WDFu6ZekQm72LDIz2BiTNnN~Bxv7tH65gWbiBaV8ACaF2c8jfGmTbETbtgR8EXWM0WPgrcRvJ~rRwzG8JbsYRgXGL-GszweHDu41IoeZv20tBcv~Pa0URr4FhZ37qVBRNGk8JHYE7i4oiYBNfjR30CWQBuwR0nlbi~faR0lwTujWCSKBzNMylYY2MpLHYfWzF0yBIGcvZbT5mNEl9vt2Sv3k6lBtke~xgj00oc5LVK7UTNq9OX~dYqc1CSZpIjyjemaac5z9xOXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for z= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3arc or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8E, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various N-body simulations (Duffy et al. 2008; Gao et al. 2008; Prada et al. 2011). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767982/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767982\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=KQ9knH-vjmjw3G5Gwvp1fdxKcgich67HAoIAx3fE1Ev5I8~litpTmMMIpQOYMQacNnK0~s2WKtg4nbJ0rsBWRx-iRnN8OslwrgNhO2SMpa6GjHWwHQjb2zWVDkGUmEAUla2TSScqXMz4BAQXRhsCWMbrrjuId3d~A-rWHrymaSga6v-QavpUhtAbmwB0SM6PZz5RrZYJhOQ1ppQH4B4qQ1-EFv~WjlJFDgavpu6yH-~~k8mgEF27BIF3gX21bgLy7LHHLuTQULZ6caHXnrfsiTfF6ULI6STl2mY4XmWxjocDsbux8yoLyRgWycwZ-Hj8tzBwMAr0~yjwvNvAC19Bpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767982&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for <em>z</em>= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various <em>N</em>-body simulations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. 2011</a>). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=TLRM3PFi1pbNU~v4DEDzyhXvmoKOtrqUqvs~SR1aoBuveWEPN6lecme0oFccvnXp8xlgrvoZ0~WDFu6ZekQm72LDIz2BiTNnN~Bxv7tH65gWbiBaV8ACaF2c8jfGmTbETbtgR8EXWM0WPgrcRvJ~rRwzG8JbsYRgXGL-GszweHDu41IoeZv20tBcv~Pa0URr4FhZ37qVBRNGk8JHYE7i4oiYBNfjR30CWQBuwR0nlbi~faR0lwTujWCSKBzNMylYY2MpLHYfWzF0yBIGcvZbT5mNEl9vt2Sv3k6lBtke~xgj00oc5LVK7UTNq9OX~dYqc1CSZpIjyjemaac5z9xOXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for z= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002). Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3arc or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8E, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various N-body simulations (Duffy et al. 2008; Gao et al. 2008; Prada et al. 2011). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767982/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767982\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=KQ9knH-vjmjw3G5Gwvp1fdxKcgich67HAoIAx3fE1Ev5I8~litpTmMMIpQOYMQacNnK0~s2WKtg4nbJ0rsBWRx-iRnN8OslwrgNhO2SMpa6GjHWwHQjb2zWVDkGUmEAUla2TSScqXMz4BAQXRhsCWMbrrjuId3d~A-rWHrymaSga6v-QavpUhtAbmwB0SM6PZz5RrZYJhOQ1ppQH4B4qQ1-EFv~WjlJFDgavpu6yH-~~k8mgEF27BIF3gX21bgLy7LHHLuTQULZ6caHXnrfsiTfF6ULI6STl2mY4XmWxjocDsbux8yoLyRgWycwZ-Hj8tzBwMAr0~yjwvNvAC19Bpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767982&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Upper: the mass\u2013concentration relation of the projected mass distribution for <em>z</em>= 0.45, predicted by a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a>. Crosses indicate the average concentration parameter from our semi-analytic calculation without any weighting, whereas filled triangles and open circles are average concentration parameters with the lensing bias, assuming weights from giant arc cross-sections \u03c3<sub>arc</sub> or arc cross-sections plus the Einstein radii \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, respectively. Lines are predicted mass\u2013concentration relation from spherical averaging of haloes in various <em>N</em>-body simulations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. 2011</a>). Lower: similar to the upper panel, but average ellipticities of the project mass distribution as a function of the mass are shown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also compare our result based on the triaxial model with other work studying the mass\u2013concentration relation in <em>N</em>-body simulations based on the spherical NFW profile. We find that our mass\u2013concentration relation has larger concentration than predicted by the relation of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a>, which has been adopted for comparisons with lensing measurements in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. (2009)</a>. On the other hand, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> concluded that concentrations of massive haloes evolve little with the redshift. As a result, concentrations predicted by the model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> are much larger compared with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a> relation predicts. We note that such little evolution of massive haloes has been noted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b136\" data-open=\"b136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. (2003)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b137\" data-open=\"b137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. (2009)</a>. Our mass\u2013concentration relation based on the triaxial model resides in between the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b115\" data-open=\"b115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Prada et al. (2011)</a> relations, and more resembles the relation presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. (2008)</a> which was essentially the modification of the model proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. (1997)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also investigate the impact of the lensing bias on the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution. We find that the lensing bias due to the arc cross-section tends to increase the mean ellipticity, which is understood by the fact that the ellipticity of the projected mass distribution significantly enhances the giant arc cross-section (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). In contrast, the lensing bias due to the Einstein radius decreases the mean Einstein radius, because of the alignment of the major axis with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>). Therefore, these two lensing biases counteract with each other. In either case, however, the effect of the lensing bias appears to be small, with the change of the mean ellipticity by \u223c0.05 at most.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a> has shown that extreme lensing clusters having very large Einstein radii are more severely affected by the lensing bias. Thus we check the dependence of the concentration and projected ellipticity on the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. For the mass distribution of the cluster, we assume a flat prior of log\u2003<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub> between 10<sup>14</sup> and 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and the number distribution predicted by the mass function of dark haloes above 10<sup>15</sup>\u2003<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>, which is expected to more or less resemble the selection function of our cluster sample. The result shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A2</a> indicates that both the concentration and ellipticity depend strongly on the Einstein radius such that clusters with larger Einstein radii are more concentrated and spherical. Again, this can be interpreted by the alignment of the major axis with the line-of-sight direction (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"16767989\" scrollto-destination=\"16767989\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=aWAzoqoLZXPiNVjQP7Yyjl3~d7Lngbo~7t9f97hnBE8vBHcqlqkZ6eIJbtJR3I9z4ms2z3BfKuG7FI-uXQLUK9frmkfYsSLWBdgA7PiwGr6OiZpktTvUE7GEr1a~PSixH2dW7RBlMUa6pYqBaQZHoCADgyw73smIzmQXkt-FC9JtV4jk6WlP31WE7M8umjXyslR0-N02VRtWE3UWOlf0sUaApPW3vPoDzLPcaOeDenz0V6qkBRYohHugt4YfvwkI298rVDFQoDjZOmZ2n~mqvNiusNd~QhIEr86dwpKXwc0rHEiryW3Qo-EGoflBNFPD2KKyK66YLw4ofpUZvxxjAA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8E. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002) and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767989/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767989\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=PSUOQmpaOqVnNG5OY2LmPHYuiV0WhoKN85EyUe0Th0fegQnuJU0bROnpH5YY5PM2DIFBRQPbzK9~FGRGvxPo7Ekb43j0oMsWdMBtxcb-EhLkeuSs1f9fclkTwk2I6wKnLFnGcmbrSgaT4MD8LZ1qxbdlcKGZ2VuYCKchCar9wovjN1HZjptHz~n4XoURy7SsDolBbTQUdWn7jMxVy1AvT92ubGUyUTISb5Z~9iOLJPh--MRvHi8WKt78yYcxl2yNqwSU4Eeh2fOun-cLoEeLXQIi599sWbzjKHHT~RGegp5z5h8~ydv3~Ypa36QezxbC1ErPKCvSJfwk8C~JtukHrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767989&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a> and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=aWAzoqoLZXPiNVjQP7Yyjl3~d7Lngbo~7t9f97hnBE8vBHcqlqkZ6eIJbtJR3I9z4ms2z3BfKuG7FI-uXQLUK9frmkfYsSLWBdgA7PiwGr6OiZpktTvUE7GEr1a~PSixH2dW7RBlMUa6pYqBaQZHoCADgyw73smIzmQXkt-FC9JtV4jk6WlP31WE7M8umjXyslR0-N02VRtWE3UWOlf0sUaApPW3vPoDzLPcaOeDenz0V6qkBRYohHugt4YfvwkI298rVDFQoDjZOmZ2n~mqvNiusNd~QhIEr86dwpKXwc0rHEiryW3Qo-EGoflBNFPD2KKyK66YLw4ofpUZvxxjAA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8E. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of Jing &amp; Suto (2002) and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16767989/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16767989\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&Signature=PSUOQmpaOqVnNG5OY2LmPHYuiV0WhoKN85EyUe0Th0fegQnuJU0bROnpH5YY5PM2DIFBRQPbzK9~FGRGvxPo7Ekb43j0oMsWdMBtxcb-EhLkeuSs1f9fclkTwk2I6wKnLFnGcmbrSgaT4MD8LZ1qxbdlcKGZ2VuYCKchCar9wovjN1HZjptHz~n4XoURy7SsDolBbTQUdWn7jMxVy1AvT92ubGUyUTISb5Z~9iOLJPh--MRvHi8WKt78yYcxl2yNqwSU4Eeh2fOun-cLoEeLXQIi599sWbzjKHHT~RGegp5z5h8~ydv3~Ypa36QezxbC1ErPKCvSJfwk8C~JtukHrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16767989&ar=973116&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The average concentration (filled squares) and ellipticity (open triangles) of the projected mass distributions as a function of the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>. They are derived from a triaxial halo model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jing &amp; Suto (2002)</a> and include the effect of the lensing bias from the arc cross-section.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16767991 id=\"16767991\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss12>APPENDIX B:\u2002LENSING ANALYSIS FOR INDIVIDUAL CLUSTERS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Figs <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f18  f24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f18  f24\" data-open=\"f18  f24\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1\u2013B7</a>, we show for each cluster the critical curve of the best-fitting strong lens modelling plotted on the Subaru/Suprime-cam <em>gri</em>-composite image (2 \u00d7 2\u2003arcmin<sup>2</sup>; squares are positions of multiple images used for mass modelling), weak lensing mass map plotted on the Subaru/Suprime-cam <em>r</em>-band image (contours are drawn with spacing of 1\u03c3 noise level, and the cross indicates the position of the brightest cluster galaxy), and the tangential shear profile as well as the best-fitting NFW profiles. The shading in the tangential profile plot indicates the measured Einstein radius and its 1\u03c3 error at the arc redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"16767995\" scrollto-destination=\"16767995\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure B1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/420/4/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2011.20248.x/2/m_mnras0420-3213-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265596&amp;Signature=eTe8kjOXiRgEGsRrIRNkzpB264fgyge9cpyI1hzyZmgWrk999ABZkj-smvKwHZx9jLGcyqFt6~znJ7S5C-oYdlW7ZsGVWtklvbin37XUMgBq8oMqkct-5m-gmkI5aUy1WJiW9PwmfOPjNwJNI6V2yb5W7tKwOrWv3RT9S-goshqzZjfrEzcO7fHaR09p3epCX0F8L1tT55QyhExVVhoW5-twTf5KTeDwM9Gq~1TErTgKpFFUIA-WBnVInA39FtOTtAaftKG4L~lLrFKjKdKz1MH7kKbHTK0kuQF0eCdzG3WEzr1nir7GH3FfxWH6XuSRoOgwsyyyAIRKDara4S-D1w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SDSS\u2003J0851+3331, SDSS\u2003J0915+3826, SDSS\u2003J0957+0509, SDSS\u2003J1004+4112.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0420-3213-f18.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a from the projected mass distribution assuming a spherical mass distribution, which is relevant for the comparison with our lensing measurement, based on the semi-analytic calculation described above. clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. In this case we show the redshift of the main arc.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note233\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note233\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> is measured east of north.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note234\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note234\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup><em>References.</em> 1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span>Bayliss et al. clusters there are multiple arcs with different source redshifts. In this case we show the redshift of the main arc.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note233\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note233\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>The position angle \u03b8<sub><em>e</em></sub> is measured east of north.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t2_note234\"></span><div content-id=\"t2_note234\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup><em>References.</em> 1 \u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span>Bayliss et al. We show the median of stellar ellipticities before (<em>e</em>*<sub>raw</sub>) and after (<em>e</em>*<sub>cor</sub>) the PSF correction (numbers in parentheses are standard deviations), the number of stars used for the PSF correction (<em>N</em>*), the number density of source background galaxies (<em>n</em><sub>g</sub>), the <em>r</em>-band magnitude limit of source background galaxies (<em>r</em><sub>lim</sub>), the mean lensing depth (\u3008<em>D</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>D</em><sub>os</sub>\u3009) and the effective source redshift (<em>z</em><sub>s, eff</sub>), the range of the radii for tangential shear fitting (\u03b8 range), and the total S/N of the tangential shear profile.</p></div> </div><div 3</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the weak lensing analysis.
